It says that you cannot sign the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation because it would impede this minister launching on his human rights campaign in the region, particularly against Burma. Can everyone recall Mr Downer's loud public campaign against the Burmese regime? Can you remember his policy of human rights constructive engagement with the Burmese military junta? Can you remember also what a particularly successful policy that has been? Have you noticed this morning's news report that Aung San Suu Kyi has been given another 12 months in home detention? I do not think it has succeeded, Minister. But the principle you argue is this: if you sign this thing you cannot talk about human rights in the region. There is a problem. Alex has a problem. Alex's problem is called: Dr Mahathir Mohamad. Dr Mahathir Mohamad—whom I thought was the Prime Minister of Malaysia, a member of ASEAN and, therefore, a signatory to the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation—only last year said:

quote.para: We—

speech.para: in Malaysia—

quote.para: are very disappointed over these things—

speech.para: in Burma—

quote.para: and, of course, we have done our very best to try to get them to change their minds.

speech.para: That is a statement from the Malaysian Prime Minister, hopping right into the Burmese regime. So much for the TAC, the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation, preventing the Malaysian Prime Minister from hopping into the Burmese, and they were all members of ASEAN—they are not even external adherents to the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation. That argument goes down in a screaming heap. Why has the minister advanced both these bogus arguments, apart from his jolly old Adelaide sense of humour? It is along these lines, Minister: you know, as I know, that the doctrine of military pre-emption stands there like a huge boulder in the middle of the road. And as a foreign policy professional himself in the past, he knows that that policy, frankly, is completely negative as far as Australia's long-term national security interests are concerned. The Howard doctrine of military pre-emption makes no sense whatsoever. We have a Prime Minister trying to wriggle out from under it, saying, `Oh, gee, we'll never use it anyway.' It begs the question: if you would never use it, why have it? If you do not believe that this doctrine is valid for Australia's circumstances then why do you maintain it? The bottom line is this: that is the real reason.

My appeal to the parliament, and through the parliament to the executive and to this minister, is this: given that Australia's long-term national economic and security interests are at stake here, is it too much to ask, Minister, for you to have the courage of your convictions to formally advise your Prime Minister that he has got it wrong, that he needs to swallow his pride, say that this thing is absolutely incompatible with Australia's national security and foreign policy interests and indicate a positive response to the possibility of Australia embracing the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation. That is the challenge which lies in your in-tray, Minister for Foreign Affairs. If you are in any way up to the challenges of the office which you hold, you would discharge it with courage, not with the lack of courage we have seen today. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This MPI, on the day when the Prime Minister is in Vientiane at the historic summit with 10 ASEAN heads of government, is a spiteful MPI. It is driven by spite, because if you supported Australia's participation in the region you would use today as a day to celebrate what the government has achieved and what the Prime Minister is doing; you would not, as an act of spite, move a motion in the parliament to attack the Prime Minister on this very day. I regard this as a typical example of what has happened to the Australian Labor Party. Its day-by-day tactic is based on newspapers but no strategy. No thought goes into what the medium- and long-term approach of the Australian Labor Party should be. We have childish hyperbole from the opposition spokesman on foreign affairs about how Australia is trashing its relations with Asia on the very same day that the Prime Minister is in Asia at a historic summit. How mature would the political point be that, for all the breathlessness of the Keating government about engaging with our own neighbours—as though somehow there was something unnatural about engaging with your own neighbours—they never went to a summit of this kind, and nor did the Hawke government? There are historic reasons for why these things happen and why they do not happen, but as a government we have been committed to building our engagement with Asia, but we do it from a position of strength and national pride—not a position of begging, not a position of weakness—and we have achieved great things.

speech.para: Today is a day when you would expect more than one side of the parliament to be celebrating the achievement of Australia beginning to negotiate a free trade area between Australia, New Zealand and the 10 ASEAN countries. Other than the FTA that we have negotiated with the United States of America, this has the potential to be one of the greatest steps forward in Australian trade and foreign policy. And the Labor Party uses a day like this to move a childish, hyperbolic motion like this, just out of spite. If I may say so, it explains why they lost the last election: no strategy, no intellectual thought given, just tactics day by day. Tom Allard, from the Sydney Morning Herald, writes a beat-up story about the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation—and who is first to the microphone? None other than the member for Griffith, driven not only by political expediency but by his passionate desire to replace the member for Werriwa as the Leader of the Opposition. The last time he had a go at that, he had one vote: he had the vote of the member for Griffith. He had no other votes, so he had to withdraw. He is having another go at it—that is what he is dedicated to doing—and spiteful MPIs of this kind being moved by the opposition on a day of great achievement for Australian foreign policy just about says it all. It just about says it all about the opposition.

Today is Tuesday. Next Monday, the foreign minister of Indonesia and I will be chairing and co-hosting, in Yogyakarta, a historic interfaith dialogue, bringing together religious leaders from the different countries in the region to promote religious tolerance and to talk about the bonds that different religions represented through this region have and the values that these religions share. This is an initiative being pursued by the Australian government in cooperation with the Indonesian government, and yet we have this childish assertion—and it can be called nothing more than childish—that the government does not wish to engage with Asia.

The Australian foreign minister and the Thai foreign minister a few months ago in Bangkok co-hosted the second regional ministerial HIV-AIDS summit. HIV-AIDS is a big issue in the region; it is something that I think we, as a sophisticated and successful country, should make a contribution to addressing in the region. We co-hosted the second of those summits. The first of those summits was held in Melbourne in October 2001. It was chaired by me, and that was the first time ministers from the Asia-Pacific region had got together to address the issue of HIV-AIDS. The member for Griffith talks about arrogance. He moves an MPI but then arrogantly listens to none of the debate except his own hyperbolic remarks, his spiteful remarks. He has nothing else to offer to this parliament but spite and hyperbole. This was a very historic contribution by Australia to addressing the issue of HIV-AIDS in the region.

When it came to counter-terrorism, it was Australia, with Indonesia, which co-hosted in February this year the first Asia-Pacific ministerial meeting on counter-terrorism, which was another historic contribution by Australia to the affairs of the region. Out of that has been established the Jakarta Centre for Law Enforcement Cooperation. It is an Australian-Indonesian initiative, and it is helping to develop the capabilities the region needs to counter terrorism. I think we have signed nine bilateral memoranda of understanding on counter-terrorism with our regional neighbours, and we signed a counter-terrorism declaration with ASEAN as a whole. It is another illustration of the work the government is doing in the region this time to address the issue of terrorism and to help to develop the capacity of the region to deal with the issue of terrorism.

On the economic front, I hope Australians generally, and the parliament in particular, will understand that today is a very historic day in terms of our long-term prospects for economic integration with the region, which I myself am very committed to. The Labor Party of course wants to distract people's attention from this to the parliament, because it does not want them to see the government succeed. The government has been democratically elected by the people of Australia, regrettable as that may be to the Australian Labor Party, and the government is the government of Australia, whatever political party it may comprise. I would have hoped all Australians today would wish the Prime Minister well at this historic summit. I think all Australians, except for the 60—I think there are only 60—members of the Australian Labor Party in this chamber do wish the Prime Minister well. It does not matter whether they are Labor voters in the electorates of Greenway, La Trobe or Bowman or whichever electorate they may be in or whether they are Labor voters in the electorate of Mayo—and 16 per cent of people in my electorate voted Labor at the last election; there were some.

talk.start.para: —Name them!
—I think I could, actually; I think I pretty much know who they are!

—It is the modern Labor Party; it is the Labor Party of 2004. In Ben Chifley's day they did much better down there in what is now Mayo. I am sure all those Labor voters wish the Prime Minister well on this historic day—except the 60 members of the Latham Labor Party in here, who wish the Prime Minister a terrible day and hope everything goes wrong. The member for Griffith has been doing all he can to whip up opposition to the Prime Minister.

—It is entirely true. You have no strategy; in the Labor Party you just have tactics. The election may be over, but there will be another one. It will be in three years time. For three years we are going to keep belting you about not having any strategy, not having any tactics, not having any policies.
—I would like to know who you are. I believe you are a member of the House of Representatives. You have a badge on your lapel. You have not made much of an impact here, I can assure you.
(Mr Jenkins)—Order! The minister will refer his remarks through the chair.

—But seriously, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Labor Party wishes ill will on the Prime Minister today, and they would not have moved this spiteful MPI if they did not. It is a classic example of what is wrong with Latham Labor. The member for Griffith wants it to be Rudd Labor. Rudd Labor? I think not, actually. I do not think that is going to happen. But nevertheless it is all about the fact that there is an opportunity here to get into the media. Doorstops are held, and sincerely held. The phrases have all been thought out beforehand. Out they come: `the horrific Howard government', `Howard's a fascist'—all this sort of stuff—`Howard hates Asia'. It all comes pouring out: the invective, the abuse, the denigration and—you come back to the word—the spite. It is all there. And then off he goes, prances off into his office, no doubt makes himself a cup of tea or coffee or whatever he does in his office in the morning and rings up a few of his mates just to make sure they are onside, sharpening their knives and putting their knives into Biff—that is the game most of the day.

speech.para: Another opportunity arises: somebody says, `What are we going to move an MPI on today?' That is one of the things you can do in opposition: you can spend the morning talking about what the MPI is going to be. I remember. You have to have it in by 12 o'clock, so you all ring each other up: `Oh, please, can I have it?' And Mr Spiteful here rings up and says, `Can I put in an MPI saying Howard is a dud on the day he's having a summit with the ASEAN leaders? Please, Biff, can I put in an MPI saying Howard's a dud?' And what does Biff say? `Yes, of course, mate. I don't know what's going on. I've never even heard of the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation, mate. In Green Valley we haven't been hearing of that.' And that is what it is all about; that is what has happened here today.

The opposition have never asked a question about the free trade agreement between Australia, ASEAN and New Zealand. They used to attack the FTA with the United States, and they asked a lot of questions about that. The Leader of the Opposition came out and initially said he was opposed to it. `If I had to vote on that today, I'd vote against it,' is what he said

talk.start.para: —That is right. That was why he said he would vote against it. But we have an FTA with Thailand. Do the opposition even know what the FTA with Thailand is about? Some of the members of the opposition are so invisible they would not even know there was an FTA with Thailand, or the FTA with Singapore, or the prospect of an FTA with Malaysia, or the prospect of an FTA with China. Are these of any interest to the opposition? There are no questions about them, just about the United States, because the old bourgeois left of the Labor Party are pretty anti-American. We have heard about the branch meetings—all the sneering and jeering at Bush, the Bushies and all this sort of thing. We know what goes on in the Labor Party, and it all spills over into here.

speech.para: They were against a free trade agreement with the United States, but eventually realised that was too politically difficult to sustain, and never even raised a question about free trade agreements with any Asian country at all—not a question. They are not serious. This is not a political party which should be taken seriously any longer at the federal level. They have had their opportunity to work through decent policies, to think up a strategy. And they lost the election—that is fair enough. It is tough when you lose an election, but you have to come back and rebuild.

talk.start.para: —You are so funny!

—Most of us do not laugh with joy when we lose elections, even if the member for Griffith does. Usually when we lost elections we felt a bit depressed, but not the member for Griffith, because he sees it as his chance—his chance to get the leadership of the Australian Labor Party. By the way, I can predict you won't. But the fact is the Labor Party have started the new parliament making exactly the same mistakes they made in the last one and the one before that. The last two elections in a row they have gone backwards and further backwards. And in this parliament they are going to use the same tactics. This MPI is a tactical and a strategic mistake. Labor should support the government in its engagement with Asia, not be spiteful.

—There has been a visible change in the government. People today have really noticed it. We saw today—as the foreign affairs minister scurries out of the chamber—that there has been a huge visible change in the government's attitude, in the way it is presenting ideas, in the way it is putting forward its fourth-term agenda. There is no doubt that, with that visible change, it believes, firstly, that it is invincible—that all its policies have been somehow vindicated, that it is right in everything it does; and, secondly, that it can do no wrong—no matter what it says, no matter what it does, no matter what its policies are, there is just no way it can do any wrong.

speech.para: But what is more disturbing is that it thinks it has some sort of absolute mandate to take every single idea it has and project it forward—that everything it has as an idea and policy suddenly has an absolute mandate from the community. The government is absolutely wrong on that count. Before I go on with that I want to make mention of the commitment of the foreign affairs minister to this topic. He says we should take it seriously, but have a look at the time that this minister actually spent in the 15 minutes that he had on the clock to actually deal with the issue, to actually deal with the treaty. He probably spent about 12 minutes out of 15 talking about the Labor Party, talking about our electoral aspirations, talking about us; he spent very little time talking about the actual treaty itself. I think that shows the dedication; it shows the time the minister has actually spent either (a) understanding the issue or (b) taking the issue seriously. Well, on this side of the House, we actually think this treaty is a very serious issue.

What this government has done through its election win is become very arrogant. We heard that from the member for Griffith, who dealt very eloquently with this arrogance. We saw today in question time just how arrogant this government can be. The foreign affairs minister also spoke about the historic summit at which the Prime Minister is present today. I agree: this is a historic summit, a very important summit. He said that we do not wish the Prime Minister well. I think he is wrong. Members on this side actually do wish the Prime Minister well, because he is representing all of us—he is representing all of Australia. This is something the foreign affairs minister does not understand. The arrogance has gotten to his brain and he does not understand that we do wish the Prime Minister well, because he represents all of us—he represents the people of Australia.

We wish Australia well. We actually wish that we get something out of this summit. It has been a long, 30-year road to get to this summit, so we take it very seriously. The message I would give to the foreign affairs minister and, through him, the Prime Minister is: do not miss this opportunity. Do not miss this historic moment and this great opportunity that we have now been given. Do something significant with it rather than just squander it by coming into this place, just talking about us and refusing to either listen to the Australian people or meet the needs of Australia.

The minister came in here and spent the majority of his time talking about us and very little time actually dealing with the issues before him. But none of this is new. The people who have followed the speeches of the foreign affairs minister would understand a little bit of history about how we have actually got to today. They would understand the attitude of this government, the arrogance that I am talking about and their attitude of being the deputy sheriff of our region—a ridiculous proposition—or lap-dog of the United States. This is a silly policy that the government has progressively tried to distance itself from but has not completely walked away from. We know that it is still there, locked away in their mind. It is still part of their arrogant thinking towards foreign affairs.

The most ridiculous of all—it is more than ridiculous; it is actually frightening—is the one about military pre-emption. Somehow, in our neighbourhood and region, we are different to every other country. That is the message this Prime Minister and foreign affairs minister send out on a regular basis. Somehow we are not like they are. Somehow we are different. Somehow we can afford to have a different policy to the rest of our region. Somehow we can say to our neighbours, `We reserve the right to unilaterally come into your country and have a pre-emptive strike on your national territory because we believe that you may not be doing enough.'

I see a couple of government members here, including one at the table. There are only two members of the government here. That is how important they think the debate on this treaty is. They have this attitude that somehow we have this right. If the tables were reversed—and this is something the government should really think about—and any one of our regional neighbours were to copy identically the government's policy, what would be their reaction? What would be the foreign affairs minister's reaction if Malaysia or the Philippines or Laos or any other nation in our region were to put into place the same policies? I think we would be a little bit concerned and we would have a right to be, just as they are concerned about this government's attitude towards them. We talk about missed opportunities, wishing the Prime Minister well and the great opportunities for Australia. I say: do not miss those opportunities; take them today. Go to this ASEAN summit today, after a long, 30-year road towards us being involved, and take the opportunities. Seize the day and actually do something with this. We do wish the Prime Minister well on behalf of all Australians.
This Treaty of Amity and Cooperation in South-East Asia is not a new one. It actually dates back to 24 February 1976. I want to put two of its articles on record. Article 1 says:

quote.para: The purpose of this Treaty is to promote perpetual peace, everlasting amity and cooperation among their peoples which would contribute to their strength, solidarity and closer relationship,

speech.para: I do not see anything too wrong with that. I actually think that is a good thing. That is something that we on this side of the House support. I cannot understand why the government would not support such a proposition. Article 2 of the treaty states that the signatories:

quote.para: ... shall be guided by the following fundamental principles:
a. Mutual respect for the independence, sovereignty, equality, territorial integrity and national identity of all nations;

speech.para: I do not see too much wrong in that. I think this is a good thing. This is something that the government should support. It also states that other fundamental principles are the right of every state to lead its national existence free from external interference, subversion or coercion and no interference in the international affairs of one another's states. Settlement of differences or disputes by peaceful means, the renunciation of the threat of use of force and effective cooperation among themselves should be the guiding principles. These principles, to all fair-minded Australians, would be more than reasonable. We would say, `Please, can we line up to sign this treaty? This is a fair and good thing.' But somehow this government thinks it is not.

Somehow this government is telling the people of Australia, our regional neighbours and the global community that it does not agree with mutual respect for independence, sovereignty, equality, territorial integrity or national identity of all nations. How can that be? How can this government be so arrogant domestically and globally that it would refuse to sign this treaty? I am bewildered by its attitude. We have had the necessity today of coming into this chamber to put this very important public matter before the chamber and raise this issue. This should have been a non-issue. This should have been a great opportunity seized upon by this government to actually give Australia a renewed international image of cooperation with our regional neighbours and partners which we could have been proud of into the future rather than the sort of foreign affairs direction that we have been getting from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Prime Minister or, for that matter, many people on the government benches.
I think that if most reasonably minded government backbenchers took the time to read the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation they would be asking questions within their own caucus as to why—

talk.start.para: —Have you read it?

—I would ask the member for Blair whether he has read it. Would you like me to table it for you? I do not think that the member for Blair realises that the treaty actually exists. What he should realise—and this is very important—is that his government is actually standing in the way of a great opportunity for Australia.
—Not true!

—He says he could not agree more. I agree with him. This is a great opportunity for Australia. We should seize the day and do something positive. Let my voice and that of the member for Griffith, the shadow foreign affairs minister, not be the only voices on why we should be a part of this treaty. The government gives only two excuses. I would just put them down as excuses as I cannot see that they are much more than that. One is that somehow this would restrict the government's ability to speak up on human rights abuses. I will not go into great detail in reference to Burma, in particular, because I do not have enough time left on the clock. The reality is that they are just excuses and they are not satisfactory.

speech.para: In conclusion, I say that we will miss a great opportunity. It is obvious from what is happening today with the Prime Minister at the summit is that he is putting his own personal perspectives and interests above the national interest. That concerns me. Australia does deserve better. We all deserve better. This should be a government for all of the people, not just some of the people.

talk.start.para: —I am glad to hear that the member for Oxley wishes the Prime Minister well in his endeavours in Vientiane. I cannot help but notice the irony of having a member for Oxley wishing the Prime Minister well in going to Vientiane to seek to advance Australia's position and develop issues such as free trade in the world marketplace. Historically, the idea of those words coming from a member for Oxley might be a surprise for some, but I can tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that there are many people in Australia—the vast majority of Australians—who are wishing the Prime Minister well in these endeavours because the opportunities for Australia that flow from this are fantastic, and we really need to be part of it.

speech.para: I do, however, agree with the Minister for Foreign Affairs when he cites the spite that is coming from the opposition foreign affairs spokesman on this issue. Why is there spite coming from him? The fact is that Labor, in opposition and in the time they were in government, built this massive molehill around their commitment to Asia, their pre-eminence in their devotion to Asia and their willingness to place a relationship with Asia above everything else, and that included many of the other important relationships that Australia holds throughout the world. The fact is that today really is the high point of our relationship with Asia. Through the ASEAN leaders' forum we have tremendous opportunity to develop free trade for the benefit of Australia, and it is happening now; it is not happening courtesy of a Labor Party government, courtesy of a Labor Party initiative. That is where the spite springs from.

What was the lowest point in our relationship with that region? It was probably the celebrated time when the former Labor Prime Minister Paul Keating made some ill-advised comments about the Malaysian leader Mahathir Mohamad. He made the statement at the time that the Malaysian leader was a recalcitrant, which has echoed down the years to today. It has echoed again and again and it still is with us today. In fact, it has taken this Prime Minister and this government to develop the relationship to the point it is at today from the low point we experienced at that time. Now we are approaching the prospect of the first visit by Abdullah Badawi, the Malaysian Prime Minister. That is the first opportunity for a visit from a Malaysian Prime Minister to our shores in 20 years. The milestone that this represents has been trumpeted in the media in Australia, quite correctly. Even as far back as June 2004 the Age wrote that the `moves point to a major change in bilateral relations after years of political upheaval'. So it really is very much a high point in our relationship with Asia.

One thing that should be looked at very closely is the statement by the opposition foreign affairs spokesman that Australia's future will be entirely shaped by the economies of this region. That is the core of the Labor Party view on this issue. I think we should look, for a moment, at the United States economy and what sort of impact that has on the world and on Australia's place in the world and our opportunities for trade.

In 1980 the US accounted for 25 per cent of the world economy. In 2001 the US economy accounted for 34 per cent, or more than a third, of world GDP. That is still the world's greatest, biggest economy. US military expenditure is nearly $400 billion—six times that of the next largest, Russia, at $60 billion, and 10 times that of China at $42 billion. So to say that Australia's future will be entirely shaped by the economies of this region, as the opposition likes to put it, is to cut out the US and say: `What is that? It is 34 per cent of the world GDP but, hey, our economy is going to be shaped by the region, and that's it.' This is a position that flows, I suppose, from the anti-US position that has been articulated again and again, particularly by the Leader of the Opposition. It is mouthed also by his followers, people such as the member for Griffith.

Of course, exports in this country are very important to us. Our opportunities in trade are very important, particularly in rural areas where it is estimated that one in four jobs comes from exports. The current problem with the current account deficit and the slide in the US dollar and the climb of the Australian dollar to US79c is a real challenge for us. How do we address that? We have to address that through better trade deals—through things such as the free trade agreement with the US, the trade deal that has been negotiated with Thailand and the trade deals with other countries, such as Singapore. We must set out to try and establish relationships that can overcome problems such as an Australian dollar at US79c. That is something that is a challenge.

In my area, for example, the pork industry has to try to compete against overseas countries, many of whom are heavily subsidised. That high Australian dollar is something that is very hard for us to combat, and we have to try and establish for ourselves trade relationships that overcome it. Since the coalition came to government, our exports have increased in value from around $100 billion to around $143 billion—a 40 per cent increase over 8½ years at a time when world merchandise export growth has fallen. That is quite significant. These are the achievements of the coalition government. How are we doing it? By seeking to develop trade in this way. We do it effectively through measures such as those being discussed in Vientiane.

I would just like to quote, from the Melbourne Age editorial today, some of the opportunities that come from the possibility of us establishing a free trade agreement involving ASEAN, Australia and New Zealand. It said:

quote.para: Annual two-way trade with Australia already stands at $33 billion and the summit's main goal has been to endorse a timetable to conclude a free trade agreement covering a market of more than 600 million people by as early as 2007—

speech.para: that is a huge opportunity for Australia—

quote.para: with the eventual prospect of an expanded free trade area involving partners such as China and India. This would cover a third of the world's population. If ASEAN begins these negotiations, Australia can consider this week a success.

speech.para: I say that it will be much more than a success; I say that it will be a huge triumph, a huge opportunity—something that I think sticks right in the craw of the member for Griffith, and he should not be taking that attitude. He should be applauding the steps that the government is taking, not seeking to sink the steps that the government is taking, seeking to belittle them.

I would also like to touch on the rhetoric that the opposition are using to deal with this issue, this beat-up they are running in relation to what they call the doctrine of military pre-emption. In order to have something that is a doctrine of military pre-emption, you would have to be assuming that an attack on Australia was imminent, that there was no other way of addressing it and that the other country would not act, and therefore you would take direct action. Those are the sorts of things that have been taken into account in relation to Australia, with the position that the Prime Minister has articulated. He has said that, if there was likely to be an imminent attack, if there was no other way of addressing it and if the other country would not act to stop it, the government would act to defend Australians. That is a logical position. But to categorise it as a doctrine of military pre-emption is to infer that an attack on Australia may not be imminent and yet you would still act, that you might attack when there was some other way of addressing it or that you might attack when the other country was prepared to act.

Quite clearly, those important conditions, those circumstances that the Prime Minister has brought clearly front and centre, are being glossed over by members opposite and are being neglected and taken out of the debate. And those are very important issues, because it is a simple matter of logic that if Australian interests are threatened, at the end of it all, it is the obligation of every single member of this House and the Prime Minister to ensure that Australians are protected. That is our job, and that is the basic statement that has been made by the Prime Minister, something that is continually glossed over and misrepresented by the members opposite. Today they were characterising the policy, saying that the Prime Minister was saying, `Get lost, jump in the lake and drop dead.' That is the kind of beat-up that we are getting from members opposite, instead of proper consideration of the issues. (Time expired)

debateinfo.title: FAMILY AND COMMUNITY SERVICES AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (2004 ELECTION COMMITMENTS) BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 18 November, on motion by Ms Ley:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Election Commitments) Bill 2004 is an omnibus bill that seeks to implement a range of commitments made by the government during the federal election campaign. The amendments outlined in the legislation are: to create a utilities supplement for senior Australians of age pension or veteran pension age who currently receive income support; to establish a new seniors concession allowance for self-funded retirees who hold a Commonwealth seniors health card; to change the eligibility requirements for the carer payment by increasing the number of hours that carers may spend in work, training or study without losing qualification for the carer payment; to create a new special rate of child-care benefit for some grandparents with primary care of their grandchildren, which will cover the full cost of child-care fees; and to extend bereavement payments to widows of totally and permanently incapacitated veterans and ex-servicemen. Of course, Labor will support the measures in this bill, though, as with much of the government's legislation, we are agreeing not because the policy initiatives are strong or because this is the best way of dealing with the problems that have been identified but because these measures go a little of the way to ameliorating the deprivations and hardships that this government has created.

speech.para: Specific promises were made during the election campaign, and Labor believe that we have an obligation to ensure that these promises are delivered in full. We will not stand between Australians and the money that was promised to them during the election campaign through these new initiatives, despite their obvious flaws. Of course, one flaw is that the approach taken by the government is incredibly ad hoc and responds to criticisms that the government faced during and before the election campaign about their lack of concern and their lack of compassion for low-income Australians and older Australians. The measures do not represent any philosophy of social welfare, there is no logic to them and they do not reflect how members of the government see a holistic approach to welfare reform. They are ad hoc measures. Many of them are not even targeted at low-income Australians—for example, the seniors concession allowance for self-funded retirees is available to Australian couples on retirement incomes of up to $80,000 a year. There are many Australians on pensions—not the age pension—who will not receive a cent through this new omnibus bill. And it certainly seems inconsistent that people on very low incomes, who are earning a fraction of the amount identified in the seniors concession allowance, will not get any benefit at all.

Labor believe, instead, that welfare reform of course is necessary and that the government's approach of applying bandaid upon bandaid makes social security in this country less fair and more complex. Our social welfare system should be an integrated structure that is easy to understand and follow, where eligibility for financial assistance is based on need and incentive, not political quick fix solutions. The government do not understand social security. They are not interested in maintaining a coherent and efficient system that works for people in genuine need. They are only interested in applying bandaids whenever a problem arises. You can see that with the $600 family payment, the $100 utilities supplement and the $200 payment for self-funded retirees. They are all bandaids; they are not long-term solutions for any of the underlying problems that are easy to identify. Instead of making the system simpler, the government continue to make it more complex, because of this approach of applying bandaid upon bandaid. It becomes more complex because each bandaid has a different eligibility test and many of them have different indexation methods. It is very difficult for Centrelink to follow the details, let alone your average Australian. Rather than just applying these bandaids, Labor believe that we should find better and consistent ways of helping people who are feeling financial pressure. Instead of coming up with a one-off payment every time a problem arises, our view is that it would be a lot better to address the fundamental flaws in the system to prevent these problems arising in the first place.

I also want to highlight the fact that this government did not bother to properly fund the measures in this bill before its introduction. Certainly, when the measures were foreshadowed during the election campaign, the figures were quite different to what we see at the end. The government's own bean counters in Treasury concluded that the savings that were supposed to fund the initiatives in this bill were overestimated by $130 million. That is a very substantial overestimation. That is a $130 million black hole in the funding of this bill to start with.

We have also seen that the government has failed to achieve the savings that it needs to fund the bill. The Minister for Health and Ageing indicated during the election that the government would fund these measures by allocating $700 million of the total it said could be saved from reducing the price paid by government for medicines. Not only has the government failed to achieve these savings, it does not even know how to start going about doing so. It does not know whether legislation is required to make these savings. It does not know what form that legislation would take. It seems to be engaged in head-to-head conflict with the pharmaceutical companies at the moment to see what the pharmaceutical companies will cop when it comes to cutting their profits. This debacle raises the spectre of an enormous black hole for the government.

The first measure in the bill is the utility supplement for senior Australians. Schedule 1 of the bill creates a new utility supplement for senior Australians by amending a range of Commonwealth legislation, including the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 and the Social Security Act 1991. The new payment is intended to assist senior Australians to pay for regular household bills. Currently, many senior Australians on income support are entitled to receive one of a number of concession cards that provide access to cheaper prescriptions and a range of other benefits. The new payment is intended to provide assistance to older Australians to help them pay for utilities such as gas, electricity and water.

The bill provides that all Australians of age pension or veteran pension age who receive income support will be eligible for the new payment. The utility supplement is $100 a year for singles or $50 each for each member of a couple, and it will be subject to the consumer price index. The payment will be paid in two instalments each year, on 20 March and 20 September, starting on 20 March 2005. It strikes me as curious that the government have chosen to index this payment according to the CPI, given that they have admitted in legislation currently before us that they were wrong to index the $600 per child family payment on the basis of CPI. They have admitted that indexing on the basis of CPI leads to a whittling away of a benefit over time and have introduced legislation to fix that with family payments. It is extraordinary then that, at the same time that we have legislation fixing it in the family payments area, we have this small amount of money paid to pensioners to help them with their utilities that the government have chosen to index in exactly the same way that they have agreed is a problem with family payments.

The government claims that the new benefit will be paid to 2.2 million senior Australians each year at a cost of $606.4 million over four years. The utility supplement creates two classes of pensioners that are divided simply by age. Australians on a Commonwealth government pension other than the age pension—for example, a disability support pension, a war widow pension, a sole parent pension or a carer pension—are not eligible for this utilities allowance. I find this difficult to comprehend also. Many of these Australians are just as needy as, and some of them perhaps even more needy than, people on age pensions.

Qualifying criteria for social security should always be based on need or incentive. It is not good economics and it is not fair social policy to divide people simply by age. Because of the eligibility requirements for the new payment, a carer aged 60 caring for their partner of a similar age with severe disabilities will be treated as less deserving of this extra financial support than an age pensioner couple in a similar situation who are just a few years older. Perhaps the government believes that pensioners who are not of age pension age are somehow less deserving than those who are. But, as I have already indicated, Labor does not intend to prevent eligible age pensioners from benefiting from this legislation to create the utility supplement. It is just worth pointing out the extraordinary anomalies for people who do not qualify simply because of their age.

The self-funded retiree payment is covered in schedule 2 of the bill, which establishes a new seniors concession allowance of $200 per annum for self-funded retirees who are eligible for a Commonwealth seniors health card by amending a range of Commonwealth legislation, including the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 and the Social Security Act 1991. The new payment is being made in recognition that many self-funded retirees do not generally receive concessions for energy, rates, water and motor vehicle registration in the same way as some other senior Australians do and to acknowledge the contribution made by self-funded retirees in providing for their own retirement.

The bill limits the new cash payment to holders of the Commonwealth seniors health card. Under existing means testing arrangements for this card, the new payment will be available to retirees with adjusted taxable incomes of less than $50,000 per annum for singles and $80,000 per annum combined for couples. The government proposes to make this payment on 1 December and 1 June each year, starting with a $200 payment on 1 December 2004. Again, this payment is subject to CPI indexation and, again, I make the point that the government admitted in the family payments debacle that CPI indexation is not appropriate because it does whittle away the value of these cash payments over time. It seems extraordinary to me that, at the very same time that we are fixing one payment through one piece of legislation, the government is introducing another piece of legislation that is subject to the same problem. I wonder whether the government will have to come back in a few weeks time or next week and fix this indexation problem here.

The government estimates that 287,000 self-funded retirees will receive the new payment, at a cost of $255.2 million over four years. Of course Labor supports any measure which makes life a little bit easier for people who are living on fixed incomes, but it is difficult to understand the logic of this haphazard response to cost-of-living issues for older Australians. It is not clear from the legislation whether the government intends for both parties in self-funded retiree couples to receive the new $200 payment. I imagine that it is not the intention of the government, but the legislation certainly does not make clear that it is not the intention. It is inconsistent with the government's treatment of the utilities allowance, which is available to couples at the single rate. The utilities allowance cannot simply be claimed twice by both members of the pensioner couple, yet it is not clear whether this payment cannot be claimed twice by a self-funded retiree couple.

So in the same bill we have completely different policy approaches on display. Australian couples of a certain age on income support can receive a maximum of $50 for each member of a couple towards utilities expenses—in total the couple gets the same as single Australians of pension age—but self-funded retiree couples who have health-care cards can possibly each claim $200 per year to help pay for the same things. They get double the benefit that a single self-funded retiree gets and double the benefit available to older Australian couples on income support. It creates a very inequitable result, because Australian couples of pension age get half the new utilities allowance each, whereas self-funded retirees in a couple may get double the payment that single self-funded retirees are entitled to.

These payments also stand in stark contrast to the Treasurer's criticisms of Labor's Medicare Gold package. The Treasurer continues to claim that benefits paid to older Australians will naturally blow out because we have an ageing population, yet his own government introduces new measures that are aimed at exactly the same age group and that are certainly not subject to particularly stringent means testing.

Schedule 3 of the bill amends section 198C of the Social Security Act 1991 to change the eligibility requirements for the carer payment by increasing the number of hours that carers can spend in work, training or study without losing their qualification for the carer payment. Currently, people who are caring for an adult or a child with a disability and who receive the carer payment are not disqualified from that payment if they temporarily cease providing care in order to undertake training, education, unpaid voluntary work or paid employment, but the maximum length of time has been 20 hours. That is being increased to 25 hours.

On the face of it, it is a perfectly good measure. Labor certainly supports any measures that allow carers to re-engage in the work force, to work as volunteers, to get training or to get an education. It is worth noting, though, that, while this bill increases the number of hours that a carer can work, it does not change the income test for the carer payment. So, if carers work an extra five hours at the minimum wage of $12.30 an hour and get an extra $61.50 in income, they lose $24.60 in pension, because the pension cuts out at 40c for every dollar earned. When you include the $24.60 that they are losing in pension, plus what they lose in tax, it really does not make it particularly worth while for carers to pick up a bit of work, training or education that may help them into the work force at a later time. The government likes to give with one hand and take back with the other.

The next measure is the child-care benefit changes for grandparents. These are covered in schedule 4 of the bill, which amends the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) Act 1999 and the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Administration) Act 1999 to improve child-care assistance for grandparents in receipt of income support who have primary care responsibilities for grandchildren. This means that grandparents who have primary care of a grandchild or grandchildren and who are receiving income support will be entitled to a special rate of child-care benefit. That special rate of child-care benefit will cover the full cost of child-care fees charged to eligible grandparents by approved child-care services. The government estimates that this change will cost $76.4 million over four years, and it hopes to commence eligibility from January 2005.

Of course we support these measures as far as they go. We had a much more comprehensive package for grandparents before the election campaign, and we believe that these changes do not go far enough. We support any extra assistance given to grandparents, but it is worth noting that this extra assistance only goes to grandparents who have their children in approved care, which means predominantly long day care or family day care. There will be a vast number of grandparents who have care of their grandchildren and will not benefit at all from these measures. This includes grandparents who are using registered carers, either because they are more conveniently located or because the children already have a strong relationship with those carers. Most likely, it will be because grandparents, like many Australian parents, simply cannot find child care for their grandchildren. The Australian Bureau of Statistics estimated that in June 2002—and these are the most recent comprehensive figures that we have—there was a national shortage of 174,500 child-care places.

It is plain that grandparents will be on the same long waiting lists and will be facing the same difficulties in finding places for grandchildren that parents face in finding places for their children. That is certainly the case for grandparents who live in rural areas, in parts of regional Australia and in parts of urban Australia. Indeed, in my own electorate, I think one estimate is that there are 500 children on child-care waiting lists in one suburb, Erskineville.

It is plain that many grandparents will not receive any assistance at all. They, of course, are struggling through in the same way as grandparents who do manage to find child care in long day care centres or in family day care for the children that they care for. It is impossible to know how many grandparents are in this group that will not benefit at all, because of course there are no figures kept by the government on grandparents who would be seeking care for their grandchildren but who have given up being able to find it.

The contrast, of course, is with Labor's proposal before the election campaign to give every grandparent who had caring responsibilities for their grandchildren $20 per week for each child in their care. The government proposes to spend $76 million over four years; our proposal was to spend $144 million over the same period—almost double—in helping grandparents who have responsibility for caring for grandchildren. That is the sort of help that grandparents need, and it is the sort of help that this bill does not deliver. It does not deliver any universal assistance for grandparents at all in recognition of the massive public service they perform in raising happy, healthy children. Labor's commitment was a recognition that grandparents have already sacrificed much to raise their own children and that many are now on fixed or low incomes and struggling to raise grandchildren as well.

It is also important to note that the government got the costings of this policy wrong during the election campaign. The estimate during the election campaign was $70 million. This bill contains the official estimate of $78.6 million over four years to deliver this special rate of child-care benefit. So that is a difference of almost $9 million, more than 10 per cent off the mark. Given that the government's estimate included the cost of waiving the work, study or training test for grandparents to access child-care benefit, this is another example of the sort of dodgy figures that the coalition pull out of their hat at election time. The government's boast of economic responsibility is completely undermined by these sorts of chronic underestimations of costs at election time, which are subsequently made up when they return to parliament.
The other thing worth noting here is that the Minister for Family and Community Services herself said:

quote.para: Up to 16,000 grandparents who have the primary responsibility for raising and caring for a grandchild may now be entitled to additional support through Child Care Benefit ...

speech.para: That change has been made by waiving the work or study test for grandparent carers. It has been done as an administrative change; it has not come before the parliament as legislation. So the estimates do not include the extra 16,000 grandparents who will now be eligible for the maximum rate of child-care benefit because of the waiver of the work, study or training test—a change that was made just a few weeks ago by executive decision. That is yet more evidence that the government did not do its sums before coming up with these policies. At the conclusion of my comments I will move an amendment that relates to the issue of grandparents' eligibility for child-care benefit.

Before I do so, I will mention that schedule 5 of the bill honours an election commitment to extend bereavement payments to widows of TPI veterans and ex-servicemen. The current provisions for bereavement payments are that six fortnightly payments are made to surviving partners. The bill will extend these payments to include all payments in excess of the general rate. This will benefit surviving partners of 28½ thousand TPIs and 15,000 extremely disabled veterans. The cost is $14.8 million over four years. Labor of course supports that extension.
I will now go on to the second reading amendment that I foreshadowed. I move:
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:

(1) notes that under the proposals contained in this Bill grandparent carers who are receiving income support will have access to a special rate of benefit, but that this will only be available to those grandparents who use approved child care services;
(2) acknowledges that under the proposals in this Bill grandparents who use registered child care providers will receive no benefit whatsoever; and

(3) condemns the Government for its inequitable treatment of those grandparents who use registered childcare providers and notes that the Government has failed to ensure the reasonable availability of approved child care services”.

talk.start.para: (Hon. B.K. Bishop)—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—I rise to support the Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Election Commitments) Bill 2004. The measures contained in this bill will assist many older people and carers in my electorate of Makin and across Australia. Importantly, they honour the commitments we made during the recent election campaign. We owe a debt of gratitude to our older Australians, many of whom have fought in wars in the defence of this country. They helped to make Australia the great place it is today, which is why they deserve the assistance and support we are providing in this bill.

speech.para: We also recognise the changing nature of Australian society. It is a fact that there are an increasing number of grandparents who are the prime carers of their grandchildren, for whatever reason. It could be because the parents are absent or, sadly, because the parents are incapable of looking after their children due to alcohol or illicit drug addiction. On many occasions, while out doorknocking and on Saturday morning electorate visits, I met many grandparents who were struggling because of the need to look after their grandchildren. There are measures in this bill which will be of assistance to them.

It has been estimated that over one-fifth of children below school age in Australia are cared for by their grandparents as part of the family's regular child-care arrangements. In 2003 the government, through the Department of Family and Community Services, commissioned the Council on the Ageing and the National Seniors Association to undertake a project entitled Grandparents Raising Grandchildren. The focus of the project was on talking to grandparents who are raising their grandchildren, to discover what support mechanisms they require and the financial and legal issues they face. An extensive Australia-wide public consultation process was followed, with the aim of gaining a clear picture of the needs and requirements of these seniors.

One of the issues raised by many grandparents was access to and the affordability of child care. The government announced during the election campaign that it would provide assistance to grandparents who are raising their grandchildren and bearing the costs of child care. This bill honours that commitment. From 3 January 2004, grandparents who are on income support and who are the principal carers of their own grandchildren will receive free approved child care under a special rate of child-care benefit to be known as the grandparent child-care benefit.

The government has recognised that many grandparents who are the prime carers of their grandchildren have limited means of accessing quality child care. It is a fact that most of these seniors never expected to find themselves in the situation of being full-time carers for their grandchildren and are therefore ill prepared for the costs associated with this responsibility. Nevertheless, as the COTA National Seniors project discovered, they are committed to providing the love and care that their grandchildren need. In a very real sense, they are the silent heroes of our nation. Having given so much already, they continue to give to the next generation.

To ensure that all children in the grandparent carer's immediate family are treated the same, the government will provide free approved child care to other children in the grandparent carer's own family, provided the grandparents' grandchild is also attending approved child care. Eligibility for this benefit will also include great-grandparents as well as those in adoptive or step relationships, so long as they are the principal carers. Grandparent carers will be able to claim up to 50 hours of the grandparent child-care benefit per child per week. This follows the waiver of the work, training and study test for grandparent carers, which was introduced on 1 November 2004. Grandparent carers will also be able to request additional hours of free child care in exceptional circumstances, such as hospitalisation.

Before moving on to the other measures contained in this bill, I want to advise the House of the Grandparents for Grandchildren South Australia group that has been established in my home state. The chief aim of this group is to promote the role and needs of grandparents raising their grandchildren. A new support group has been established at Modbury Heights in my electorate, and I wish to congratulate those involved, particularly Mrs Kerry Forster, who has worked very hard to bring this to fruition. The group produces a very interesting newsletter entitled The Coffee Break, which is full of information that would be of assistance to seniors who are caring for their grandchildren.

A new payment is to be established with the passage of this bill, which will be known as the utilities allowance. Despite the promises made by the Rann Labor government in South Australia to bring down the price of electricity, chiefly because of the national power grid deal that we had to have, courtesy of Messrs Keating and John Bannon—just like the recession we had to have—the cost of electricity continues to rise. People are hurting, and this is particularly so among the elderly. The utilities allowance will go some way to alleviating the burden by providing a payment of $100 per year for singles and $50 per year for each member of a couple. People of pension age who are in receipt of income support will be eligible to receive the utilities allowance. Importantly, the allowance is to be linked to the consumer price index to ensure that the value of the payment, in real terms, is protected.

This bill also honours another of the government's election commitments through the establishment of the senior's concession allowance. Self-funded retirees miss out on many of the concessions available to pensioners for such things as water and sewerage rates and motor vehicle registration from state and territory governments. Despite the states and territories receiving a huge windfall gain from the GST revenue, which goes entirely to them, they are unwilling to pass on the benefits to their communities. I am constantly amazed by the buck-passing that goes on. If you listened to a South Australian state government minister speaking, you could be forgiven for thinking that they have absolutely no responsibility for anything. If there is a problem, it is always some other level of government's responsibility. If there is a solution, they will not fund it. And, if there is to be any kudos, then and only then do they wish to participate.

It is the federal government which is now introducing the $200 a year seniors concession allowance to holders of the Commonwealth seniors health card. This payment will also be linked to the CPI. This payment is aimed squarely at helping self-funded retirees, who deserve some relief and support for the contribution they have made to providing for their retirement.

The government is also to be commended for another new measure, contained in this bill, which provides for more flexibility for carer payment customers by increasing the time a carer can work, train or study without losing eligibility for payment from 20 to 25 hours per week. Carers play a vital role in our community and save the taxpayers millions of dollars each year. This new measure will provide carers with more opportunities to undertake work, training or study and will assist them in the development and/or maintenance of skills for present or future work force participation.

In the area of veterans affairs, the government is increasing the bereavement payment for spouses of veterans from 1 January 2005. From that date, spouses of veterans who were receiving a disability pension at the special rate for the totally and permanently incapacitated at the intermediate rate or for extreme disablement will receive a bereavement payment to the equivalent of six payments of the veterans above general rate disability pension.

I am pleased to support this bill because, as I have said, it will benefit the people I represent, the people of Makin. Equally, it provides yet one more reason why the coalition government was returned to office with the support of the majority of Australians. At the very beginning of the recent campaign, the Prime Minister made it clear that the election was about trust. Who could the Australian people trust to deliver a strong and growing economy? Who would the Australian people trust to provide more jobs and reduce unemployment? Who would create the right environment to keep interest rates low and encourage home ownership? Who would Australians trust to protect them, as much as possible, from international terrorism? As this bill clearly demonstrates, the Australian people can also trust the government to deliver on our election commitments. We promised the measures contained in this bill and, with the support of the parliament, we will deliver.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy Speaker Bishop, I commence my contribution by congratulating you on becoming a member of the Speaker's panel. I understand this is the first time you have sat in the chair, and there have been some photographers in the gallery interested in marking the moment. We are aware that you were, at an earlier point in time, hoping to occupy the chair more frequently. You certainly had some supporters on this side of the House in that regard, but it is good to see you in the chair now.

speech.para: As my colleague the member for Sydney has outlined Labor's position on the Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Election Commitments) Bill 2004, I will turn to a series of associated matters. This bill is about creating a utility supplement for senior Australians of age pension or veterans pension age who currently receive income support. It is about establishing a new seniors concession allowance for self-funded retirees who hold a Commonwealth seniors health card. It is about changing the eligibility requirements for carer payments by increasing the number of hours that carers may spend in work, training or study without losing qualification for carer payments. It is about creating a new special rate of child-care benefit for grandparents with primary care of their grandchildren, which will cover the full cost of child-care fees, and it is about extending the bereavement payments to widows of totally and permanently incapacitated veterans and ex-servicemen.

As the member for Sydney has outlined, it is not our intention to delay passage of this bill and to hold up the payment of benefits to people in these categories. But I feel it is my task to outline to the House that this bill comes associated with a trifecta of double standards. The first of those double standards flows from much of the work that Treasurer Costello has done on the question of intergenerational equity and intergenerational costs. Treasurer Costello is very proud of having commissioned the Intergenerational Report, which came with the budget papers. He is also very proud, as we have heard as recently as last week and in this chamber yesterday, of having referred to the Productivity Commission the question of the impact of the ageing of Australia's population.

The draft report from the Productivity Commission was released last Thursday. As we would expect, there is nothing new or highly original about these statistics, but the Productivity Commission went on to conclude that there will be a major impact of ageing on government revenue and on demands for government services. We know that by 2042 Australia's population is projected to increase by around 30 per cent to over 25 million and that the number of people aged over 55 will grow faster than the number of people aged under 55. There are currently around 15 million people aged under 55 and slightly more than four million people aged over 55. By 2042 there will be 16 million people aged under 55 and over nine million people aged over 55. This change in the demographics of the Australian population, according to the Productivity Commission, will open up a gap between revenue and outlays at both the state and federal levels in the order of seven per cent in 40 years time.

The Treasurer publicly and in this place consistently points to his concerns about the impact of ageing on our society and its impact on government outlays and demands for government services. As recently as yesterday the Treasurer was in this House criticising Labor's Medicare Gold policy on this basis. As it turns out, the criticisms that the Treasurer made of the Medicare Gold policy are quite erroneous, because Medicare Gold, as well as being a package which would benefit people over 75, is actually a health efficiency measure which would save between $500 million and $600 million each year. That is the amount wasted each year now because the Commonwealth government funds aged care while the states administer the public hospitals, and so there is no signal in the system to make the Commonwealth make available the right number of aged care beds. That shows up in state administered public hospitals with frail Australians who could be in an aged care institution or in some other form of care ending up being accommodated in acute public hospital beds because there is nowhere else for them to go. As we all know, there is nothing more expensive in our health system than an acute hospital bed. Medicare Gold would resolve that problem and save between $500 million and $600 million a year. It would get out of the system the cost shifting and buck passing that currently happens between the Commonwealth and the states on the question of care of older Australians and, with the Commonwealth as a monopoly purchaser of hospital services for older Australians, it would drive efficiencies across the public and private sectors.

The Treasurer is right to ask: what is the intergenerational impact of Medicare Gold? We know what the intergenerational impact of Medicare Gold is because it has been modelled for the Labor Party by experts, and the experts say that over 40 years the cost of Medicare Gold to this country would decrease as a percentage of GDP. This is in circumstances where the Productivity Commission tells us that if health care costs are dealt with as they are now then as a percentage of GDP they will blow out from six per cent—as they are now—to 10.8 per cent of GDP by 2044-45. The Treasurer is always on about the impact of ageing but he is basically administering a health care system in which we are expecting to see an enormous increase in government outlays as a percentage of GDP. Medicare Gold, because it is an efficiency measure, would actually as a percentage of GDP cost less over time. So we have the efficiencies of Medicare Gold on display against the inefficiency of the current system.

We have picked up the challenge and we have been prepared to model the intergenerational consequences of Medicare Gold. But what stands in stark contrast to all of the Treasurer's rhetoric is the failure of the government to model the intergenerational consequences for older Australians of its various promises in the recent election campaign. In this package there is a utility supplement for senior Australians of age pension or veteran pension age who currently receive income support. By definition that is a growing class of Australians. What is the cost of that? What will that be as a percentage of GDP in 20 years or 40 years time? Where is the intergenerational modelling on that? What are the consequences of that promise for revenue outlays of the Commonwealth with all of the implications about budget deficit or taxation arrangements?

If the Treasurer has that intergenerational modelling then we would like to see it. If he wants to say to Labor that we should model the intergenerational consequences, it is a double standard not to do it himself. He ought to be producing in this House the intergenerational modelling of the costs of the utility supplement. And what is the intergenerational cost of the new seniors concession allowance for self-funded retirees who hold a Commonwealth seniors health care card? What is that going to cost as a percentage of GDP in 20 or 40 years time? Where is the intergenerational modelling on that? If it has not been done then how can the Treasurer hold out this government as one that is looking at the challenge of ageing in a way which will ensure that the costs of ageing do not get out of control in Australia? If it has not been done then the Treasurer's words stand revealed as the most empty and hollow of rhetoric. If it has been done, where is it? While we are on the question of intergenerational modelling, where is the modelling of the mooted changes to the private health insurance rebate for older Australians? What is that going to cost as a percentage of GDP in 20 or 40 years time? I know that is not within the ambit of this bill, but it will be dealt with later this week.

The Treasurer gives all the signs of being a man who is serious about the policy question of ageing. He displays a great deal of pride about the Intergenerational Report with the budget papers, a great deal of pride about putting these matters on the COAG agenda and a great deal of pride about referring it to the Productivity Commission. He is Mr Ageing. He says he is going to deal with this challenge. If he is going to deal with this challenge then he will deal with it in each and every piece of legislation and expenditure item proposed by this government for older Australians. There are two in this bill. The intergenerational modelling of this package should be produced before this debate ends. That is the first double standard that informs this bill.

I will describe the second double standard that informs this bill. We listen day after day in question time to various government ministers talking about their record of fiscal responsibility. The topic of how fiscally responsible the Howard government is is often used in this parliament. One wonders some days how they can maintain that pretence of fiscal responsibility having spent $66 billion in promises associated with winning the recent election and having spent $6 billion on the Prime Minister's campaign launch. They maintain that pretence of fiscal responsibility.

In line with that pretence, how is the $130 million black hole in this package going to be covered? The government, having spent $6 billion on the Prime Minister's campaign launch and $66 billion in total in the run-up to the election and on election promises, then got startled by Labor's Medicare Gold. It had until that point intended to skate through the election campaign taking the votes of older Australians for granted. The Prime Minister was proceeding on the political strategy that he already had the votes of older Australians in his back pocket so, out of a $66 billion spend, senior Australians did not need a cent spent on them.

Then the Leader of the Opposition announced Medicare Gold on 29 September in his campaign launch and the Prime Minister went into a campaign bunker and did not emerge for two days. He knew then that the game was up. He knew then that he could not take the votes of senior Australians for granted. His polling would have been showing him that in spades. But he knew as well that his fiscal credibility had been torn to shreds by the $6 billion spend in his campaign speech, that the financial press was laughing at him and that he was receiving very bad publicity for this in the mainstream media. So he was in a dilemma. He had taken the votes of senior Australians for granted and he then needed to do something about them because the polling had gone bad post-Medicare Gold. What was he going to do? He had to cobble together a savings measure to support this package so he quickly did that, only to find when the Department of Finance and Administration modelled the savings measure that it was $130 million short. Where is the $130 million that is needed to fund the black hole in this package coming from? That is another question that this government needs to answer before we finally deal with this legislation.

Almost more breathtaking than those two double standards is the double standard associated with the savings measure that supports this bill. It is breathtaking. The savings measure is a series of changes to listing and pricing arrangements for generic drugs and an increase in the efficiency dividend from one per cent to 1.25 per cent—that is, savings measures associated with the expenditure on this bill are being generated by changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. You say to yourself, `If there were hundreds of millions of dollars of savings that could be responsibly taken from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, why didn't the government find it earlier, given that the government was advocating a price hike of 30 per cent in the price of essential medicines?'

As a consequence of the Intergenerational Report about which I have spoken, the Treasurer came into this place and went to the Australian community and said: `The Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme is not sustainable in the face of ageing. We have to do something about it. I know what we are going to do: we are going to put up the price of essential medicines by 30 per cent and put that burden on Australians when they are required to make a copayment for their essential medicines.'

It was Labor that at that point said: `Hang on Treasurer; we are as interested as you in the long-term sustainability of the PBS and we understand that its long-term sustainability is under pressure because of ageing and because of the innovation of new and expensive drugs. We understand that. We're more wedded to the PBS than you are, Treasurer, because we actually invented it.' So Labor said: `We understand the problem, Treasurer, but we think there is a better way to fix it than putting the price of essential medicines up by 30 per cent for all Australians. We think the better way to fix it is to look for savings based around listing arrangements and pricing arrangements in the PBS.' That is exactly what we said to the government.

What did the government say to us? For years it said nothing. It did not take up Labor's offer to explore these hundreds of millions of dollars of savings which could be made on the PBS. It did not say anything. Finally, in frustration, the then shadow Treasurer, Bob McMullan, the member for Fraser, and I wrote to our respective counterparts—he of course writing to the Minister for Finance and Administration, and me writing to the Minister for Health and Ageing—asking for information about the potential savings that could be generated on the PBS. We said we wanted to use those savings to offset the need for the 30 per cent price hike in the cost of essential medicines. Here is what the Minister for Finance and Administration wrote back:

quote.para: A fundamental principle in the construction of budget and forward estimates for the PBS is that the fiscal impact of new listings on the PBS are not included in the Budget aggregates until there is certainty about both when they will come onto the market and the price that will be charged.

speech.para: He goes on:

quote.para: Given this principle, I consider that it would be inappropriate to make any form of speculative provision in the forward estimates for the effect of generic drugs coming on to the PBS in advance of any of these steps having been completed.
