Should such a provision be contemplated, it would be necessary, for reasons of consistency, to also include an estimate of the potential future listings of new, patented, high cost drugs. If this approach were to be taken, I consider that PBS forward estimates would become so speculative as to be meaningless.

speech.para: So, in the face of Labor saying, `We think there are hundreds of millions of dollars of savings on the PBS,' the Minister for Finance and Administration from the self-styled fiscally responsible Howard government said, `No, no, no; if we did that on the forward estimates it would make the forward estimates so speculative as to be meaningless.'

talk.start.para: —We wouldn't know how much we were saving.

—No, we would not know how much we were saving or how much we were being required to spend on new branded drugs. Apparently, what is meaningless when it is sent in June in a letter from the minister for finance to our then shadow Treasurer becomes full of meaning on an election day when the Howard government needs a few hundred million dollars of savings to support a measure for older Australians because it is getting a vote bleed from older Australians due to Medicare Gold. So it is meaningless in June—it would render the forward estimates speculative; it would be the end of fiscal responsibility and management as we know it in Australia—but, of course, two days after Labor's campaign launch, it can be done and these savings can be booked, and they have been booked to support this measure short $130 million.

speech.para: Honestly, some days you have just got to shake your head in wonderment about the double standards, backflips and arrogance exhibited by the government. What did they think? Did they think that noone would notice that for a couple of years they denied that there were these savings—they denied in writing that they were available—and they suddenly found them a week out from the election? Did they think noone was going to notice that? They are so arrogant they think people forget what happened yesterday. We have not forgotten, and let me tell you who else has not forgotten: the pharmaceutical industry has not forgotten. The pharmaceutical industry is rightly asking how this is going to be done.

Where is the legislation to implement the changes? If the expenditure starts on 1 January, don't the savings have to flow from 1 January? Isn't this the last two sitting weeks before 1 January? Where is the bill? Does anybody have an answer to that question? Where is the bill? How are you going to start on 1 January spending money that you do not have? Where is the bill? Second, is it possible to mandate a 12.5 per cent decrease in PBS medicines? Has anybody looked at that? Not as far as I am aware. Where is the modelling and data to support the government's claimed PBS savings—the savings that they said could not be found—and what will the impact of the increased efficiency dividend be on the Public Service? That is not a PBS saving but it is actually a saving that is booked here too.

So we have a government that denied for years, and denied in writing, the existence of these savings now relying on them. Having put itself in a position where it is going to start spending on 1 January, it appears to have no clue—to be completely clueless—about how it is going to generate these savings in time to match the expenditure. So something I would really like to hear from the Treasurer or the Minister for Health and Ageing before the conclusion of this debate is where these savings are coming from; when they are going to be implemented; what the details are; and what consultation the government has had with the pharmaceutical industry. If the answer to that is blank looks—and I suspect it will be—then this government has to explain how it can try to maintain its so-called credentials for being a fiscally responsible government in the face of this gross fiscal irresponsibility. I suggest that it stop criticising other people's policies on that basis until it amends its own. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Election Commitments) Bill 2004, which we are debating today, will amend the social security law, the family assistance law and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 to give effect to certain commitments made during the election campaign just gone. The benefits will flow to self-funded retirees, to older Australians, to grandparents caring for children and to certain disability pensioners. Obviously we are keen to see those measures passed as soon as possible to ensure that older Australians continue to receive the assistance that they so deserve under the strong economic management of this government.

speech.para: There are five measures in this bill and I begin with the $200 seniors concession allowance paid to all holders of the Commonwealth seniors health care card. This payment recognises that self-funded retirees do not receive from state and territory governments discounts on power, rates, water and sewerage, nor do they receive such discounts very often on motor vehicle registration. But it also recognises that this group has made a considerable contribution in providing for their own retirement. Many in my electorate of Bowman have said, `It's appropriate, it's welcomed and I'm glad that we are not forgotten by this government.' That payment comes in two instalments to eligible cardholders: on 1 December and on 1 June.

Secondly, the bill establishes the new $100 utility allowance payable to senior Australians of age pension age or veteran pension age who are in receipt of income support. This payment will help that group to pay for regular household bills such as gas and electricity. In general, that will be $100 per year, or $50 for each member of a couple. Together those payments will benefit over two million Australians who continue to contribute to Australia and to their own futures. Both payments will be indexed twice yearly, both will be tax exempt and both will be payable even if the citizen is overseas for up to 13 weeks of the year.

Constituents in Bowman have said to me that it is often very difficult to plan ahead, particularly for utilities, while one is living on a pension—and I point out that the pension does fall from $775 per fortnight for a couple to $464 for a single. This is often a concern for singles who are living alone. Many feel that that fall of $8,086 per year is hardly representative of a cost difference between living in a single or double household. So they are very delighted that that payment will be to a household, regardless of how many pensioners are living there.

It is interesting to hear the member for Sydney say that there is an additional complexity or an additional administrative layer. Certainly to deliver a payment like this for utilities on a week-by-week basis would be completely counterproductive. The very purpose of the payment is to make it easier to plan ahead and meet those obligations. I cannot see any other way of doing it except as an intermittent payment. But also to view this payment as a bandaid is to completely miss the point because 5.2 per cent of Australians now do not have to rely on bandaids—they are gainfully employed in the economy. That means there are a lot of bandaids left over to give to those who truly deserve that assistance in their senior years. That allows people planning their final years to have the security and support to pay for such things as utilities. In the case of the $200 payment, it is given to two individuals in a household, obviously because it covers power, rates, water and, at times, registration for more than one vehicle. A number of costs accrue to such a family and it is entirely appropriate that there should be a payment to each individual.

The bill also allows for child care to be more affordable for grandparents who are carers and receiving income support such as an age pension or a carer payment. The special rate provided for in this bill will cover the full cost of childcare places charged to eligible grandparents by approved childcare providers.

I would like to shed some light on a key part of this bill, the disability portion. This bill will provide additional support for people who care for an adult or a child with disability. That group of people perform a vital role in our community. Increasing the amount of hours that they can dedicate to either work or further study, and therefore have a break from the often very onerous role of caring for a relative, is a good thing, and being still eligible for the carer payment is a very important part of that.

But I want to put a family face on the dilemma of accessing respite. We have a number of couples and families in my electorate in that position. One is a single mum of 55 years of age. She has a severely disabled son living at home at the age of 17 who has Cornelia de Lange syndrome. This is a fairly rare condition, first described in the 1930s. It is a multiple congenital anomaly syndrome which affects both feeding and behaviour. It can lead to severe epilepsy, severe malformations of the upper limbs, scoliosis, osteoporosis and psychomotor disorders, which can make it extremely difficult for the person to leave the house, have an excursion or even go shopping with a carer.

The family is one of nature's great masterpieces, so can there be any greater contribution than family members dedicating their life to caring for other family members who need almost day-to-day, hour-to-hour support for almost everything they do to meet their basic needs? Currently in Queensland a family in this situation receives not 20, not 10 nor five but 3½ hours of respite a week. The purchase of additional respite is $27 an hour, and 50 per cent more expensive on weekends.

When this young boy turned 13 he no longer had access to the Special Needs Subsidy Scheme, which provided two days a week of assistance at vacation care. Once he had turned 16, the income arrangements changed to where he now receives $400 a fortnight and his mum receives a carer payment of $375 a fortnight. Mum is forced to do extra work where she can and extending the period she can work by 20 hours to 25 is extremely valuable for her. But there is a catch. For her to be able to access and utilise and enjoy 25 hours, we need a state government that will provide adequate respite care.

I seek the indulgence of the chamber to at least acquaint ourselves with a report released just last week: Disability support services 200203. That report contains a state-by-state comparison. I am cautious about my comments and I must say that the first chapter following the introduction is about the quality of the data, which has been collected only over six months—but it is the best we have at the moment. What we have here is a possible reason why in Queensland it is so hard to access respite care and to be able to enjoy 25 hours a week of either study or work. This mum, who cares for her severely disabled son who is unable to leave the house, is perhaps able to work on a special school bus and take her son to school and back and earn $300 a fortnight on top of the allowance, but there is very little option above that for any quality respite that is affordable. This bill makes those improvements from a Commonwealth level but, as this document will show, there is an extremely restricted supply of respite care in Queensland. So to start with that analysis and summarise it, it is obvious that the prevalence of disability will be somewhat homogenous across states, although small variations will exist.

If we look at the number of people accessing disability services, there is a considerably lower level in Queensland than in other states. That is partly explainable by the demographics of the state, but you would expect there to be some policy response to that. Let us see if it occurs. When it comes to the number of people accessing respite care as a proportion of the population, the level in Queensland is at least 10 per cent lower than in comparable states—and about half that in Victoria. The number of outlets are down as well, and the number of people accessing each of these outlets for disability services is not 6,600 as in New South Wales or 6,100 as in Victoria but a whopping 8,890 people per outlet. Further, for centre based care, which is a direct responsibility of state governments, there are 117 centres in New South Wales, 136 in Victoria and 51 in Queensland. That is clearly not a policy response to the demographics of a large and decentralised state. The number of people in Queensland trying to access each of these centres is not 56,000 or 35,000 as in other states but 72,500 per respite centre.

In the social sector there is only one true measure of commitment, and that is in resources. In respite dollars per capita, we see approximately $8.76 per head as the national average. Queensland is once again well below that at $8.20, and a separate analysis performed independently showed that Queensland has the second lowest average of all states. Disability support money from the states is $906 million and $851 million in the larger states but $325 million in Queensland. This is well down, and the support payment per head of population is $136 in one state, $175 in another, $120 or above in every state but Queensland, which has a support payment of $88 per person.

So it was doubly barefaced then for the Queensland government to put out a press release in the middle of last year that indicated there was going to be a boost to funding which had not been included in this report. It is important to try to figure those additional resources in, even though it is cheating a little because we are not looking at what the other states have also committed. Even when you add in the new commitments from the Queensland government, you see that they are still well below the national average for disability and respite funding. The final line of the press release on respite care said: `Families are at the forefront of this government's reform agenda for disability services.' Families at the forefront—isn't that revolutionary policy formulation? Isn't it breathtakingly underwhelming? Commitment can only be measured in dollars, and we have here a reform agenda for the government. Perhaps Queensland should begin its reform agenda by committing as many dollars per head of population and per user as every other state does. It does not seem to be that complex.

Queensland families can be forgiven for a touch of despair when it comes to accessing respite care, and I have made that divarication because it underpins why it is so difficult in Queensland to actually be able to benefit from any increase in eligibility for carers payments. It is one thing for a state government to cast itself as the friend of the disabled but quite another to then starve disability services for 2½ election terms and then crow about having crawled back to the national average or only just. The real issue—the bottleneck, the stumbling block—here is the state's unwillingness to satisfactorily fund respite services. We have a number of families in my electorate who cannot even place their own child in work experience, which obviously is unpaid—in, for example, a pet shop—because they have to pay $30 an hour for the respite carer to accompany their child to work. As one mum said, `Our children don't cause us as much stress as the system and trying to get some help.'

I have been provided with a bundle of correspondence from mums on trying to deal with Disability Services Queensland. While I commend the individual workers within the department, I have here a complete record of the frustrations of one mum trying to find support from her own state department. So it is interesting that Queensland only now is embarking on measures to increase respite funding when the GST revenues are also just beginning to flow. But the memories of families with disabled members will be long in Queensland, even though they only have 3½ hours of respite care in which to contemplate them. Currently, this is a key impediment for Bowman families, preventing them from fully benefiting from the alterations to the carers payments we are speaking of here today. I commend this bill and each of its five parts.

talk.start.para: — Mr Deputy Speaker Beazley, as this is the first occasion, to my knowledge, that I have been in the chamber while you have occupied the chair as a member of the Speaker's panel, may I congratulate you on your election to this office. As you have done in other appointments in the House, you will add lustre to the position.
(Hon. K.C. Beazley)—Thank you very much. The view is very good from here.

—The opposition, led today by the member for Sydney, has indicated it will support each and every one of the measures in the Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Election Commitments) Bill 2004, which covers a suite of different election promises that the government is attempting to put in place through this House and the other place. But the member for Sydney has moved an amendment which goes to the core of not just how adequate but how fair and equitable at least one of these changes is. The government has moved to recognise grandparents providing care if they have the full charge and responsibility of a child. It has said that one group of grandparents looking after a child who can get access to approved child care should be given a benefit, so there is a case to be made —and we believe a compelling one—that a group not able to gain access to approved child care, which is then forced to go to a registered childcare place, should also get this benefit. Is there anything in the nature or circumstances of people in the second group that makes them less of a person, carer or grandparent in comparison to people who have been able to get an approved child-care place? We do not believe so.

speech.para: In putting this amendment forward the member for Sydney, as our shadow minister, has rightly argued that if you are going to put in this form of payment you must be fair and make sure that it is available to all grandparents in that position. It should be given to both grandparents and to an approved or a registered child-care place. I support that amendment completely.

This is an omnibus bill. It has a range of measures, some of which I will speak to in more detail than others. This range of measures has a context, and well do we know it—there was an election recently. In that recent election in October the government put a series of proposals to the electorate. Indeed, there is an even broader context. Since the budget, which was brought down in the middle of May this year, there has been an even broader fiscal question about how much money is being pumped into this economy through the budget. Originally, I think it was in the order of $37 billion. The mark-up was at least $37 billion of stimulus. If we look at it again it is probably $50 billion worth of stimulus.

In just a single day the member for Bennelong—despite his 4.3 per cent buffer in that seat—promised $6 billion worth of benefit to electors from one end of the country to the other, not only in his electorate but in every electorate. The sorts of measures that he was promising in the areas of caring and child-care places were announced for the benefit of people in his electorate, as well as others. What was the grand total? Some people say that it was $50 billion plus $6 billion. In our calculations the all-up total was $66 billion worth of funding in one year. In January and February of 2001 the coalition was in a bit of trouble. From memory, it spent in the order of $21 billion from the budget through to the election period, and it added to that in the election itself. Remarkably, we still have a low-inflation economy, despite the fact that this government has been in power. It tripled the amount of money spent in order to buy its way into office. Introducing a stimulus of $66 billion into the economy in one year has rightly been regarded by most economic commentators in this country as profoundly wrong and dangerous. The great irony in this election was that the government's greatest weaknesses were the ones that helped it get re-elected. Of course, the member for Brand would well know that that irony has not only visited us once. So too, the coalition's greatest weakness in 2001—the fact that over 2½ years 13,000 people came illegally into Australia by boat—became its strength.

This is a government of inversions. It takes its great weakness, turns it upside down and campaigns on it very effectively by spending hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money informing us about its general programs and pushing specific programs. But then it is entirely profligate in its responsibilities to Australia's budget. Again in question time today the Treasurer put out a few warning signals. He has been talking about problems in the economy, about the fact that the housing market has settled down somewhat and about there being a few problems with debts.

The greatest problem that the Australian people faced in this election was that they were up against a government that would spend anything, do anything and say anything to get re-elected. The government did not care what it promised to whom and how much it would cost, as long as it got back into power. However worthy these propositions are—and some of them, I would argue, are worthy—the context is that it was about the coalition buying its way back into government at any cost. Properly answered, the great concern that people had about interest rates would have seen this lot thrown off the Treasury bench and back into the oblivion that they deserve. Quite simply, they were utterly irresponsible in their spending this year. From one end of the country to the other—unless they are Liberal Party apparatchik, a member of the government frontbench or one of those people elected on the back of what the Prime Minister and others promised—no-one could argue that there is a shred of responsibility in what it has done.

The general context, properly put by commentators Australia wide, identifies that what this government needs to do over the triennium until the next election is to bring the budget back into order. But one of the first pieces of government business is to lay before us a series of issues that have particular point: we have promises of half a billion dollars, $1 billion and $2 billion. I would argue that some are particularly worthy. We are not going to gainsay the fact that this will provide a benefit to ordinary Australian pensioners. It will also provide a benefit directly to self-funded retirees. In both those cases, the benefit is worthy. But it is also necessary because it is this very government that those two groups of people need to be defended against.

Why is that so? Why has a government that has been profligate in its spending chosen to target these measures in order to help people. Why is it necessary? Why is that the case? It is because the cost of living for people on a pension or benefit is not the same as the cost of living for everyone else in the community. The general low-inflation period that we have—courtesy of the Hawke-Keating governments and of the major changes that were made through the middle of the 1980s and 1990s—has provided the basis for 14 years' worth of growth. It has also had an impact on self-funded retirees. Retirees who enjoy a higher level of income during a period of high interest rates have less money to survive on during a period of low inflation and low interest rates, particularly those people who provided for themselves. They definitely got a benefit from the Commonwealth, but they made a greater input into their future benefit by going without at the time and there is a case that they should in fact receive some extra recompense.

I would agree with that. I spent a long time during the period of the Hawke and Keating governments attempting to convince the then Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Social Security, Brian Howe, that there was a case to answer with regard to self-funded retirees. I argued that those people who had worked hard all of their lives faced the same cost pressures that people on pensions faced, except that people on pensions had the health care concession card—particularly at that stage, when the pension rate was $6,500 or $7,000 a year and self-funded retirees who had worked in the education sector, for instance, were on $11,500 or $12,000 a year. That concession card gave them access to a series of state benefits for travel and other things, which meant that their relative cost of living was lower than for those who were on that benefit.

I have to confess that I did not succeed with Mr Howe, but I did succeed finally when Graham Richardson came in, because Graham understood two things: he not only understood the merit of the case but he understood the politics of the case as well—that those people who had done it hard and were effectively in straitened circumstances deserved a go—and he made the decision to extend that health care card and those fringe benefits to that small group of people. I am proud of the fact that, working in the Treasurer's electorate office at the time, I pushed that case and I succeeded from that office in bringing that change into place under a Labor government. There are many people that have benefited from it. In this bill the government seeks to extend that benefit by allowing those self-funded retirees an extra concession to get access to some of the things that have been there for pensioners.

For the utility concession the bill provides for a utility supplement for senior Australians of aged pension or veteran pension age who currently receive income support. Furthermore, there is a new seniors concession allowance for self-funded retirees who hold a Commonwealth seniors health card. In the first instance, I played a key part in getting them that concession to start off with, and here we have an expansion of people's capacity to receive what pensioners can access but that those self-funded retirees cannot. In a low-inflation period, the PBS costs have been reduced, but they still face problems with travel and with paying the electricity, gas and other myriad bills and cost pressures that come upon them. So I think this is actually a good measure.

There is a problem of the ongoing cost to the Commonwealth of providing these benefits. Whatever the budget figures say now about the cost of these measures being $200 million, $600 million or whatever, the context, of course, is that this inevitably will be small bickies compared to what it is going to be when a quarter of the population is aged—when the boomers, I being one of them, will represent one-quarter of the community. So whatever cost indicators there are will increase almost exponentially. Therefore, supportability and sustainability of these measures is a key ingredient.

There is health-care concession for people on pensions and, set beside that because they are on income support, the state governments have for a long time provided a series of measures to assist those people. So the second area where the government have attempted to balance this up is through a specific utility supplement for people on aged pensions so that they will get some assistance with the key things that really hit them now—gas, electricity and so on. That is a good measure as well, but you have to place that into a broader context. They need the assistance because people on pensions and other income supplements are at the end of the scale where the relative amounts of money they spend on utilities and on the everyday necessities of life are proportionately far greater than for people on much higher incomes. The proportionality is significant and it is important.

In my electorate of Blaxland, there are a lot of people on income support as aged pensioners, and they have told me time and again just how hard it is to get by since the GST came into effect. Indeed, one of my branch members, Peter Morton from Chester Hill branch, has told me a number of times that his ability to provide for himself—and other people's ability to provide for themselves—is very much hit not just by the GST but by the fact that a government entity that this government now half owns is belting the daylights out of them to the tune of a dollar a day. That government entity, Telstra, which is relatively trammelled because the government still owns half, has increased its line fee charges to $28 a month. That is a dollar a day for every pensioner in Australia with a phone, which is an absolute necessity for them.

Peter says that getting the rental supplement and utilities assistance will be a good thing for him but it is going to be swallowed up anyway—he will be a little bit better off with that but his bigger problem is some assistance with the Telstra bill, and he has properly identified that the government is entirely responsible here. Companies can get a tax deduction on their costs but, of course, individuals cannot. He said that on gas bills—he has told me about this a number of times and it is true—under the heading `gas supply' the state government provides a quarterly $16 credit on the bill and this has gone up along with the rental fees. He also makes a point about the one dollar a day for Telstra charges. Where is the utility supplement in relation to Telstra charges? It is not there. Line rental fees are compounded by the GST, so you have not only got the one dollar a day, there is an extra 10c on top that is going directly into federal government coffers. Of course, they argue that they are only collecting it for the states. Mr Deputy Speaker Beazley, as you know, this is a Commonwealth government tax, just like all other Commonwealth government taxes, imposed on people so they pay a double whammy, because 51 cents of that dollar go directly to the Commonwealth government.

With respect to increases in charges for utilities, affecting aged pensioners Australia wide, the government says in this bill, `We'll help you pay the gas and we'll help you pay the electricity'—they are private entities or part state-owned entities—`and we'll pocket the full amount of money that we can in Telstra line charges and we'll charge you the GST on top of it.' I think Peter is right: this is outrageous. They actually need another supplement to the bill to fix it up. There is a $100-a-year utility supplement. Peter Morton says that that would be welcomed, but it does not even cover the cost of the Telstra line rentals, let alone the electricity or gas. There should be research done or an inquiry carried out on the impact of these hidden costs. But the government of course would rather that these costs were kept hidden. They do not really want to deal with the fundamental constraints on people on income support.

Peter also asked how the utility providers justify those costs and why it costs Telstra $1 a day to keep a phone line connected. I think I can tell him that it does not cost Telstra $1 a day to keep a phone line connected. This is a $1 tax on every Australian pensioner and every person using a phone Australia wide. When the member for Melbourne was the shadow minister, we in the opposition rightly argued that these exorbitant increases in charges were reprehensible to the nth degree. There is no margin for people on fixed incomes to handle a big increase—unless it drops, as almost manna from heaven, from this government from time to time just before an election. There is $66 billion in funding this year. What does the government spend in the off-years? If you go back a year or so, you find it is about $4 billion. There is a big difference proportionally. But we all know it is about the member for Bennelong and his cohorts buying an election.

Peter Morton and all of my constituents—the people who do it tough at the end of the line where you are dependent on some government largesse and these extra little bits to make your life more liveable—deserve to have a utility supplement that covers not only what the government are promising in this bill but also the real costs imposed in relation to Telstra. So, while I welcome the general provisions of this bill, I understand—as everyone else in the opposition does—that this is a way for the government to buy favour. There are significant questions about the sustainability of these provisions into the future and there are significant problems that will arise due to their picking and choosing which grandparents will get help and which grandparents will not. So we will support the provisions but we make the argument that this is about buying your way into office and it is ultimately unsustainable.

talk.start.para: —Labor supports this legislation on the basis that it will go some way towards easing the financial pressure on pensioners and self-funded retirees. However, I want to take this opportunity to express concerns, which have already been expressed by the member for Blaxland, about the sustainability of the government's spending program. I will go through a number of the provisions of the Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Election Commitments) Bill 2004. The utility supplement is welcomed. It is not a lot of money. It is $100 a year for singles and $50 for each member of a couple. It is designed to assist our senior Australians to pay their regular household bills from the utilities whose services they use.

speech.para: The self-funded retiree payment is a new seniors' concession that allows $200 per annum for self-funded retirees who are eligible for a Commonwealth seniors health card. We of course support that provision. There is a change to the carer's payment. This is by way of increasing the number of hours that carers may spend in work, training or study without losing their qualification for a carer payment. We certainly support that. The maximum length of time that a carer may temporarily cease providing care in order to take training, education and voluntary or paid work and still retain their qualification for the carer payment is currently 20 hours per week. Under this legislation, that will be increased to 25 hours per week.

In addition, there are new benefits relating to child care. Grandparents who have primary care of a grandchild or grandchildren and who are receiving income support will be entitled to a special rate of child-care benefit. That will cover the full cost of child-care fees charged to eligible grandparents by approved child-care services. We have some genuine concerns with this provision, and that is why the member for Sydney has moved a second reading amendment. The amendment criticises the government for not adequately supporting grandparent carers. In particular, under this legislation there is no support for grandparents who cannot find a place for grandchildren in approved care and who are thus forced to use registered care. They are given no special assistance to meet the cost of registered care. We are bewildered as to why that distinction would be made. It means that a large number of grandparents who are carers miss out on this particular benefit.

There are desirable changes in relation to veterans' entitlements. The bill extends bereavement payments to widows of TPI veterans and ex-servicemen. Of course, we greatly appreciate the contribution of ex-servicemen, who have made big sacrifices to keep our country free. We think this is also a reasonable measure.

The cumulative impact of these measures is $972 million over four years. That is an affordable set of initiatives. But it is an allocation of funding that is on top of a very large additional spending program from this government. In fact, it is a massive spending program. If we count the budget initiatives and all of the initiatives that have been taken since the May budget—that is, right up to and including the election campaign—the total amount of extra spending over four years is a staggering $61 billion.

Not only is that a huge amount of money, but I have been able to make an assessment of how much of that $61 billion is consumption spending and how much is investment spending. Disturbingly, the answer is that only $5 billion of that $61 billion is, in fact, investment spending—and here I am being rather generous, because that includes Customs posts in Beijing and Jakarta. Of course that will do some good, but the direct economic stimulus from those Customs posts will be felt in Beijing and Jakarta, and not in Australia. I know it is a small point, but I thought it was worth making. The big point and the big story here is that, in order to be re-elected, this government has over the last few months committed Australian taxpayers to $61 billion of extra spending, of which only $5 billion is investment spending. The problem we have in this country is that there is a spending spree, a consumption binge, which can have only dire consequences for the Australian economy.

Since this government came to office in 1996, it has deliberately addicted Australians to debt. We are now in a situation where households have negative savings—they are dissaving—and they are continuing on a consumption binge. Yet they are struggling to make ends meet in that, instead of saving for this consumption, they are more and more putting it on the credit card and taking out larger and larger mortgages. The total impact is that just as Australians are struggling to make ends meet so is Australia. That has shown up in a current account deficit of 6.5 per cent of gross domestic product. Mr Deputy Speaker Hatton, that is a current account deficit of a similar order of magnitude to, or even larger than, the current account deficit of the mid-1980s which prompted your predecessor, Mr Keating, to warn of the prospect of Australia becoming a banana republic. The Hawke and Keating governments put in place a comprehensive reform program designed to ensure that we are never again in that situation. It was a problem which the Hawke and Keating governments inherited and understood, and they responded by putting in place that comprehensive reform program.

As a result of that program, we should have been able to look forward and say, `We will never be so vulnerable again'—and yet we are. We are very vulnerable to any external shocks and to an economic slowdown because this government has addicted Australians to debt. That debt is showing up in our foreign debt. When the government said they would cut foreign debt—when it rolled out the debt truck, and when the debt truck was circling around Australia—the Prime Minister, then opposition leader, said he would follow policies which would over time reduce foreign debt. Instead of reducing foreign debt, they have more than doubled foreign debt. Using the Treasurer's favoured measure of the debt per person in Australia—which he used when he was shadow Treasurer—our foreign debt is now $20,000 per man, woman and child in this country. It was in the order of $10,000 per man, woman and child in this country when the then opposition leader, and now Prime Minister, promised that an incoming Howard government would follow policies which would bring down the foreign debt. Instead the government has doubled foreign debt, and it has addicted the Australian people to debt.

The short-term economic consequences are already starting to appear. Figures released just today and yesterday are already showing evidence of a substantial economic slowdown as people realise how vulnerable they are, how overburdened with debt they are. House prices have started to fall. There is evidence that retail sales are now starting to fall and that there is an economic slowdown. This is an economic slowdown I talked about in my address-in-reply speech just three or four days ago. I did not realise that within three or four days evidence would already be coming in pointing to the high likelihood of such an economic slowdown. We can only hope that it will be a soft landing and not a hard landing. We can only hope that consumers will realise how overextended they are and gradually withdraw their consumption spending so that we land softly. If they do not, and if they were to continue consuming at the sorts of rates at which they have been consuming, then ultimately the inflationary consequences of that would mean that the Reserve Bank would have to intervene. So let us hope it is a soft landing, and not a hard landing as a result of Reserve Bank intervention, as inflation moves out of the target range of the Reserve Bank.

That is the short-term economic problem confronting Australia, but what of the long-term economic problem? Mr Deputy Speaker, as member for Blaxland, you also alluded to the problems of the ageing of the population and the sustainability of the sorts of measures that were announced here today. We know that the $900 million associated with these measures will not, of itself, break the bank, but this government is going to have to start thinking seriously about investing in the nation's future instead of continuing to promote a consumption boom. The government has committed $61 billion of new spending over the four years from the May budget, and all but $5 billion of it is consumption spending. The measures in this legislation are directly targeted at an ageing population; they are targeted at pensioners and self-funded retirees. But I have to ask the question that is opened up by this debate: who is going to pay for the ageing population in the generations to come? The truth of the matter is that fewer and fewer babies are being born in Australia as the fertility rate collapses. In 1961, at the peak of the baby boom, Australian couples had almost four children, on average, and now it is down to less than two—1.7 children, to be precise. The Intergenerational Report,which the Treasury produced two years ago—as confirmed by a Productivity Commission report on the ageing of the population which was released just last week—forecasts that the figure of 1.7 children will continue to fall to around 1.65 children. The fertility rate will continue to fall, and that means fewer and fewer children will be born.

But those four babies per family who were born at the peak of the baby boom are ageing. They are now already in their 40s and 50s and over the projection period of the Intergenerational Report—the next 40 years—those same baby boomers will be flooding into our hospitals and into our nursing homes. That is why the Treasurer has finally realised there is a problem with health spending in Australia. Marvellous technologies will keep those Australians alive longer. And that is what we want; that is a reflection of the progress we have made and of the improvement in living standards in this country. We want people to be able to stay alive longer and to be healthier. But declining mortality rates combined with collapsing fertility rates mean that there will be such an ageing of the population that there will be four million extra Australians over the age of 65 four decades from now.

How many more young people will there be? The answer is a very worrying one. There will be fewer young people. There will not be more people under the age of 15; there will be fewer people under the age of 15 four decades from now than there are in Australia today. We will have indeed around 250,000—we cannot be precise about these things—fewer children in 40 years time. What does that all mean for health care costs? The Productivity Commission estimates that health and aged care costs will take $13 of every $100 earned in Australia—that is government spending on health and aged care costs. That will be almost a doubling of present costs.

Should we be panicked about the ageing of the population? No, it is not a crisis but it certainly is a challenge. Sadly, the government only realised two years ago, after the preparation—I doubt that the government commissioned it—of the Intergenerational Report by the Treasury, that the ageing of the population was a problem. The problem, or challenge, is best solved by reference to the three Ps: population, participation and productivity. With the first, population, the die is already cast—as I have already explained. The ageing of the population over the next 40 years is a consequence of decisions taken by parents over the last 40 years. So the ageing of the population is inevitable. There is nothing that we can do about the ageing of the population. I will even invoke the phrase used by the Treasurer. He said, `Demography is destiny'. He is right about that. Occasionally he gets something right and on this occasion he is right. The die is cast. The ageing of the population is a reality and we are not going to be able to prevent it.

So how can we meet the challenge of the ageing of the population? We do it through the other two Ps. The second P is participation. Some good things can be done here. An increasingly skilled female work force will come into existence over the 40-year time frame covered by the Intergenerational Report and the Productivity Commission report. As those highly skilled women come into the work force in increasing numbers—and as they come to represent the norm rather than the exception, as perhaps was the case 40 years ago when educational outcomes were not quite as good as they are now—that will increase participation by working age women in the work force. That is a good thing. We should be encouraging that by encouraging family friendly provisions in and beyond the industrial relations system. Labor is the only party that is prepared to use the industrial relations system to encourage the provision of family friendly arrangements in agreements. So we can improve participation, and it will happen for working age women.

But the Treasurer has put almost all his eggs in one basket: improving the participation of older Australians. This is the work till you drop scheme. The Productivity Commission report that was released this week is a fascinating read on this matter. It is an indictment on the Treasurer. The Productivity Commission in fact did various sensitivity analyses in terms of changing the participation rate of older Australians. It came to the conclusion that changing the participation rate of older Australians in the work force can have at best negligible impacts on income growth in this country. So the very basket in which the Treasurer has put almost all his eggs is a dud basket. We cannot get there simply by requiring older Australians to work till they drop. That second P, participation of older Australians, will make very little difference. It will do very little in terms of responding effectively to the challenge of the ageing of the population.

So that leaves us with the third P. The third P is productivity growth. That is the key. As Labor has long recognised, today's productivity growth is tomorrow's prosperity. That is why Labor put in place that comprehensive and coherent economic reform program of the 1980s and early 1990s. It was designed to lift productivity growth by creating the open competitive economy. And Labor achieved that. The results have been astonishing. Australian productivity growth since around 1993 has outpaced that of just about every country in the world except Finland and Ireland. It certainly has outstripped that of the United States. But, having opened the door and created the open competitive economy, we cannot open that same door again. Therefore, it is incumbent on this generation of Australians, who are benefiting from the prosperity gained from the yield of the economic reforms of the 1980s and early 1990s, to identify and invest in the new sources of productivity growth in this country.

And we know what they are; it is not a secret. The new sources of productivity growth in Australia are investment in skills, investment in new ideas and investment in infrastructure. On all three grounds the government fails miserably. The Productivity Commission and the OECD have both concluded that in the 1990s skills formation actually detracted from productivity growth in Australia. We have underinvested in skills. We have certainly underinvested in new ideas: business spending on research and development as a share of gross domestic product has been falling since the change of government. It has picked up a bit just in the last couple of years but the gap between Australia and the OECD continues to widen. And we are underinvesting in infrastructure.

When the Governor-General outlined the forward program for this government, there was no coherent economic reform program designed to secure ongoing productivity growth in this country to combat the ageing of the population. While I welcome this legislation, the fact is that the government has failed appallingly to recognise the problem and to meet the challenges of Australia's ageing population.

talk.start.para: —During the 2004 election campaign, this government pledged extra assistance to certain important groups in the Australian community. This extra assistance is aimed at self-funded retirees, older Australians, carers on income support, grandparents caring for children and certain disability pensioners. The Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (2004 Election Commitments) Bill 2004 gives effect to the government's commitments.

speech.para: Firstly, all holders of the Commonwealth seniors health card will benefit from a new payment of $200 a year—the seniors concession allowance. The new payment recognises the fact that most self-funded retirees do not receive concessions for energy rates, water and sewerage, and motor vehicle registration from state and territory governments. It also acknowledges the community contribution made by this group of people in providing for their own retirement. The payment will be split into two payments—one in December and one in June each year—to people who are eligible cardholders on 1 December and 1 June respectively. It will be indexed twice yearly, will be exempt from income tax and will remain payable during temporary absences from Australia of up to 13 weeks.

In a further measure, the bill provides for senior Australians of age pension age or veteran pension age on income support to attract a new payment known as the utilities allowance. The payment will help these people to pay regular household bills such as gas and electricity. The new payment will generally be $100 a year for singles and $50 a year for each member of a couple. It will be paid twice each year following the pension indexation adjustments on 20 March and 20 September. Again, it will be indexed twice yearly, will not attract income tax and will still be paid if the person is temporarily absent from Australia for up to 13 weeks. These two significant new payments will help ease the financial demands on over two million older members of our community.

This bill will establish additional support for an important group of people in our community—those providing care for an adult or a child with a disability. These carers will now be able to spend 25 rather than 20 hours a week in work, training or study without losing qualification for carer payment. This greater flexibility will improve carers' work force opportunities and allow more of a break from caring without affecting their carer payment eligibility.

Grandparents with the primary care of their grandchildren fall into a further group who will benefit from the extra assistance provided by this bill. This particular measure is in addition to the waiver of the work, training and study test for child-care benefit already implemented by the government which allows eligible grandparents access to child-care benefit for up to 50 hours of approved child care a week. This bill will now make child care more affordable for grandparent carers on income support, such as age pension or carer payment, by enabling them to have access to a special rate of child-care benefit. This special rate will cover the full cost of child-care fees charged to eligible grandparents by approved child-care services.

Finally, the bill will provide for increased bereavement payments under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 in respect of disability pensioners who are receiving above the general rate of disability pension. Previously, the bereavement payment had been limited to 100 per cent of the general rate. I thank all those on our side and on the other side who contributed to the debate today, and I again commend the bill to the House.
Question put:

motion.para: That the words proposed to be omitted (Ms Plibersek's amendment) stand part of the question.

debateinfo.title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT (100% MEDICARE REBATE AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 17 November, on motion by Mr Abbott:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —At the outset I had better clarify some pervasive confusion about the Health Insurance Amendment (100% Medicare Rebate and Other Measures) Bill 2004. It is not like me to correct the clerks, because they are always correcting me, but it is not a 1,000 per cent Medicare rebate—as the clerk just read; it is 100 per cent. A 1,000 per cent Medicare rebate would be a lot more expensive than $1.7 billion, and I am not sure that the Howard government would stump up for that times 10.

speech.para: If the clerk is a little anxious about having misread the bill title, he should feel in good company because the Minister for Health and Ageing, when he spoke in the second reading debate on the last sitting Thursday, consistently referred to the bill as `the 90 per cent Medicare rebate bill'. It is very clearly audible on the tape; I would recommend it as required viewing to anybody in this parliament who is interested in Medicare issues. Of course, by the time we had the Hansard, it was corrected so the right figure—100 per cent—was written, but it does give you the occasional moment of concern that the minister for health seems to so fundamentally misunderstand the basis of a $1.7 billion measure that he is putting before the parliament. In truth the measure is for a 100 per cent Medicare rebate for unreferred GP services.

As members who were in this parliament prior to the last election might recall—and I am sure those who were contesting seats for election into this parliament would also recall—the health debate last term was about the Howard government's neglect of our health system. We saw bulk-billing rates plummet under the Howard government, we saw out-of-pocket costs to see the doctor soar and we saw that result in a national figure of six million fewer consultations in the Australian community with GPs. That is six million times Australians looked in their purses or wallets and decided they could not afford to see a GP under the policies of the Howard government.

We on this side of the House feared that many of the times that people postponed getting medical care from their GP they were putting off preventative health checks—the sort of thing they think they will get done the next month or the month after when they have a bit more money but, because of the financial barrier, they end up never getting done—or they were turning up looking for free care in emergency departments of public hospitals, putting them under more stress and strain. Through its policies the Howard government was developing a crisis in the affordability of access to general practitioners. Bulk-billing rates were tumbling nationally, in some communities by as much as 30 per cent, and the out-of-pocket costs of seeing the doctor were almost doubling on the Howard government's watch.

It was not a health policy issue that finally caused the Howard government to act. Having never been a supporter of Medicare, it was quite content to turn a blind eye as Medicare slowly withered under it. What startled the government into some form of action was public opinion polling which showed that the government's key weakness was in health. That was the only thing that caused the Howard government to react and to deal with bulk-billing issues and the out-of-pocket costs of seeing a general practitioner.

You have to give them marks for persistence, because they have had a few goes at it—there is no doubt about that. The first package was A Fairer Medicare, under the then minister for health, Senator Kay Patterson. A Fairer Medicare was really about creating, despite its name, a two-tiered Medicare—a means tested Medicare—where bulk-billing would forever have been confined to people with concession cards and everybody else would have paid to see the doctor. Like many of the Howard government's health policies it was inherently inflationary in terms of medical expenses. As history will record, A Fairer Medicare hit the fence. It was laughed out of court by the health professionals, including the doctors, as an absurd suite of policies. Ultimately the government backed away from it, and it achieved that in part by changing the minister to the current minister for health.

As I have had cause to remark in the past, we on this side of the House were breathlessly awaiting a second package, which was to be called `Even Fairer Medicare', but perhaps the Howard government realised the absurdity of that title, because they decided to move on to MedicarePlus. We saw the MedicarePlus package announced by the minister for health. Then MedicarePlus morphed into `Strengthening Medicare'. By then they were on go No. 3 of trying to fix their perceived political weakness in the area of health. Of course, none of this has been about health policy; it has been about political fixes.

`Strengthening Medicare' came with a television campaign which assaulted the screens of Australian viewers courtesy of the expenditure of more than $20 million of Australian taxpayers' money. There was a mail-out of a glossy booklet to every household in Australia and a travelling roadshow—which had quite an amazing capacity to turn up in marginal seats—going through shopping centres. The main thing the Howard government was interested in was having a program on which it could found an advertising campaign.

We will recall the media coverage at the time which had people whose job it was to buy advertising space on Australian TV for commercial entities—the people who buy advertising for Coca-Cola, Toyota, Coles and some of the biggest spenders on our TV screens—shaking their heads and saying that the spend that the Howard government engaged in for `Strengthening Medicare' was beyond saturation advertising and had gone to the diminishing returns part of the curve. Apparently there is a science about advertising which says, `If you ramp up and spend this much you will get the strongest public reaction, and if you spend over that amount you will get diminishing returns for your spend.' The Howard government was so flush with taxpayers' funds, funds out of my pocket and the pocket of every other Australian, that it kept spending beyond saturation.

So visible were these ads that I think many of us in the House would recall them being the subject of a very funny parody on the television show The Panel. These ads really did become a kind of feature of the public landscape for a while as the government spent and spent taxpayers' money to try and convince Australians in the run-up to the election that they had done something effective about health.

Against that background—three goes at trying to address bulk-billing and out-of-pocket costs and more than $20 million of taxpayers' funds spent on government advertising—we were bemused that the government thought that it needed to announce another Medicare measure during the election campaign, and so it decided to announce this measure, which is referred to as the 100 per cent Medicare measure. Once again, this has all the hallmarks of political fix about it. If 100 per cent Medicare was a good idea, one wonders why it was not in the budget papers with A Fairer Medicare, way back when, under Senator Patterson. If 100 per cent Medicare was a good idea, why didn't Minister Abbott announce it at the time that he announced MedicarePlus? If 100 per cent Medicare was a good idea, why didn't the government announce it and then advertise it as part of `Strengthening Medicare'? The government did not think it was a good idea back then.

The government was just feeding out health measures, complete with advertising, and watching the polls. It was nothing to do with health policy and all about the differential between the Labor Party and the coalition on the question of who would be best to handle health. The government watched those polls right up to the commencement of the campaign and said, `We've got to tip out another bucket of money. It doesn't matter what it goes on; we've just got to tip out another bucket of money. We've got to have a health story, create a health story, get a yarn, get a policy announcement'—and out came 100 per cent Medicare, which is in the bill that we are dealing with now. I think it is interesting that the Minister for Health and Ageing cannot remember the title of the bill and mistakes its intent by calling it `90 per cent Medicare'.

Let us be clear about what this package does. It increases the Medicare rebate for what are referred to as `unreferred GP services' from 85 per cent of the schedule fee to 100 per cent of the schedule fee. Of course, there is a whole lot of technical detail about what an unreferred GP service is. Most interactions that a member of the public would have with a GP fall into that category; certainly all the standard consultations do, and the Medicare rebate for those is to be increased from 85 per cent to 100 per cent. That will mean an additional rebate of $4.60 for a standard 15-minute GP consultation. Across all GP services, the average additional rebate is $5. We know that the current average out-of-pocket cost to see a GP who does not bulk-bill is $15.24. If—and I will come back to that very important word `if'—the GP hands on all of the additional rebate to the patient, the average out-of-pocket cost will be around $10. That is if it is handed on.

It really is a fairly simple proposition. The government is going to pay an increased Medicare rebate for most GP services. The fact that it is such a simple proposition actually means that it is a devastatingly flawed proposition. This package increases the Medicare rebate for unreferred GP services to 100 per cent of the schedule fee without putting any conditions on it. There is nothing in this legislation to increase bulk-billing or to sustain bulk-billing rates over time. There is nothing in this legislation to ensure that out-of-pocket costs for patients are minimised over time. They have just added the money in. Faced with adding the money in, what can a GP do? Apart from the minister for health's error in his speech about a 90 per cent Medicare rebate, the minister made it very clear that after this legislation comes into operation the doctor will work it out. So the government is going to pay an increased Medicare rebate and, to use the words of the minister for health, `decisions about bulk-billing will be up to individual doctors'. That is what he has said.

A doctor who is faced with this new government policy has a set of choices. A doctor could say, `I'll bulk-bill and get the 100 per cent Medicare rebate plus the bulk-billing incentives that came through the other Howard government health packages.' Or a doctor could say, `I won't bulk-bill but I will pass the increased Medicare rebate on to patients,' which will reduce the patient's out-of-pocket costs by $4.60 for a standard consultation. Or a doctor could say, `I'll pass on some of the increased Medicare rebate to the patient and moderate my out-of-pocket costs by $2 or $3.' So, effectively, when the transaction is completed, the patient has got some of the additional Medicare rebate with reduced out-of-pocket costs, and the doctor has got some of the increased Medicare rebate. Or a doctor could say, `I'm just going to keep my out-of-pocket costs as they are now. If I factor those as being $15, $20 or $25, I will keep it at $15, $20 or $25 on top of the new Medicare rebate, whereupon I am basically earning the extra money.'

Of course the Medicare rebate is the patient's. We understand that. It flows directly to the doctor when the doctor bulk-bills. It goes to the patient in other circumstances when the patient goes to claim their Medicare rebate, having paid the doctor the total fee. The circumstances I am describing are what will be the effective result at the end of the day when those transactions are completed. So the doctor might bulk-bill, or the doctor might change charges so that your out-of-pocket costs come down, or the doctor might change charges so that your out-of-pocket costs come down but not by the full amount of the new Medicare rebate, or the doctor might keep your out-of-pocket costs where they are now and effectively take the new Medicare rebate. There is nothing in this legislation which affects a doctor's decision about that. The doctor will make his or her own decision.

Against that background, is it going to increase bulk-billing? The minister for health says there should be more bulk-billing, because bulk-billing doctors will secure higher rebates. In the meantime, the AMA is urging members not to let this increased rebate take them back to `the treadmill of bulk-billing'. The President of Australian Medical Association, Dr Bill Glasson, has said that this is the beginning of the end of bulk-billing. There is nothing in this package that requires a doctor to bulk-bill and there are no conditions attached or tied into this package in any way.

In view of what is being said by the AMA—and presumably it is saying that being informed by the attitudes of its members, the GPs on the ground—I think we can say that this measure is not going to do anything for bulk-billing rates. Bulk-billing rates will not be sustained by this measure. It is not going to make a difference to bulk-billing. There is no condition in the package that will make a difference to bulk-billing.

What is going to happen with those doctors who do not bulk-bill? We know that in a number of communities all around the country finding a bulk-billing doctor is about as rare as seeing a blue moon or a pig flying; it is impossible for people to find a bulk-billing doctor, particularly people who do not have concession cards, even though they might be very low income earners with onerous family responsibilities. We know that all around Australia finding a bulk-billing doctor can be very, very difficult; many communities have faced falls of 30 per cent in bulk-billing. As a result of this bill, this new government proposal, what will happen to the out-of-pocket expense of the people in those communities who now pay to see the doctor? The only lead we really have on that is that the Minister for Health and Ageing seems to be figuring all of his work on the basis that the doctor and the patient will split the new increased rebate. Let us just go through the figures on that.

We should note, I think, that the Department of Health and Ageing has confirmed to the opposition in briefings that it has not modelled the effect of this package on GP incomes. The department has chosen not to make any assumption on what percentage of the rebate increase GPs will absorb into income and what they will pass on to patients. I suspect that the failure to get any modelling might arise from the fact that the government had not cooked up its 100 per cent Medicare rebate until we were in the campaign environment and could not draw down on departmental resources. The second theory is that it is classic Howard government—never ask a question that you do not want the answer to—because it might have been very worried about what that modelling was going to show: what was going to go into GP incomes and not into patients' hands. But, without any modelling, the minister for health—presumably assisted by a crystal ball which he rubs and in which he watches the clouds clear and then he makes an assumption about what is going to happen next—has made an assumption.

We know that the average GP sees about 7,000 patients per annum. So the simple maths would tell you that, if the average GP were going to keep the full rebate increase, their income growth would be around $35,000 per annum. Minister Abbott, assisted by the crystal ball into which he has gazed, has decided that the answer to this is that GP income will increase by about $20,000 per annum. The minister's assertion that GPs are going to increase their incomes by about $20,000 per annum means basically that he is expecting doctors to keep around $3 of the increased rebate, and have that feed into income, and pass on about $2 in reduced out-of-pocket costs to patients. So even though the minister was in here saying in his second reading speech, `Let me stress that all patients will benefit from this measure,' the absolute high point he would put that at, even on his own crystal ball gazing, is that the average patient might see a $2 reduction in their out-of-pocket expense. That is not much of a result for having spent $1.7 billion. We do not even know if the minister is right, and it is well and truly possible that he is wrong and patients will see even less than that. That would only be an assumption about the first effect, because the world does not stand still; health does not stand still. Over the medium term, doctors will make decisions about where they are going to put their fee level. Over the medium term, we would expect those fees to rise; historically they always have. In those circumstances, even the minister's predicted $2 gain for patients may well not be sustained.

That brings me to the question of the sustainability of this package over time. We asked the Department of Health and Ageing to supply to us how it arrived at the annual cost of this measure. It is a $1.7 billion package with costs over the half-year, starting from 1 January next year, and then the remainder of the out years, and there are various figures at the bottom of those tables. We have asked the department, `How did you generate those figures? What is the indexation arrangement? What assumption are you making about the number of times Australians will visit a GP?'—things you would think you needed to do to come up with a robust figure in a budget bottom line for the forward estimates. But the department has indicated to us that the figures are indexed by the current WCI5 indexation rate, which is commonly used in health—it is a wage indexation rate—of around two per cent a year. If it is indexed at two per cent a year—and we know that health inflation runs at a greater rate than that—it means that, even if the minister for health is right and even if patients on 1 January are going to see a $2 reduction in their out-of-pocket expense, that by definition is not going to be sustained over time because the increase in GP costs will in real terms exceed the indexed 100 per cent Medicare rebate. So this is all an illusion that may last for a little time. But 12 months, two years or three years away we will be seeing once again patient out-of-pocket costs increasing—and let us remember that they have almost doubled under the Howard government so far.

Just to prove the proposition that medical fees keep rising, the AMA has announced their annual recommended fee schedule and it is indexed at 3.41 per cent. So already we have the AMA recommending an indexation rate which is higher than the indexation in this package. A survey conducted in the November GP Journal found that 52 per cent of GPs were planning to increase their fees, with more than 80 per cent of GPs now surveyed now charging a standard fee in excess of $40. So the news over the medium to longer term is not happy when it comes to 100 per cent Medicare. The very small changes it will make to patient out-of-pockets in the short-term will not be sustained over time.

There is another very interesting thing in the government's figures when you look at them. The first thing that struck me when I looked at the figures was the first full year of the figures. There is obviously a half year because of the 1 January start, but the first full year of the figures actually has in it a higher number than the final out year. You have to say to yourself: why is that? Why is the cost of the measure apparently going down over time? How is that possible? When we asked the department that, we got back from it the indication about the indexation rate, but that cannot explain the figure going down if it is indexed. I tell you what explains the figure going down: it is that the government has assumed there will be fewer GP visits over time. It is impossible for the government's figures to add up any other way unless we are going to see fewer GP services provided over time.

Is that a rational assumption by the Howard government, even in the face of population growth? Perhaps it is a rational assumption, because the Howard government's policies to date have driven fewer GP consultations over time because they have created the crisis in affordability and access. So it probably is rational for the Howard government to assume that this flawed policy is not going to make a difference to that, that the crisis of affordability in access, the continued declines in the availability of bulk-billing—particularly in some communities—and the increasing out-of-pocket costs will be sustained over time, that fewer and fewer people will go to the doctor, and that more and more people will go without care or will go to the emergency departments of public hospitals looking for care and causing unnecessary costs and cost-shifting in our health system. The figures in this assume that result, so we know that the Howard government believes from these figures that people will go to the GP less.

When we have put this contention to the minister and the department we have had put to us some impenetrable mumbo jumbo about there being an increasing number of long consultations. It might be right that there are increasing numbers of long consultations, but unless you are putting the proposition that one long consultation is a substitute for five, six, seven or eight standard consultations it still does not add up that the figures are going down over time. Longer consultations are more expensive than short consultations, so increasing numbers of long consultations should have the figures going up over time, not down. It also does not explain GPs reacting to the price signal that is in the government's bulk-billing incentive—an incentive that is a flat dollar fee which is worth more to you if you add it on to a short consultation rather than a long consultation. The government has actually sent GPs a price signal that it prefers short consultations, so the government's spin about that does not stand up to anything that looks like rigorous scrutiny.

That is where we find ourselves. The fourth political fix of the Howard government in the area of bulk-billing and out-of-pocket costs is yet again a failed political fix, and I would not be surprised if over the next three years we are back here several times. Having had A Fairer Medicare, Strengthening Medicare, MedicarePlus and 100 per cent Medicare, I am not sure what the government's ad agencies are going to come up with next, but we will have two or three more Medicare packages before we get to the next election because it will not have fixed the problem. You cannot fix the problem by spending $1.7 billion without attaching any conditions to it in respect of bulk-billing or moderating out-of-pocket costs. The Howard government will not fix the problem through this package.

We obviously understand that the government put this policy before the Australian people in the election campaign. It has a 1 January start date. Whilst on the minister's own estimates the best it will do is give people an additional $2 in the short term as a decreased out-of-pocket cost, it is not our intention to stand between the Australian people and that additional $2, should they get it—and obviously many of them will not get any of it—so we have facilitated the government's arrangements to expedite the consideration of this bill. Whilst I will be moving an amendment in the House shortly, it is not our intention to delay passage of this bill either here or in the Senate, so the government can meet the 1 January implementation date. Then we will be holding the government accountable as to whether this $1.7 billion has been properly spent.

The bill does have two other measures in it. There was an anomaly in the original design of the Howard government's so-called safety net. As we recall, the safety net has two different thresholds. There is a different threshold for families that are eligible for family tax benefit A. People get paid that family tax benefit in different ways. We know that some people get it fortnightly, therefore their entitlement to the lower safety net threshold is apparent. Some people get it paid as a lump sum at the end of the year through the tax system. They choose not to take it fortnightly, presumably because of the high degree of sensitivity about overpayments—and we can well understand that high degree of sensitivity. These families actually file a deferral with Centrelink and then get their benefit as a lump sum at the end of the financial year, but the safety net arrangements as they currently stand do not make it clear that those families trigger the lower threshold. That anomaly will be corrected. Then, of course, there will be a change to veterans' Medicare rebates to maintain the relativity between veterans' Medicare rebates and the Medicare rebates paid to other Australians. That is consequential on the rest of this bill and is dealt with in the bill itself.

Our concern is not about fixing the safety net anomaly—and we will have things to say about the safety net on another occasion—or about maintaining the relativity on Medicare rebates for veterans and veterans gold card holders. Our concern is about the essence of this package and that, in a world where it is hard to find extra dollars for health and where there are always pressures on the health system, this is a deeply flawed policy which will spend $1.7 billion on the Medicare component alone but will not fix the problems that are causing people major difficulties in getting access to GP care. With that, I move the following amendment:
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“while not declining to give the Bill a second reading, this Parliament condemns the government for:

(1) doing nothing while out of pocket costs to see a general practitioner have soared from a little over $8 to a national average of $15.37 and failing to attach conditions to 100% Medicare aimed at reducing out of pocket costs;
(2) causing bulk billing rates to fall from 80% under Labor to a little over 70% and failing to attach conditions to 100% Medicare aimed at bolstering bulk billing rates;
(3) failing to ensure that any of the $1.7 billion spent will be passed on to patients; and
