(4) continuing its undermining of Medicare as Australia's universal public health insurance system”.

talk.start.para: (Hon. B.C. Scott)—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

—To respond to the member for Lalor's speech, I think she is operating under a number of flawed assumptions. The first is that general practitioners are grasping, greedy individuals and that the reason they might raise their fees has something to do with an increasing cost base. As a former plaintiff lawyer—an ambulance chaser—she would be a contributor to this, because it is well known in this place that one of those substantial cost increases in the conduct of a general practice is the massive increase in professional indemnity insurance fees. These fees have been brought about by the actions of plaintiff lawyers by suing general practitioners for just about anything that can happen, and over periods of up to 24 years.

speech.para: Somebody practising in the legal profession should understand—and it was understood by the designers of Medicare during a period when I was present in this House—part V, section 51(xxiiiA) of the Australian Constitution, which, in simple terms, prevents a form of civil conscription of medical practitioners. The member for Lalor said in her speech that there was nothing in the Health Insurance Amendment (100% Medicare Rebate and Other Measures) Bill 2004 to virtually force doctors to comply with bulk-billing. No-one knows better than she does that that would be unconstitutional and that no government has had the power to dictate what general practitioners charge.

She suggests that there could be an increase in fees that general practitioners charge, for whatever good reason—and I underline the words `good reason'—when the outcome of this legislation is that the patient will be $4.60 better off or, to use her other example, $1.7 billion better off over four years, because that is the additional money that this government is providing to rebate to patients. It is a patient rebate. If medical practitioners who do not bulk-bill increase their fees, then the patient is still better off by $4.60. To suggest that there is some relationship between that and what the government provides is patently false and typical of the member for Lalor. The first thing we have to understand is that whenever bulk-billing was introduced in its various forms it was always a voluntary scheme.

The member for Lalor cries crocodile tears and talks about people in country areas—of which you, Mr Deputy Speaker Scott, would know something. The only people who ever made a real profit out of bulk-billing, and then went on to buy football teams and things of that nature, were doctors who were in a position to practise in areas of high-density population and who set themselves up in practices where they had all sorts of associated services, such as pathology, x-rays and you name it. That was very profitable for a period.

The member for Lalor asked us to consider history prior to the last election. I would like her to consider back into the early 1980s, when this form of Medicare was created by Minister Blewett and the Hawke government. I would like her to remember that, during that period, they discovered the tiger they had by the tail and set about to reduce the incidence of bulk-billing. One of those policies eventually introduced by the Keating government was a media campaign that we had too many doctors and they were all rushing into the metropolitan areas to bulk-bill and buy football teams. There was a policy decision made, which is a matter of public record, to reduce the intake of medical graduates by 4,500 about 10 years ago—and, surprise surprise, what is now one of the pressures on bulk-billing and on the availability of general practitioners outside of the high-density areas? Whether in the peripheries of the big cities or throughout country areas, what is the other problem? We are short 4,500 doctors who, if it had not been for the initiative of the Hawke and Keating government, would be young undergraduates coming in to the stream 10 years later. We do not hear about that effect on bulk-billing. We do not hear about the competition that that might have brought into the market that would probably have turned more general practitioners to bulk-billing.

So when we look at it we find these various circumstances, but then of course—and it is oft forgotten in history—the Hawke government also decided, for the purpose of reducing bulk-billing, to introduce a copayment. Minister Howe brought in the copayment and it was passed through the parliament. Then Treasurer Keating decided he was going to challenge for the leadership of the Labor Party and, consequently, the prime ministership. What did he do? When he lost the first contest in Caucus, he went off to the left wing and said, `Switch your vote from Hawke to Keating and I will cancel the copayment.' That is the history of the Hawke and Keating governments—underline `governments'—in their management of bulk-billing and the attempts they made to reduce it.

That is the last time we had a Labor government. It is all right to be the smart alec in opposition with all your wonderful schemes—and I wish the member for Lalor had stayed around to be reminded that, while she is criticising the Howard government for spending money, she was the author of Medicare Gold and goodness knows how much that would have cost. Anybody who stands up and proposes something like Medicare Gold has no grounds whatsoever to criticise anybody else in this parliament who suggests some level of expenditure.

The first factor arising from the speech made by the member for Lalor is that one of the causes of increased doctors fees chooses to criticise them and to suggest to this House that, in contravention of the Constitution, this legislation should contain measures to virtually force medical practitioners, and GPs in particular, to enter the bulk-billing system when it is unconstitutional and ignores the cost based variation that occurs throughout Australia in the delivery of medical services. I have already made the point that, in the electorate of O'Connor, there is not one general practitioner who, in my recollection, has ever bulk-billed. That is not because they are greedy, grasping individuals; it is because, given the population density of the areas they service, they could never survive on what various governments have set as the schedule fee, be it 80 per cent or 100 per cent. The point is that they just do not have enough patients but, on the other hand, they provide a magnificent service.

For many years in my electorate it has not been uncommon that not only did doctors not bulk-bill but the community, through their local authority, also has had to provide subsidies—be that a car, premises, residence or sometimes just up-front cash. That was not because the practitioners were greedy, grasping people. Many of them, as time has gone by, have been overseas doctors—yes, I might say the majority. These people have given a wonderful service, but they are entitled to a reasonable living. This bill improves their chances, particularly if they bulk-bill, remembering that, as was admitted by the member for Lalor, the $7.65 and $5.10 bulk-billing incentives also remain.

But let us compare this proposal with what the member for Lalor and her leader took to the last election. It was bulk-billing, bulk-billing, bulk-billing. So, for people living in high-density population areas, a practice can probably economically operate as a 100 per cent bulk-billing practice. But the reality is that, in other areas, were Labor to have been elected on their policies, the people who had no choice about bulk-billing would not have received anything. Irrespective of the somewhat generous proposals that were announced at the time to get people back into bulk-billing, there were two factors that they did not consider. Firstly, some doctors have never bulk-billed and have a philosophical objection to bulk-billing and, if they are the only doctor for 100 kilometres around, there is a fair chance you will go and see them. Secondly, if you are elderly, you have attended the same practice for many years and you have faith and confidence in that practitioner, you are not going to leave.

Where do those people stand? Under the provisions in this bill, they are at least $4.60 better off than they would have been under Labor if no bulk-billing were available. At least, when they make their claim, if they pay up front they will get the additional money—about $30. That is what they will get, whatever the doctor charges. I do not commit the government, but let me say that the schedule fee has risen ever since I have been in this parliament. I have never really investigated the formula or the arrangements but, quite clearly, it does increase and no doubt there are some arrangements associated with that. The member for Lalor just completely ignored that proposition. She suggested that this thing is set in concrete and as the doctors charge more—as they will; as I said, one of the reasons is the cost of their professional indemnity insurance—that is a cut from this $4.60 average. It is not, and that is another thing that must be said about her amendment, which is virtually misleading the House.

She wants to condemn the government for `failing to ensure that any of the $1.7 billion spent will be passed on to patients'. It will all be passed on to patients, whether or not the doctor takes it and bulk-bills and they walk out of the surgery paying nothing. If that is the incentive that pushes a doctor into bulk-billing, the patient is the beneficiary. And, of course, if they are going to a non-bulk-billing doctor because they have no choice, when they get their rebate from Medicare it will be $4.60 higher than it was previously and, what is more, $4.60 higher than in any proposal from the Labor Party during the election.

These are the fundamental issues that we are talking about. It is about time that, when people bring amendments to the House, they are at least based on fact or are otherwise truthful. This amendment is a blatant misleading of the House—unless of course you are in some way numerically challenged. I do not know how many sums you do when you are doing your law course, but it seems to me that there is not much evidence that the member for Lalor carried on with arithmetic. It is clearly and truly an assistance, and it is the only assistance to people in my electorate and people living in the outer suburbs.

This is also about getting a supply of doctors, which this government has set about doing. We have a number of excellent policies that are associated with getting enough medical practitioners into the field. As a deliberate policy decision, the last Labor government—not the Labor opposition that come up with all these miracle cures in the hope that they never have to implement them—reduced the intake of undergraduates in the medical disciplines by 4,500. That pain is just hitting Australia. We all know that the lead time from starting an undergraduate course to becoming an independently practising GP is about 10 years. We have to look at all of these factors. So, whilst it is all right for the Labor Party to say that the system is not working, the fact is that it is fundamentally their system.

Bulk-billing has always been a difficult issue, and it is something that the parliament cannot impose upon these other people. It cannot be done and it will not be done. That is the fundamental issue. I am amazed when I look at this. There are issues that are of considerable importance. The 100 per cent of the schedule fee is not restricted to the much publicised figure of $4.60. That is for a standard consultation of between six and 20 minutes. Were the time to be, for instance, over 40 minutes, the additional payment would be nearly $13, which of course has to be a great help.

It is worth mentioning at this time that, under the Labor government and its Medicare policies, if you lived in the electorate of O'Connor and you had to see a non-bulk-billing doctor and pay cash at the door, when you got your account the only means by which you could get reimbursement was to post off your application form and wait for a cheque in the mail, notwithstanding that you might have a very low net income because you might have two or three kids or be a pensioner—because there was no Medicare office out there, whereas someone in a metropolitan area could virtually go around the corner to get a cash refund. The money was gone and you just did not have it for that period of time. The initiatives that this government took in that regard to deal with this system included electronic transfer into your bank account. More importantly, we put in Medicare Easyclaim. We have also funded a large number of rural transaction centres, where people can get the speediest possible access to a Medicare refund.

Let us hope that, at least in the foreseeable future, with the endorsement of the Australian people, who provided this government with a majority in both houses—remember that was the people's decision—we might be able to introduce legislation, which the Labor Party once cancelled so someone could become Prime Minister, involving a sensible copayment arrangement whereby the medical practitioner can make a charge in his surgery. That of course was something that was deliberately forbidden under the Labor plan—again, to force people into a form of civil conscription that could not be done through legislation. If the doctor's fee is an additional $10, people should have the right to pay the $10 in the surgery and the doctor should be able to claim the full rebate that we are providing. That would be sensible and convenient for people wherever they were. But, of course, the reason that Labor have blindly opposed that simple arrangement is that they are scared stiff that fewer and fewer doctors will operate under their preferred method of bulk-billing.

I congratulate the government for taking this particular measure. It will be infinitely beneficial to my constituents, who were going to get nothing under Labor. They very smartly worked that out, and my Labor opponent's vote went down by two or three per cent, from what was previously a relatively low level. People are not silly. They know the difference. This is good legislation and the appropriate response.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker Baldwin, I start by congratulating you on your elevation to the Speaker's panel. It feels a bit like old home week making this speech, with you in the chair and the minister at the table, the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads, coming from the Central Coast.
—Or groundhog day.

—Maybe not quite. The Health Insurance Amendment (100% Medicare Rebate and Other Measures) Bill 2004, as has been said by all other speakers, delivers on the Howard government's promise to increase the rebate for all GP services from 85 per cent to 100 per cent. Whilst we on this side of the House will not be voting against the legislation, I believe it is based on a poor policy premise. I support the amendments moved by the shadow minister, and I will spend some time going over some of the issues that she has raised and which have been raised in these amendments.

speech.para: It is of great concern to me that this legislation is based on poor health economics. Any decision that the government takes should have a definite outcome; the government should be aware of the outcome that it will deliver. I do not believe the government really knows where it is going with this. Yes, it will deliver a 100 per cent rebate to the patients of GPs, but there is no guarantee that those patients will pay any less, and there is no guarantee that there will be an increase in bulk-billing. I feel that the government has tricked the Australian people into thinking this is a good policy which is going to lower their health costs, when in fact there is absolutely no guarantee whatsoever that this legislation will deliver lower health costs for the Australian people. Whilst the rebate for all GP services is going to be increased from 85 per cent to 100 per cent, that does not in any way, as I have already outlined, guarantee cheaper costs for the Australian people.

This package was announced on 6 September. It is quite different from the Labor Party's new deal to save Medicare, which was designed to increase bulk-billing by GPs in the community. Since the Howard government was elected, the bulk-billing rate in my electorate has fallen by 30 per cent. Currently, 51.3 per cent of all services in the Shortland electorate are bulk-billed. This has created severe disadvantage for a number of people in the community. Coupled with the acute doctor shortage in the region, this is creating a lot of hardship for people. Since the election on 9 October we have lost two doctors from the area—one on the Central Coast and one at Lake Macquarie. This translates as longer waiting times for people to see their doctor and higher costs for services.

The previous speaker, the member for O'Connor, has quite a selective interpretation of the cause of the doctor shortage. I have a distinct memory of the 1996 legislation introduced by this government which had a very negative impact on the number of GPs available and resulted in poorer service levels and longer waiting periods for people in the community. This 100 per cent rebate benefit will apply to non-referred attendances provided by vocational and non-vocational registered GPs, consultations in GPs' surgeries, after-hours consultations, home and aged care visits, and services provided by GPs to their unadmitted patients in hospitals.

I would like to concentrate on home and aged care visits. In my area, particularly on the Central Coast, residents are not being admitted to aged care facilities simply because they do not have a GP who will treat them in those facilities. It is all very well for the government to say they are going to extend the 100 per cent rebate, but I would be really happy if they would take some action to ensure that people can get medical treatment and get a GP to visit them when they are in those facilities. We need at least a commitment from a GP so that those persons can be transferred from our public hospitals to aged care facilities. This bill will also ensure that veterans get a 115 per cent rebate as opposed to the 100 per cent rebate that nonveterans receive.

I would like to spend some time talking about the fees that GPs are charging and how I really do not believe this legislation will do anything to stem the increase in doctors' fees. The previous speaker attributed all fees to medical indemnity insurance. I have already identified one reason for those increases in fees, and that is a doctor shortage. It is a way that doctors can manage their caseload. Until the government does something that is real in that area, I do not believe the situation will improve in any way. Since the election, an increase in doctors' fees has already been recommended, and I think this is just a symptom of something to come. These increases will be ongoing and, of course, once again it will be the patients, the Australians who rely on their doctors, who will have to bear that cost. It is very bad policy, as I have already stated, to grant an increase—to introduce a policy without having in mind a measured outcome. In her amendments, the shadow minister noted the increase in people's out-of-pocket medical expenses. These expenses have soared from a little over eight per cent to 15.3 per cent, and this does affect people when they have to make a decision as to whether or not they can afford to see their doctor.

I have had a number of constituents visit me in my office and tell me about how they have to balance their budget in order to be able to go and see the doctor. You see, in my area it is not just people in receipt of wages who are not being bulk-billed; rather, it is the pensioners and people with health care cards who are attending the doctor and not being bulk-billed. The government's previous measure, which increased payments to doctors for the bulk-billing of pensioners and young people under 16, resulted in a couple of surgeries within my electorate introducing or reintroducing bulk-billing. But do you know when that finished? I hate to tell you, but it was as soon as the election was over. Isn't that interesting? Here we had a government initiative put in that was taken up by a very small minority of practices and which in most practices has now been dropped. Once again, it was a short-term fix and one that I believe benefited the government more than the people in my electorate.

The minister at the table, the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads, would be aware that in our area on the Central Coast none of the doctors started bulk-billing after the government introduced its package earlier this year. Rather, they approached both the government and the opposition and asked for help in managing the crisis that exists on the Central Coast of New South Wales. This crisis has been caused by the doctor shortage and the ageing population. All the electorates on the Central Coast have rather elderly populations. The minister's electorate has the fifth oldest population in Australia. Shortland has the 10th oldest population in Australia. Dobell, which is the other electorate on the Central Coast, has the 29th oldest population in Australia. This, coupled with the fact that there is also a very young population and an extremely disadvantaged population, causes a situation that I would have to say is explosive. It has caused an enormous increase in the waiting times in our public hospitals and it has caused enormous hardship for people who have difficulty either getting an appointment with a doctor or being able to afford an appointment with a doctor.

The government need to do a little bit more than what they have done in this legislation. There needs to be a guarantee to Australians that this legislation, previous legislation and subsequent legislation are going to deliver better access to health care and lower health costs to the Australian people. Otherwise, we are going to have a situation where there are only going to be a few people who can afford to access a quality health service and quality health treatment. The remainder of the population will be forced to accept a second-rate health service and in many cases will not be able to afford to attend their GP. That is a very sad state of affairs.

There are also some concerns about this legislation from the doctors' point of view. Whilst the legislation says that the rebate will be indexed, it does not say how it will be indexed and it does not guarantee that the level of indexation will actually match the increases in costs for doctors. Over a period of time the benefits of this package for doctors will be eroded. On the one hand you have the package not delivering for patients, as it is quite obvious that many doctors will for one reason or another continue to charge their patients at a level similar to the level they are charging at the moment. On the other hand, you have a situation where doctors will find that this promised increase will erode. If practice costs increase at about 4.5 per cent per annum, the new rebate will be eroded by 2010. That is if the average index is based on the WCI5. That is approximately two per cent per annum.

I do not believe this package was modelled properly. I do not think that it was given a robust assessment. I believe that the health economics employed here are unsound and that the outcomes for patients will be very poor. I am sure that initially it will benefit a number of people but it will not take too long before any benefit that patients receive is eroded. This legislation is quite flawed. I do not want to be coming back here in a year's time saying, `I told you so.' What I want to be coming back here in a year's time and saying is, `All Australians have access to quality health care and we do not have a second-class health system here in Australia.' Unfortunately, under the Howard government we have had a decline in doctors, we have had enormous doctor dissatisfaction and we have had a dramatic fall in bulk-billing. The losers are the Australian people. I support the amendment that has been moved by the shadow minister and I would like to suggest to the minister that he looks at and accepts it—and that he employs a good health economist to evaluate his legislation before it is introduced into this parliament.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker Baldwin, may I take this opportunity to congratulate you on your election to the Speaker's panel. I rise to speak in support of the Health Insurance Amendment (100% Medicare Rebate and Other Measures) Bill 2004. Australians enjoy what is arguably the best and most affordable health system in the world. This bill honours the government's election commitments to make it potentially even more affordable.

speech.para: Our general practitioners perform admirably on a daily basis. They have earned the respect of their communities and—just as importantly—they have earned their confidence. Since the election of the Howard government in 1996, a great deal of work has been done to protect and strengthen Medicare and to provide even greater access to high-quality GP services. Under Strengthening Medicare, provision has been made for a further 1,500 doctors and 1,600 practice nurses. The aim of the federal government is to ensure that as many Australians as possible have access to quality and convenient GP services when they are needed.

During the recent election campaign, the government gave a commitment to make GP services more affordable for all Australians. This bill honours that commitment. This is as opposed to the ridiculous proposition, during the campaign, by the member for Lalor and opposition health spokesperson, of Medicare Gold, described I think by Peter Botsman as having the head of a donkey and the body of a wombat. In the animal farm that is the present Labor Party, where would we place this piece of political recklessness? For the sake of Australia, we can only hope it goes the way of the dodo.

When Labor caucus voted for a previous opposition leader, media comment suggested that the turkeys had voted for Christmas. There are now fewer turkeys but just as much squawking by members opposite. Apart from the mangy dog, the dead parrot, the collection of roosters and a new entrant, the red-crested galah, during the election campaign we had the Labor Party promising a turtle interpretation centre. Why? Who knows. I do not think the turtles were requiring a Medicare rebate! And we must not forget the Milky Bar Kid, who politely awaits the demise and removal of the dead parrot so that he may then lead this menagerie. He is not hoping to send the dead parrot for resuscitation to his local GP—no, he is just waiting politely for the other's demise and removal, which I am sorry to say is not funded under Medicare.

Indeed, the public must be feeling extremely pleased that the coalition was returned to office at the recent election as it looks on at the bewildering display of political shenanigans. What people expect from an opposition is at least some form of policy coherence. At least the people of Australia will get good health policy and economic management from the coalition government.

Subject to the passage of this bill, from 1 January 2005 the rebate for all GP services will be increased from 85 per cent to 100 per cent of the Medicare schedule fee. This means that, for the standard 15-minute surgery consultation, an additional rebate of $4.50 a visit is paid. If the GP does not bulk-bill, the patient will still benefit from lower out-of-pocket costs after they receive the 100 per cent Medicare rebate. As a further encouragement to doctors to bulk-bill their patients in addition to the incentives contained in Strengthening Medicare, the payment will be made to the doctor for consultations that are bulk-billed. Through this measure, the government will invest more than $1.7 billion over four years to make GP services more affordable. The 100 per cent Medicare rebate will apply to consultations provided in GPs' surgeries; after-hours, home and aged care facility visits; and attendances by GPs on their unadmitted patients in a hospital.

Many Australian families are already benefiting from the new Medicare safety net introduced by this government. This bill contains further measures which will confirm eligibility for the extended Medicare safety net at the $300 threshold for all families that are eligible for family tax benefit part A. I remind honourable members that the extended Medicare safety net covers 80 per cent of out-of-pocket costs for Medicare services provided outside hospital once the yearly threshold is met.

By increasing the level of rebate to 100 per cent of the schedule fee, more services are likely to be bulk-billed. This is in addition to the already considerable incentives provided to doctors to bulk-bill pensioners and families with children. General practitioners will see their base Medicare fee incomes for services increase by around 15 per cent as a result of these changes. These can be further increased if they choose to accept the government's $5 and $7.50 bulk-billing incentives for children under 16 and concession card holders. Bulk-billing remains the choice of individual doctors, but there are now considerable incentives in place for them to pass on lower out-of-pocket costs to their patients.

It is unfortunate that Australia's world-class health system is not supported by the Labor opposition. It is troubling that Labor took policies to the last election which would have undermined Medicare and put at risk the very real improvements in medical services that have been delivered over the last 8½ years. Australia has a unique system of public and private delivery of health services which needs to be kept in the right balance. If Labor is ever given the opportunity to implement its draconian policies then not only will the private health system collapse but the very safety of Medicare will be in doubt. Labor needs to remove its ideological blinkers and understand that you cannot destroy one sector without seriously undermining the other.

If it is to be taken seriously, Labor also needs to learn that it needs to adopt more fiscally responsible policies. Open-ended funding promises issued during an election campaign are simply not to be believed—not even by those for whom the benefit is meant to accrue. It should never be forgotten that this government inherited a $10 billion black hole from the Keating Labor government. There were problems in the aged care sector, which had been ignored for years, and immunisation rates had dropped to Third World levels. While the Labor states continue to renege on their responsibilities for public hospitals, mental health, and disability funding, the Howard government will provide funding of up to $42 billion under the 2003-08 Australian health care agreements. This is a further $10 billion, or a real increase of 17 per cent.

The government is also providing $252 million worth of projects under the Pathways Home Program to assist people to return home after a period of acute care in hospital. Mr Deputy Speaker, 55.6 per cent of total public health expenditure in Australia comes from the Howard government, compared with the 44.4 per cent provided by the states and territories. We are doing more to achieve improved health outcomes, such as providing $812 million over five years to support breast cancer, cervical screening and a range of other public health services. We are doing more to improve the blood supply process by committing over $500 million to the purchase of blood and blood products.

On 29 June 2004, the Prime Minister announced a further $116 million package of initiatives over four years to build a healthy, active Australia. This package provides a national framework for addressing childhood obesity and complements the work of the National Obesity Taskforce. With each initiative we aim to provide more accessible and affordable health services to all the Australian people. Thanks to the government's policies, bulk-billing is on the increase again as more doctors take advantage of the incentives on offer. The doctors benefit, the patients benefit, and Australia's economy continues to prosper—a good result all round. I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Health Insurance Amendment (100% Medicare Rebate and Other Measures) Bill 2004, and to speak against the proposed amendment. I am delighted to be speaking on this bill because it implements one of the government's major election policy announcements made in early September during the election campaign: to increase the Medicare rebate for GP services from 85 per cent to 100 per cent of the schedule fee. In dollar terms, this means that there will be an almost $5 increase in the rebate for a standard GP consultation. The bill supports the government's commitment to delivering high-quality, affordable health care.

speech.para: This bill represents one of the most important improvements to Medicare in 20 years. It assists both GPs and their patients. Through the measures in this bill, which are complemented by the government's previously announced Strengthening Medicare initiatives, the government is providing real incentive for GPs to bulk-bill. But, importantly, GPs are not forced to bulk-bill. Where a GP does bulk-bill, they will receive the higher rebate; where they do not and the patient is charged for a visit to the doctor, the patient receives the increased rebate. During the election campaign the Leader of the Opposition proclaimed:

quote.para: When it comes down to it, on the ninth of October it's a referendum about the future of Medicare. It's a referendum about the future of health care this country.

speech.para: If this statement is anything to go by, I am pleased to note that the people of Australia—and indeed the people in my electorate of Indi—think that their health care system is in pretty safe hands under the Howard government.

Bulk-billing is important and it should be available to those who need it. But in the end, as we all know, bulk-billing is a matter between doctors and patients. This was the case in 1984 and it remains the case 20 years later, despite the sometimes hysterical ranting of the member for Lalor. She supports coercive measures to transform the GP profession into an enclave of government-controlled, bureaucratic public servants offering a new style of socialist medicine. Perhaps the member for Lalor should not be so peremptory. It is a little-known but curious fact that if the proposals that the Labor Party took to the election were implemented, the actual incidence of bulk-billing would have declined. For months, the Labor Party trumpeted its bulk-billing proposals, which, according to the policy document, would have meant that `GPs on average will receive an extra $3.35 per consultation'. They later raised it to about $5 per consultation, but did it not occur to the Labor Party that GPs in my electorate were already receiving an extra $7.50 loading when they bulk-billed a goodly number of their patients?

This point opens up a number of interesting scenarios. Let us say that a person is charged $40 for a visit to their GP. Under this legislation they will be rebated at a higher rate of $30.20. If the Labor Party's approach were followed the patient would receive only $25.70. Taking this point even further, in conjunction with the Strengthening Medicare initiatives, when the measures contained in this bill come into force on 1 January 2005, if a child or a Commonwealth concession cardholder in my electorate is bulk-billed, the GP rebate will be $37.70, whereas under the Labor Party's proposals the rebate would still only have been $30.20.

Labor only had a plan to offer higher rebates to GPs who bulk-billed. This flies in the face of the longstanding principle of universal access to the Medicare rebate that underpins a patient's contact with their GP. Once again we have winners and losers, discrimination and division and insiders and outsiders. These are the binding philosophies behind the modern Labor Party's approach in 2004 that were so clearly illustrated in the recent federal election. The Labor Party believes in division and strife. Its leader is obsessed with class warfare and envy. The Leader of the Opposition sees us as a dog-eat-dog society infested with categories of irreconcilable interests.

With the current Leader of the Opposition it is always the parts, never the whole. He remains an angry class warfare warrior who sees the world through the eyes of his roots. The tiresome repetition of the Green Valley story is in no way born out of empathy with those he left behind; it is driven by envy and anger towards those who never lived there. Not only did we see a manifestation of this in the Labor Party's schools policy—which even the Catholic and Anglican archbishops of Melbourne and Sydney saw as `potentially divisive' and `regrettable', and `which would have benefited schools of one faith background largely at the expense of another'—but we see it in the approach to the legislation we are debating today.

The reality is that, for a whole host of reasons, some GPs will not bulk-bill all of their patients all of the time. In fact, some patients would resent it if they did. Doctors and patients understand this, but the modern Australian Labor Party does not. Then the Labor Party goes to an election with a policy that penalises patients who are not bulk-billed. The government's views on this are broadly similar to those espoused by the creative architect of Medicare, Neal Blewett, when he said of bulk-billing that government `has not the power to compel them to do so nor does it desire to compel them to do so'.

For a political party that arrogantly prides itself on being the true arbiter of good health policy, the Labor Party's announcements on health during this election period were a great and severe disappointment. The centrepiece announcement of the campaign for Labor—the promise to give free first-class hospital cover to over-75s—must surely rank as one of the most appalling pieces of health and social policy ever advocated by a political party in the Western world. It was unsustainable, it was irresponsible, it was eminently unachievable and it also happened to be underfunded by around $700 million, according to Treasury. Medicare Gold became `Medicare Copper' in a matter of days. Medicare Gold was a farce from the very beginning, as nonsensical a piece of public policy as heroin-injecting rooms. But what has the Labor Party done to the architect of Medicare Gold? Kept her, promoted her and held her up as a beacon of what a perfect Labor member of parliament should be, instead of relegating her to beyond the back benches for this disgraceful, irresponsible and amateurish piece of policy.

The Howard government remains proud of its achievements in the health portfolio in recent times. At a local level, as the federal member for Indi I am pleased with many of the exciting developments which improve primary health care in north-east Victoria. For instance, we have the $1.6 million announcement of a rural medical school in Wangaratta, we have a new bulk-billing clinic in Wodonga, we have the $7.50 bulk-billing incentive for our local GPs and we have the Mount Beauty medical student accommodation block, which I opened last year and which was funded by the Commonwealth. Local doctors will tell you of the success of the Bogong Regional Training Network scheme, which has grown in GP training numbers from 10 to 43 since its inception. We have the measure we debate today where, from 1 January 2005, there is an increase in the Medicare benefit from 85 per cent to 100 per cent of the schedule fee, and we also have more than 5,340 people in Indi benefiting from the Medicare safety net. It is timely to mention the Medicare safety net and to recount the comments of the member for Werriwa, who in 1995 said:

quote.para: The methodology of good health reform is to get effective public safety net provisions in place.

speech.para: This is apparently now not the case, because Labor went to the last election promising to ditch the single biggest improvement to the architecture of Medicare seen in recent history—that is, the Medicare safety net.

I also wish to comment on another feature of this bill: the assurance that all families eligible for family tax benefit part A are automatically eligible for the lower $300 threshold. This particular issue was raised with my electorate office prior to the election by a constituent who received her family tax benefit in one lump sum and, due to a drafting error in the original legislation, was not immediately recognised as being eligible for the lower safety net threshold. She is now eligible, and I am pleased this legislation has rectified this matter to enable even more of my constituents to go on receiving immediately the significant benefits that come with the Medicare safety net.

On another local initiative in my electorate related to bulk-billing, I have spoken in this place before on the success of a new bulk-billing clinic operating adjacent to the Wodonga hospital. This clinic is offering an important service to border patients and is clearly paying dividends to the Albury-Wodonga community, mainly through the initiatives contained in `Strengthening Medicare' and MedicarePlus. Minister Abbott came to this clinic in March this year and met with GPs and patients. I refer to a representation made to me by the CEO of the Wodonga Regional Health Service, where this clinic is situated. The CEO said: `I am pleased to inform you that the clinic has been successful to date, largely due to the MedicarePlus initiative'. He also notes the `significant returns to the community of Indi that arise from a clinic committed to bulk-billing under the MedicarePlus initiative'. What all this confirms is that this government is not interested in playing politics with people's health. It is interested in getting runs on the board for the benefit of patients and the Australian community.

This bill commits an extra $1.7 billion to make Medicare fairer and stronger. Few governments in the world can claim to oversee a world-class health system as Australia's government does. The Australian people like Medicare and, as the Minister for Health and Ageing has said, believe that Medicare is a fundamental part of our health system: `Medicare remains an article of faith for this government.' The measures in this bill continue the good work of the government in making our world-class health system even better and able to deal with the challenges of the changing demographics of this nation over the decades ahead. I look forward to seeing the benefits of this legislation being delivered to the people of my electorate and to the broader Australian community from 1 January 2005, and therefore I have great pleasure in commending the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —Tonight is a night for remembering. On hearing the previous speaker, the member for Indi, speak on the Health Insurance Amendment (100% Medicare Rebate and Other Measures) Bill 2004 I remembered former member for Indi Lou Lieberman. He was a nice bloke. He cared about his people and he was a good country member, with no capital city associations. He did not have the same sharp vituperativeness as the current member for Indi. He did not have that darkness in the heart making him want to cut people open on their policy approaches. As far as I know, Lou Lieberman was never on Insiders. He did not give us the 50-second member's approach to what was wrong with life and the rest of it. He was a gentle and interesting man who readily crossed the chamber and who dealt well with people, but we get no charity from the current member for Indi—either in personal or policy terms—in regard to this.

speech.para: I think that the fundamental difference is that, if you are in opposition, with the intention to come to government again, you have on your shoulders the fact that the measures you propose have to be weighed up with what you would do if you came to government and took on the great responsibility of providing services for the Australian people. If you are in government, you have to be willing to take a bit of stick in the reactions from people who do not like everything you do. You have to be willing to take responsibility for those government measures which will be accepted by some but may injure others.

In terms of the bill and the way in which the member for Indi just dealt with it, I was at a bit of a loss. I had done a bit of preparation for this bill—not as much as I had hoped. I had just come from the Main Committee, where I had to shorten my time speaking on vocational education, and I walked in and thought I was going to deal with a different bill altogether, because we got a lot of vituperativeness. The opposition and the Leader of the Opposition got an unmeasured attack, but we did not get much sense of what this bill is about. Apart from an almost reflex approach, saying that whatever the Minister for Health and Ageing or the government was doing was right, we did not get much real understanding of the implications of the bill or—judging from past experience in Indi, having been there on a task force—much close association from the member with her electorate. She is a blow-in from Melbourne. I do not think she really yet has the beat of country Victoria or country Australia and the importance of Medicare and bulk-billing. Whether she realises it or not, she comes from an electorate that has one of the lowest levels of bulk-billing in Australia.

These measures brought forward by the member for Warringah as the minister for health attempt some kind of stopgap. They were put in, firstly, to cover the fact that the government had significant problems with Labor's approach to bulk-billing as a significant problem in Medicare delivery and, secondly, because of the bulk-billing statistics. If you look at the stats, you see the level of bulk-billing when we were in government going up almost exponentially and—guess what—the level of bulk-billing when we lost government in 1996 sliding its way down the other side of the isosceles triangle as fast as you can imagine.

Australians are not dummies. They know whether services are or are not being provided, they know when things slip away and they know when the government has pulled a swiftie. The minister for health has put forward a number of things in a belated attempt to try to catch up with Labor's approach and arguments with regard to the fundamental problem of bulk-billing. He has put some provisions forward that a number of people in the community will readily accept. Not just the members on his back bench but people generally will see that some comfort will come from those. In particular, the provision that he has put forward and argued for for people who have to go to specialists and could not otherwise cover their out-of-pocket expenses has won reasonable support within sectors of the community.

What this bill is fundamentally about, giving extra money in terms of the Medicare rebate, is the minister for health's attempt to cover the key problem that has existed for the last 12 months plus. I wish happy birthday to the member for Kooyong, who has just joined us in the House. He is a good friend and a great member for his area. The member for Warringah has attempted to provide another way to help solve the health riddle that Australia faces. He has chosen to say within this bill: `We've got a significant problem in terms of Australia's doctors. The GPs have said to us in waging a campaign for more than a year that they're not happy with the rebate that they get.'

Labor had one response; the minister has come up with another. Medical practitioners in Australia have argued that bulk-billing rates have gone down primarily because there has not been any movement in their base remuneration. They have not got the increases in salary that other sectors of the community have. They are dependent for their income, whether they bulk-bill or charge privately, on what they get back from the government in the first instance. They have argued that the costs of their medical practices in line with the cost of other private businesses from one end of Australia to the other have risen inexorably, in good part—and they have argued this pretty vigorously—because of the cost imposed by this government. Remember the GST. Remember the quarterly returns that have to be put in and the accounting costs associated with that. Because they are providers of services, where there is a provision from the government as a rebate to them—bulk-billing or not—they have to wear a lot of those increased costs and they have not been able, according to what they have argued, to find an adequate way to get recompense.

The solution for the GPs is, in part, to argue for an increase in the Medicare rebate. This government has delivered to them an increase in the rebate from 85 per cent to 100 per cent, and this goes a reasonable way to assuage the demands and the fears of those GPs. But they pointed out, even when it was first promulgated—certainly it has not been legislated yet; this is the first part of that process—that, first, it is a step forward but it is not enough; second, they need a more genuine agreement with the government because they want to continue to provide their services and run their practices in a reasonable way; and, third, if the government had done not only this but also had met them and done a real deal in terms of recognising their actual costs and what the government has imposed by that, the government would be even more generous. For them, it is not just about increasing the base rate from 85 per cent to 100 per cent. They argue that the base rate is fundamentally deficient.

Further to that, in terms of the cost pressures that are faced by GPs, you have got another anomaly arising. It is only nascent at the moment, but an anomaly will arise because the government have said: `We will do two kinds of payment. It is 100 per cent if you are bulk-billing, and we will give you 100 per cent no matter which GP you go to see.' I well remember during the election campaign that the Prime Minister argued, hand on his heart, that this was a great boon for the Australian population, because no matter whether a person is bulk-billed or not, they could have access to their doctor, the doctor would get a 100 per cent rebate, and that would fundamentally assist the doctor and the patients would be better off.

Interestingly, the cost of this measure, at $1.7 billion in the initial year—and the technical advisers can bear this out—is exactly the same as the cost of the private health insurance rebate. The cost of the 30 per cent private health rebate, in its initial year of operation, was $1.7 billion. The government have argued that they are doing the right thing by GPs. They do not expect a cost blow-out in relation to this and they do not expect patients to have to carry more of the burden, but I would look at some recent history and ask a simple question: if it is the same amount to start off with, given that there has been inflation over the period since it was introduced—although we are in a low-inflation period and you would not expect it to be so great—what is the cost of the private health insurance rebate now? The advisers would be able to tell us, and the parliamentary secretary and the minister would be able to tell us what the cost of the rebate is now. From memory, it has more than doubled. It is over $3 billion now, isn't it? Or I may not have caught up with it in the last year or so, when it may have been on its way to doubling again. The private health rebate has increased exponentially in terms of cost to the government. What do you think is going to happen with this $1.7 billion in terms of cost to the government and, more importantly, in terms of cost to the community?

Part of the problem is the differential that is embedded in this legislation. Say you walk into a bulk-billing doctor—and there are not many of them around the joint. You go from 85 per cent to 100 per cent rebate. Those characters should be happy. I am from the electorate of Blaxland, in the city of Bankstown, in the middle of Sydney. My electorate had a 97 per cent bulk-billing rate, and it has now plummeted to about 95 per cent. One could ask: what have I got to complain about? It is a very high rate, and the surrounding electorates have the same thing. But if you go outside of the area, if you go the electorate of Lowe, which is right next door—for example, you go to a doctor in Drummoyne—you will find that you are up against a bulk-billing doctor. This proposal says it provides 100 per cent rebate of the basic fee to that bulk-billing doctor, cross their hearts and hope to die. We hope they do not increase the charges over and above what you would expect to get. The doctors say, and they were saying it for more than a year before the election: it is not enough money.

What is the doctors' response to this proposal? Their response is to increase their fees. They have done what the private health insurance industry has done with the 30 per cent rebate: `Thank you very much, let's pull in the fish.' The government has provided this incentive. The government has, seemingly for electoral purposes, forgotten the fact that economics works in the real world. If you provide an incentive to a private provider that you are going to undergird, in terms of private health funds, 30 per cent of the cost of those funds, they promise—cross their hearts and hope to die. It was the government that did that, not the health funds. When the government said that they would be stopping those increases in prices, it did not actually happen. And guess what? What has happened as a result of the government promulgating that these measures would come into force in their parliament? Almost immediately, the private doctors have said, `Thank you very much, it is not enough and our price is going up.' So there might be 100 per cent of the basic rebate, but that increase from 85 per cent to 100 per cent has been incorporated in the increase in the cost to the person walking through the doctor's door. There is no fundamental solution to the problems in terms of doctors' remuneration. They get part of what they want, but they are taking the other part directly out of the electorate.

Although the member for Indi and other members on the government side have said that this is their key solution to the perceived problems with Medicare, although this government will argue that having a rebate of the core amount to go back to doctors from 85 per cent to 100 per cent is a fundamental solution, it is a way station for the doctors and it still allows them to exercise their own economic muscle—not just with the government, where they do not think they have exercised enough, but out in the broader community. They take this as effectively a supplement that should have been provided earlier and a supplement that does not really cover the demands that they have made.

If you take this further, in terms of what we have heard this week and in past weeks from the Treasurer, from the Minister for Health and Ageing, and from others about the Intergenerational Report and problems associated with the fact that the community is ageing, the graph works its way up very exponentially. Not now, but in the next decade, and the decade after that.

talk.start.para: —Medicare Gold!

—Poor simple souls; they just want to interject and have a go at what Labor has put forward as a policy that rationalises health costs in the private area. Be that as it may, we have a critical problem here. For my sins, I am a 1951 baby boomer. Mr Deputy Speaker Baldwin, like you and others, I am part of the baby boomer generation. We will be in the simple situation where the number of aged people in the population will double from 12½ per cent to 25 per cent of the population.

—The Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads may be younger than that. Be that as it may, whether he is a baby boomer or not, whether he is joining me or not, those of my generation and I take full responsibility for the fact that our share of the total community will increase, the health care costs of the total community will increase, reliance upon Medicare will increase and people on reduced incomes—because incomes will always be less than the baby boomers will want—will also face the situation where they will make a determination about going to the doctor: is the 100 per cent rebate enough or will their cost inexorably increase?

speech.para: I do not think this is going to do the job. I think it is patchwork. I can understand why it has been put together: the government has done whatever it took to get reelected. I can understand that, in order to get back into office, it spent in the order of $21 billion in May 2001 plus what it spent in the election. I can understand that, despite the fact that we have low inflation, in just three years the government spent triple what they spent in 2001 of the constituents' money—the money of the people of Australia—in order to get back. I can understand that that worked.

But the short-term improvement of the government's position is to the longterm detriment of the Australian people. It depends how you take it. On budget day there was the $66 billion or the $61 billion of expenditure, variously categorised as $37 billion or $50 billion, and in one single day of the election campaign there was the $6 billion worth of promises. It is staggering stuff. The drunken sailor stuff really resonates regarding the amount the government promised in order to snatch back office. It was very successful. It got an increase of 1.8 per cent in its national vote. It got an increase in the number of members in this place. But the price to be paid will be paid by the people of Australia. Across a whole series of portfolios, across a whole series of programs, it will be taken out of the hide of the Australian people.

This is the government's vainglorious attempt to match Labor. It is their attempt to say, `Labor is not really the party of Medicare'—despite the fact that Labor started Medibank; despite the fact that the Fraser government year after year, over seven full years, gutted Medibank and sought to stab it in the stomach, as the Prime Minister wished to do with Medicare. The coalition, in that wonderful inversion which is so much a part of their approach to things, are now the great defenders of the status quo; they are now the great defenders supposedly of Medicare.

Unfortunately, I have to tell Australia's doctors and the people of Australia who line up either in Blaxland, Lowe, Kooyong or Indi that this is not the full story. This little package is about covering the coalition's derriere in regard to health policy. It is about dealing with an antagonistic interest group, the Australian Medical Association, and attempting to assuage not only their fears but also their demand for an increase effectively in their wages. It will only go part way to solving the government's problem; it is not a full attempt at all to deal with the underlying realities in terms either of the doctors or of service provision for the whole of Australia. The fundamental provision in this legislation is the 100 per cent Medicare rebate. One hundred per cent sounds good, unless you are a GP practising in Australia and arguing that it is not enough. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —To come into this House to speak on legislation like this bill is a great opportunity. Many times when you come into the House to speak on legislation you might not have great news and great history to help put forward a very convincing debate, but health is one area that this government has excelled in. I am very proud to walk into this House many times and espouse the virtues of this government and its provision of additional health services. Let me set the scene. I do not want to be accused of not being relevant by the member for Blaxland, so I want to start off by setting the scene by providing the history of benefits that this government has provided over the past eight years. These benefits have worked to correct and improve Australia's health system and to maintain our world-class services. It might not be recognised on the opposite side of the House that we do have world-class health services, but I absolutely confirm for the member for Blaxland that we have world-class health services, believe you me, and this government has played a very big part in ensuring that we continue to have world-class services and that we continue to have them in rural and regional Australia.

speech.para: We have worked to increase the number of doctors training and practising outside metropolitan areas. We have established rural clinical schools, one of which I am very proud to host in my electorate of Riverina: the University of New South Wales School of Rural Health. It has gone a long way to ensuring that those young students who are doing their degree will look to return to rural and regional practice in establishing their craft of medicine. We have made private health insurance more affordable and accessible, thereby reducing the strain on the public health system. We have introduced the successful after-hours clinic program; it has been very successful in my electorate of Riverina. It has established clinics throughout Australia including, as I have said, in the Riverina, with the Riverina Division of General Practice as an excellent example of a successful after-hours medical clinic. This after-hours clinic operates from rooms in Calvary Hospital. The clinic provides valuable and much needed medical services to people throughout Wagga Wagga and the surrounding area. It is serviced by a majority of local doctors, who work on a roster system to ensure that this clinic is staffed after hours during the week and on weekends and public holidays, thus reducing the load on the terribly stressed state hospital system.

What we have is an ineffective New South Wales Labor government which has stressed the hospital system to the maximum, and this Howard-Anderson federal coalition government has put in place with the various ministers an opportunity for people to be able to action other health services beyond those public health services that we see so often espoused by the opposite side of the room. We have achieved many great things in the area of health. We are committed to continuing those improvements to our health system and ensuring access for all Australians. Since I was elected as the member for Riverina in 1998 more than $36 million in federal government funding has been delivered into my region in the area of health alone. This funding has gone into many different areas of health, including $1.2 million to establish a rural obstetrics training network in the Riverina and Murray region.

That is something that we need to be critically concerned with. We were faced with the prospect of mums having to be flown to Sydney for perfectly normal deliveries, and we were faced with the shutdown of all private obstetric services. But this government under the Minister for Health and Ageing, Tony Abbott, combined with myself of course—I had a bit of an input into this—determined that we would establish a rural obstetrics training network. Now we are up and running, contracts are signed, and we have some very good people on the job, including Dr Ian Stewart, a gynaecologist and obstetrician who, for a number of years now, has been operating in this area and understands how we are going to provide obstetric services in rural and regional areas into the future. This project is a fantastic pilot. It can be picked up and put anywhere in Australia to ensure services will be maintained for rural women who want to have their children in their communities. We also have $820,000 for supplying specialist medical services to towns in the Riverina and we had $13.7 million to set up a rural clinical school at Wagga Wagga to address the shortage of medical practitioners, and it has just been funded again for the next four years.

In my electorate of Riverina one of the greatest concerns in health is access to a doctor, not access to bulk-billing. The communities throughout my region and beyond struggle to attract doctors, particularly ones who are willing to establish a permanent practice. One small community in my electorate had 22 locums in 18 months. Their issue certainly was not: `Am I going to be bulk-billed?' Their issue was: `Am I going to have a doctor?' We have resolved that issue for them. This government has provided a secure service in most of the towns throughout my electorate.

Some of the initiatives that I have announced in the past have been significant in the way in which we have looked at health in a different capacity since this government put in place the health measures that were going to address many of the shortfalls that came about through 13 years of Labor rule. The Nationals have worked in coalition with the health minister to increase the number of general practitioners in rural and regional Australia and to encourage students to explore the options of practising outside the cities. I recall when John Anderson and former Minister Michael Wooldridge went out and had a look at the way in which services were declining in rural and regional Australia, had a look at the significant issues that confronted rural residents when they were seeking health services and then decided on a plan that would take us forward. We need to be eternally grateful to those two members of parliament for looking outside the square and determining that they could in fact put in place many great initiatives that would see these things resolved. They do not get resolved overnight, they take some years, but it is a beginning. The journey of a thousand steps begins with just one, and this government took the first step. We are very proud of that.

As a result of these policies over 25 per cent of Australia's medical students now come from rural areas. That is something we did not have when the coalition came into government. We did not have a quota of students who were able to come from rural areas to study medicine. Medicine needed a 99.9 per cent TER or UAI, and rural students were not able to feature very highly in that area. Now they can have 85 per cent and we can do an assessment and deliver rural students into medical courses before delivering them right back to rural Australia where they came from. That was an initiative that came from this coalition government. Doctors are much more likely to return to practise in rural and regional Australia if they have come from the bowels of our areas.

The Rural Australian Medical Undergraduate Scholarship Scheme provides $10,000 each year to undergraduate medical students from rural and regional backgrounds. There were only 100 medical students from rural areas in 1996 when this government came into power. Now we have 500 medical students receiving those RAMUS scholarships alone. That is a very significant input by any government. In addition, the Medical Rural Bonded Scholarship Scheme provides over $20,000 a year to students during their medical degree. In return, these students agree to work for six years in a rural or remote area. I think that is very credible and laudable. It is a great program that gives students an opportunity, and these places are on top of general places. It is not conscription. These kids are signing up. They know what they are doing, and they want to have the opportunity to work in rural and regional Australia.

These two schemes alone build on our other policies that will increase the number of these doctors. These policies include specialist retention payments, extra funding to support rural GPs who perform minor operations and obstetrics, and attracting more overseas trained doctors to areas where there is a shortage of doctors and communities are unable to get an Australian trained doctor. As I said, training doctors does not happen overnight. It is a process that takes many years. But we will continue to build on these existing policies, and we will continue to attract general practitioners into rural medicine. So all of these initiatives have delivered benefits—but then we come in and say, as Tim Shaw did, `Wait, there's more.'

The decision by this government to raise the Medicare benefit from 85 per cent to 100 per cent of the schedule fee has been welcomed in my electorate because it means an increase of $4.60 in the Medicare rebate for a standard surgery consultation. This increase in the rebate applies to consultations in doctors' surgeries, after hours, at home and in aged care facility visits. It is a tremendous initiative that the minister has put to the House. I listened to the member for Blaxland and I really did not much like the Labor Party's alternative to our Medicare rebate policy, which was to offer 100 per cent of the schedule fee of bulk-billed consultations only. If you are in an area where, as the member for Blaxland has just indicated, he has approximately 95 per cent of doctors bulk-billing, that is great. We have Labor areas propped up with mass city areas that can get bulk-billing at 95 per cent.

In my electorate of Riverina, and many other rural areas right across Australia, bulk-billing has traditionally been nonexistent. We would not have received any benefit out of the Labor policy at all. I ask the Labor Party: how would this have benefited people in the electorate of Riverina where general practitioners simply do not bulk-bill? I find it hard to comprehend why the opposition would seek to create a policy that neglected to consider the consequences for those who are unable to access bulk-billing. The situation is better now than it was when the opposition were in power for 13 years. We have traditionally had no bulk-billing in my electorate.

We all want to have an opportunity to spread some good health news. In order to give my colleagues an opportunity to be able to spread their good message, their good humoured news, I suggest that we all accept that this is an exciting initiative. It is part of a suite of the many exciting initiatives that have been administered in this House by this coalition government.

talk.start.para: —I wish to support the comments of the honourable member for Riverina on the Health Insurance Amendment (100% Medicare Rebate and Other Measures) Bill 2004. Medicare has been one of the cornerstones of the Australian public health system since it was introduced by Gough Whitlam almost 30 years ago. I take the honourable member for Blaxland's point: I do not think there is much point in beating around the bush and pretending that the coalition has always been unequivocally committed to Medibank or to Medicare as it now is. That is not the case. Many of us recollect the constant changes made to Medibank under the Fraser government—indeed some of us participated in them. There were our successive promises in the 13 years of opposition to fundamentally change the basic components of Medicare once it was reinstalled by the Hawke government.

speech.para: The fact is, however, that, whatever the Labor Party says, this all changed with the demise of Fightback and when John Howard as Leader of the Opposition gave an unequivocal commitment that the coalition would fully retain the Medicare system. I believe this commitment has been honoured and indeed exceeded. One of the Howard government's great success stories has been its reinforcement of Medicare. It may have taken some ideological revolutions to get there, but once the commitment was made it was kept. The government has worked to secure the long-term viability of Medicare to ensure that all Australians have improved access to the multitude of medical services available to the community and to keep our medical system affordable for those who need to access it.

The Strengthening Medicare policy was an important step towards meeting these objectives. It is worth reflecting on some of its key components. Some 60 per cent of GP consultations in Australia involve medical services delivered to children under the age of 16 years and to concession card holders—pension, health care and Commonwealth seniors card holders. The government determined that when a bulk-billing GP treated these patients the payment to the doctor would be increased by $5, and further increased to $7.50 if the doctor were located in remote or rural areas which included all of Tasmania. These amounts have increased to $5.10 and $7.65 respectively as a result of indexation from 1 November of this year.

Before we turn our attention to the next step in this process—the 100 per cent Medicare policy that is the subject of this bill—it is worth while noting the success of the earlier bulk-billing initiative. The national bulk-billing rate at the end of the September 2004 quarter was 71.8 per cent. Since the Strengthening Medicare package was announced earlier this year it has risen by 5.3 percentage points, or eight per cent in relative terms. The national bulk-billing rate for Australians aged 65 years or older is even higher, with 82.1 per cent of all medical consultations in that category now being bulk-billed. In sum, in all states and territories the rate of bulk-billing continues to increase even before the introduction of 100 per cent Medicare in January 2005.

The 100 per cent Medicare will deliver additional benefits to GPs. It will make medical consultations even more affordable for patients. In our health system, medical benefits are based on a fee determined for each medical service, which is the `schedule fee'. Until now the medical benefit paid for a GP consultation has been set at 85 per cent of the schedule fee. That percentage applies to all out-of-hospital medical benefits. From 1 January 2005 the MBS will pay a 100 per cent rebate for schedule fees for all GP visits in lieu of the 85 per cent figure that applied historically. In dollar terms this change means an additional payment of $2.10 for a short consultation, $4.60 for a normal consultation and up to $12.90 for extended consultations in excess of 40 minutes in duration. For a standard 15-minute consultation in a GP's surgery, the new Medicare rebate will be $30.85.

Importantly, this very substantial increase in payments for a GP consultation will apply to all consultations. It does not matter whether or not the doctor bulk-bills the patient for a medical consultation. That is a very important point of distinction, both philosophically and in policy terms, between the government and Labor. The Labor alternative announced during the election campaign was to increase the rebate for GP consultations to 100 per cent of the schedule fee, but only in circumstances where the consultation was bulk-billed. The government is committed to the independence of the doctor-patient relationship. Under this policy the choice of whether or not to bulk-bill would remain with the doctor.

The increase in the rebate to 100 per cent of the schedule fee will apply to all medical consultations regardless of whether or not the doctor elects to bulk-bill the patient. If the doctor does bulk-bill, the doctor will receive the additional payment of $4.60. If the consultation is not bulk-billed, the patient will derive the benefit of the additional money to reduce the out-of-pocket costs. This is a policy position that allows doctors and patients to concentrate on the essential task of providing and receiving quality health care, knowing that minimal costs will be incurred by the patient. The higher rebate for medical consultations will apply to consultations delivered in a doctor's surgery, at the patient's home or in a residential aged care facility, and even to hospital consultations involving non-admitted patients.

It should be noted—and this is important—that this decision to increase the rebate to 100 per cent of the schedule fee in no way impacts on or detracts from other bulk-billing initiatives and incentives that I outlined earlier. The Howard government's $5 and $7.50 bulk-billing incentives, introduced as part of the Strengthening Medicare package, will continue to be paid over and above the base schedule fees. In a similar vein, entitlements under the Practice Incentives Program will not be impacted on by the 100 per cent Medicare initiative. As was pointed out, the 100 per cent Medicare initiative will cost $1.8 billion over four years. This is a commitment that can be made and a benefit that can be passed on to all Australians because this government has delivered such strong economic growth and prosperity over a substantial period. It is a policy that will ensure that Australians have better access to medical services and that those services are more affordable.

There are a number of other initiatives involved in the government's commitment to Strengthening Medicare, including Round the Clock Medicare, which funds a diversity of after-hours medical centres. One of the key elements of Round the Clock Medicare is its flexibility and its capacity to respond to different circumstances and environments. Labor's alternative, Medicare After Hours, relies on just one model—GP clinics co-located with public hospitals. This is a one-size-fits-all model that is characteristic of Labor and does not optimally serve the provision of better health care in the community. On some occasions, hospital co-located after-hours clinics will be an appropriate solution, but often community needs can be better met by different solutions: clinics in the community, perhaps located close to public hospitals; private hospitals themselves; or dedicated freestanding practices.

The bill also rectifies a drafting error in the initial legislation that established the safety net. Australians incur a range of costs for medical services that extend beyond a GP visit: specialist consultations, pathology and an ever-increasing array of radiology tests. Anyone who has experienced the costs associated with a serious accident or a complex long-term illness will know only too well how medical costs can quickly accumulate. The safety net is another example of the government acting speedily to provide assistance for Australians in these circumstances.

This bill ensures that eligibility for the safety net at the $300 threshold will be confirmed for all families that are eligible for family tax benefit part A payments. A drafting error in the original bill meant that families who deferred their family tax benefit payments might have missed out on safety net eligibility at the lower threshold. This bill confirms their eligibility and gives the minister the power to determine that a registered family is an FTB A family for the purpose of the safety net $300 medical out-of-pocket cost threshold.
