As I said at the outset of my speech, after some vicissitudes in its attitudes towards Medicare the coalition has demonstrated an unequivocal commitment to Medicare and to ensuring that all Australians have improved access to affordable medical services. Strengthening Medicare and Round the Clock Medicare were important parts of that process; so too is the subject of the bill now before the House—100 per cent Medicare. The government can be rightly proud of its achievements across a broad spectrum of policies and programs, and health is one of these. This bill continues the government's commitment to providing all Australians with better access to, and more affordable, medical services. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Health Insurance Amendment (100% Medicare Rebate and Other Measures) Bill 2004. During the recent election campaign, the Leader of the Opposition made it very clear that the 9 October election was going to be a referendum on Medicare. I would have to say that, when the people voted, they were fully aware that it is, in fact, the coalition that is one of the greatest supporters of Medicare. They recognised the fact that it is the coalition that has done so much to ensure the affordability of and access to medical services for Australians. And they were sure that it was the Liberal-National coalition that was going to keep the economy strong so that this government could spend the necessary funds to provide appropriate medical services for the people of Australia.

speech.para: This government has always been focused on providing the very best services under Medicare. The Medicare Plus program provided for some $2.4 billion to be invested in ensuring the very best in medical care for Australians. The government provided measures such as the $7.50 payment in my electorate to provide an incentive for GPs to bulk-bill children under the age of 16 and health care card holders. Under Medicare Plus there was additional support for practice nurses to ensure that our GPs get the support they need to provide the very best in medical services. There were additional places to train more GPs. More graduate doctors were being funded. This government has been totally focused on ensuring that the medical service needs of this country are adequately met. We also introduced the comprehensive Medicare safety net to ensure that the government bore a substantial proportion of people's health costs once their expenditure reached a certain threshold. I will talk a little more on that later.

This government has also provided for the rural health initiative, providing substantial investment—some $562 million in the 2000 budget—to ensure that people in regional and rural areas had adequate access to health care services and to ensure that our GPs working in those isolated areas were adequately supported so that they could provide the services that people need. In my electorate, we have a branch of the rural clinical school, a highly successful initiative aimed at training doctors in regional and rural areas on the basis that, when they conclude their training, they are more likely to stay in those regional and rural areas. I have talked to some of the students and they have certainly indicated their intention that, when their training is done, they would like to practise in those areas. This government is highly aware that the shortage of GPs and the work force issues are major impediments to providing services in our more isolated areas and in regional areas.

What was Labor's response to the health care needs of this nation? Quite remarkably, they came up with an unaffordable concept called Medicare Gold—offering a pot of gold at the end of the health care rainbow. On 9 October, the people totally rejected Medicare Gold. The people of Australia knew that it could not be provided. The people of Australia knew that the services as promised would not be delivered. The people of Australia knew that, for the provision of health care, it was inappropriate to discriminate purely on the basis of chronological age. I am pleased to see that the people of Australia supported this government on 9 October and supported the fact that this government supports Medicare.

Part of the package that this government put forward is the subject of this bill we are debating today—increasing the Medicare rebate from 85 per cent to 100 per cent of the schedule fee for GP services. Through this measure, the government is investing more than $1.7 billion over four years to make GP services more affordable for all Australians. The passage of this bill will be a real test for the opposition. They have been very much a party of obstruction, a party keen to work not towards the best interests of Australia but towards obstructing those measures which this government wants to put forward for the improvement of this country.

Under this bill patients will benefit substantially. They will benefit substantially because the fees payable to a GP will rise from $26.25 to $30.85—an increase of some $4.60. But this measure does not just benefit those patients who are attending a doctor who bulk-bills. Through a higher rebate, the legislation provides an increased incentive for doctors to bulk-bill but, for those doctors who do not bulk-bill, the patient will be required to pay a smaller gap because the amount reimbursed by the government is increased.

The second measure under this bill relates to eligibility for the Medicare safety net. The extended Medicare safety net covers 80 per cent of out-of-pocket costs for medical services provided outside hospital once the annual threshold is met. The government wants to ensure that all families who are eligible for FTB part A are eligible for the extended safety net at the lower $300 threshold. This amendment will allow FTB A family groups, such as families who elect to defer all of their FTB A fortnightly instalment payments or families who do not receive any FTB A because of an obligation to repay a debt to the Commonwealth, to fall within the definition of the FTB A family for the purposes of the safety net. This amendment will allow the Minister for Health and Ageing to determine that additional families such as these are FTB A families who are eligible for the lower safety net threshold even though they are not in receipt of an instalment or lump sum payment.

The Minister for Health and Ageing is absolutely committed to Medicare. He has worked very hard to address the issues of work force shortage. He has worked very hard to ensure that Medicare is meeting the needs of Australians. In contrast, Labor put forward Medicare Gold—a strategy that was undeliverable and unaffordable. It was pie in the sky. Labor, as I said, wanted to discriminate against patients who were under a particular chronological age. Labor's strategies were focused on bulk-billing doctors; therefore they discriminated against those patients who attended surgeries where there was no bulk-billing, where the doctors chose not to bulk-bill particular patients. It was of great concern to me when, in the election campaign, the Leader of the Opposition admitted that he did not believe in a safety net; that Labor did not believe in a safety net; that Labor did not believe that those who were the sickest in the community, those who were the most needy because they had the highest levels of medical expenditure, were entitled to the protection that this safety net provided.

During the election campaign I was walking through a shopping centre at Toormina Gardens and an elderly couple came up to me. They were absolutely terrified that the opposition was going to take away the safety net. They were a couple who were not enjoying the best of health. They were a couple who were on a limited income and they were depending on the Medicare safety net to ensure their access to medical services and to ensure that they were able to afford the necessary out-of-pocket expenses that would be incurred due to the fact that they were both quite ill. The words of the opposition leader were absolutely frightening them. It is of great concern to me that many people in my electorate were very worried by the prospect that the safety net would be taken away. In fact, in the electorate of Cowper, some 5,000 people benefited from the Medicare safety net—5,000 people who would have had their benefits rejected if, on 9 October, the people of Australia had elected a Labor government.

As I have said before, this government has been absolutely focused on the need to strengthen Medicare. The Labor Party have been focused on the fact that they do not support a safety net and that they do not support the very good measures that this government has introduced. This government is focused on the fact that the bulk-billing statistic is not the be-all and end-all of proper medical services. A particular number, the bulk-billing percentage, is not the measure of affordability of and access to medical services around the country. The bulk-billing percentage is not a measure of whether people in isolated areas have access to appropriate medical services.

This government has put in place the sorts of measures that have strengthened Medicare. This government has put in place the sorts of measures that have provided improved medical outcomes for people in isolated areas, in regional areas and in rural areas. This government has given GPs the support they need to provide the medical services for those people. This government has given GPs an added incentive to bulk-bill, as I have said, children under the age of 16 and health care card holders. This government has proven to be a friend of Medicare. The people of Australia recognised that on 9 October. I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 9.00 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Honourable members will be well aware of my longstanding campaign in this House concerning the Howard government's agenda to further concentrate the ownership of traditional media in Australia, and the serious implications this holds for the public interest and for our precious democracy. We need to remain vigilant on this issue, particularly as the government will soon be able to ram through the Senate legislation that will water down one of the few remaining checks against further concentration of media ownership in Australia.

speech.para: Having just two major newspaper companies in our country is bad enough. If honourable members want an example of how this lowers standards, I refer them to two recent editions of the Australian newspaper. Last Saturday the paper carried a story by Christine Jackman and Cameron Stewart, entitled `Losing it', which purported to be a `definitive account' of how Mark Latham lost the 2004 federal election. It opened with a claim that during the federal election the Leader of the Opposition cancelled a barbecue for families that was planned for the seat of Parramatta and went elsewhere that day to make an announcement. The first point I make to the House tonight is that this claim is false. Further, I have spoken with a number of people from my electorate who attended the barbecue and who spoke with Mr Latham.

Today's edition of the Australian carries a letter of response from Mr Latham's office. This letter also proves the claim to be wrong on at least seven grounds: (1) the Leader of the Opposition attended the function as planned; (2) he was greeted by more than 200 guests; (3) he spoke to the crowd for more than 15 minutes about Labor's plan to ease the squeeze on families; (4) the Leader of the Opposition made his announcement there, and not elsewhere as claimed in the story; (5) more than 20 journalists attended the function; (6) radio news bulletins that day, and television news bulletins that night, carried coverage of Mr Latham being there; and (7) the Sun-Herald carried a report on the following day that said the announcement was `unveiled at a community barbecue at Wentworthville in the marginal Coalition-held seat of Parramatta'.

In other words, a simple check of the public record would have prevented the mistake made by the journalists involved in last Saturday's article. And yet, operating in complete denial, the Australian today carries an editor's note still insisting that Mr Latham ditched the plan and failed to participate as scheduled. When a newspaper, presented with clear and publicly available evidence, cannot acknowledge that it has made a mistake, it demonstrates arrogance and a cavalier attitude to the need to uphold the basic standards of journalism. An even more remarkable demonstration of the quality of journalism involved in last Saturday's article is the fact that the Australian's editor-in-chief contacted at least one person—that I am aware of—asking them to speak with Ms Jackman.

So I ask the House tonight: do editors now act as booking agents? If Ms Jackman cannot secure interviews on her own, and produces slaphappy journalism that is riddled with errors and light on facts, how does she hold down her job? What on earth is going on at the Australian? One thing is certain: further concentration of media ownership will not help. Australians deserve to have a wider choice and broader competition. That is in the public interest, and it is good for our democracy.

talk.start.para: —It is good news week, and today is good news day for me. Tonight I have much pleasure in indicating to the House that we have finally resolved the issue of Regional Express airlines and the problem of their relocation from gate 39 at terminal 2 of Sydney airport. What we have today is a great agreement and a wonderful outcome for a running issue we have all been very concerned about. We have a new Regional Express gate lounge, we have a new Regional Express lounge facility, and Regional Express will stay at gate 39 until the building improvements are completed at their new lounge at gate 47. The chairman of Regional Express, Lim Kim Hi, and the co-chairman, Lee Thian Soo, welcome this great news, because it has been an issue for their airline.

speech.para: I congratulate Max Moore-Wilton, Rod Gilmour and the entire team at Sydney Airport Corporation Ltd for their cooperation with Regional Express for the benefit of rural communities. My good friend Geoff Bruest, Jim Davis and the great team at Regional Express have worked tirelessly on this issue to ensure that regional commuters are able to get access to quality facilities that will ensure that the gateway to rural and regional New South Wales and other areas can be upheld and sustained. I would again like to give my enormous personal thanks to John Anderson's office. They have been magnificent in their commitment to a successful resolution for Regional Express. Again and again, the Deputy Prime Minister; his chief of staff, Peter Langhorne; and his aviation adviser, Peter Marchi, rallied to ensure that regional commuters and Regional Express airlines would be provided with facilities that are befitting this growing and successful airline.

Mr Speaker, you will recall only too well that it was only two years ago that you and I had many conversations on the demise of Ansett and the demise of Kendall Airlines, which had been running in and out of our electorates. We had no airline operating right throughout regional areas. In fact, many of our areas would have had a very dire future had it not been for the commitment of the Deputy Prime Minister, John Anderson, to ensuring that we would access regional services. As a consequence, we had an enormous amount of trial and effort but everyone stayed true to the few airlines that were combined to ultimately get Regional Express into the skies. I must at this time pay tribute again to one of the former operators in Regional Express, Michael Jones, who had the tenacity, the integrity and I guess the belligerence to ensure that this airline got up and running and offering services.

I would like to congratulate the board of Regional Express for their commitment to ensuring that regional commuters have the quality, varied and continuing service that they provide. They have certainly proven themselves. They have now moved into profit after only two years of operation. Their profits are extending into the millions of dollars now and their passenger numbers are extending into the millions as well. I am very proud of this airline. This airline is based in Wagga Wagga. It employs about 120 people in Wagga Wagga. It makes a large contribution to the entire community and to the entire electorate.

It is with great pleasure and relief that I congratulate Sydney Airport Corporation, Regional Express and the Deputy Prime Minister's office for again showing true commitment to ensuring that Australians in rural and regional New South Wales have facilities that are second to none and to ensuring that they are guaranteed a service which they can be proud of and which can continue to grow into the future. Mr Speaker, thank you for allowing me the opportunity to give these congratulations in the House on the evening of a very successful negotiation between this airline, Sydney Airport Corporation and the Deputy Prime Minister's office.

subdebateinfo.title: Electorate of Blaxland: Donovan, Ms Casey

talk.start.para: —Touchdown! It is a touchdown for the Speaker because he has been elected to an august office in this House. He is a person who has served the parliament for a long period of time and someone who has been selected by his peers to fill a significant place within this parliament. It is a touchdown for a person who yesterday gave his first speech in this House, the member for Wentworth, Malcolm Turnbull. I congratulated him at the end of that speech—a significant one, I thought. The only regret I have is that he is not on our side of the House rather than the coalition side. His story is the story of a lot of Australians: people who started with virtually nothing, who worked very hard and used their abilities and talents to achieve as much as was possible for them. I salute him for what he has achieved personally in that regard and for the fact that he has chosen to use his abilities and his talents in this parliament. I simply regret that he is not one of ours but one of theirs.

speech.para: Mr Speaker, we have been friends since I came into this parliament in 1996. My knowledge of you was increased when you led a delegation of parliamentarians from both sides of the House to South America. I deeply appreciate the way in which you led that delegation. It was indicative of the fact that you will be able to operate as Speaker of this House in a bipartisan way, which will add to the reputation of the House but also to the way in which the House operates.

But it is a touchdown not only for the member for Wannon and for the member for Wentworth but, more importantly for me as the member for Bankstown, this is a touchdown for Casey Donovan, Australian idol. Bankstown properly should be renamed Caseytown as a result of what happened very recently.

talk.start.para: —Shameless.

—It is entirely shameless but entirely right. Casey Donovan is a 16-year-old kid. It is a long time ago but I can remember what it was like to be 16. I can remember what it was like to be pilloried throughout most of my life because I was not the Australian average in terms of size. I can remember what it was like to be different. I can remember what it was like to not completely fit in. But I can also remember what it was like to, despite all of that, win the acceptance of my peers in a leadership position. For me, the first instance was as captain of De La Salle College Bankstown at the age of 16. I can remember what it was like to be trusted over people who were more gifted in other areas—athletic ones and so on. They put a kid in that people would not normally have thought of.

speech.para: But what Casey Donovan has done, as a young person of 16 years of age—a person mature beyond those 16 years—under incredible pressure but using her native talent, has been to show not just Bankstown but the world as well that talent can win through. She has shown that if you accept what you have and what you have been given and you develop that and you school it and, in the best instances of education, you bring it out of yourself and you do not have a fear of simply being yourself and expressing that—as the members for Wannon and Wentworth, and others, have done in this place—you can conquer and you can do well.

Very few of the people who initially looked at it realised what an absolute phenomenon the Australian Idol program would become. I knew from the last time, when Paulini—who was also from Bankstown—came in fourth, that this was a significant social phenomenon in Australia. But I also knew that in Bankstown, Bankstown City Council, together with the state education department, put money and effort and time into TAP, the Talent Advancement Program, for all of those children in public schools in Bankstown who were willing to try to tap the best of their abilities. First time up in a national competition, Paulini came fourth. Second time up, against all of the odds, Casey Donovan beat someone who was extremely gifted, the young Mr Callea from Melbourne and the electorate of Lalor. For someone who established their naturalness and humanity, who simply expressed themselves as fully as possible and who allied that to a brilliant singing talent, Bankstown should be renamed Caseytown. For Casey Donovan and for Bankstown it is an absolute touchdown that she was able to touch the lives and the hearts of people across Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I understand that today Tamworth businessman Mr Greg Maguire released a statement in which he categorically rejected as untrue further statements made yesterday by Independent New England MP Tony Windsor under parliamentary privilege in relation to an alleged phone call between Mr Maguire and Mr Windsor, supposedly concerning the Deputy Prime Minister, John Anderson. The statement went on:

quote.para: In parliament, Mr Windsor alleged that Mr Maguire told him in a phone call a few days after 20 September 2004 that the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr John Anderson, had made a phone call to Mr Maguire. Mr Windsor alleged that the message conveyed in that call was, “Get your mate to pull back; this is bigger than all of us.”

Mr Maguire had no phone call with Mr Windsor in which he made any such statement as now alleged by Mr Windsor concerning the deputy prime minister, Mr Anderson ... Further, neither in September 2004, nor at any time, did Mr Anderson convey any such message as is now alleged by Mr Windsor to Mr Maguire.

speech.para: Mr Maguire also said that at no stage did Mr Anderson or anyone else on behalf of the government convey to Mr Maguire that funding for the Australian Equine and Livestock Centre was subject to or dependent on political strings or any other appropriate conditions. On the contrary, Mr Anderson made it abundantly clear that the funding for the centre at the federal level was dependent on the project being supported on its merits. The New South Wales state government approach on this matter was the same. I am concerned that recently we have seen the member for New England using parliamentary privilege not to promote the interests of the electorate—

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I think the honourable member for Cowper may be adversely reflecting on a member of this House. There are forms of the House in which he can prosecute such statements.
—Mr Speaker, contrary to the position put by the Chief Opposition Whip, so far in my observation and hearing the member for Cowper has done no such thing.
—I call the member for Cowper, and I am sure he is mindful of the standing orders.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. My concern is that perhaps parliamentary privilege is being used not to advance the interests of the electorate, not to advance the interests of the constituents, but for personal purposes. This to me is of great concern. I think in this House all members, despite our political differences—

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Clearly, the honourable member for Cowper wants to suggest that the actions of the honourable member for New England were motivated by personal reasons, not out of concern for his electorate or the needs of his electorate. If that is his belief, there are forms of the House which he can use to prosecute such an argument, but the adjournment is not one of them.
—I have been listening carefully to the remarks. I rule that the member is in order.

—I think that all of us as members of this House need to cultivate those relationships that will best benefit our constituents, and it is my concern that recent statements have not achieved that end—they have not advanced the interests of the people of New England.

speech.para: Today we had a number of questions on this issue, and one was about an invitation. Rather than using question time to obtain more information about issues relating to the equine centre and the furthering of that project, questions were raised about whether a particular individual was invited to a particular function. One would have to ask whether those types of questions, in the very valuable forum that is question time, are in the best interests of our country and the best interests of the people within the electorate of the member concerned. I ask: as members of parliament, how are we best placed to further the interests of our electorate? I believe it is by working cooperatively, using the forum of this House to work together and achieve real outcomes for our constituents. As members we should, despite our political differences, always be working— (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This being my first opportunity to speak in the House, can I congratulate you, Mr Speaker, on your elevation to the chair. Sharing an electorate boundary with you and also having represented part of your seat previously, I am sure that the people of Stawell, Avoca and the towns of Glenorchy, Marnoo, Navarre and fabulous Waubra will be justifiably proud of you.

speech.para: The subject of my adjournment speech tonight will be of little surprise to members of this House. This week marks the 150th anniversary of the Eureka Stockade. In 1854, anyone wishing to mine on the goldfields in Victoria was required to pay a licence fee every three months. Many miners queued up in the early days to pay the fee, expecting improvements to roads and health and education facilities. These improvements were not forthcoming. The licence fee was considered by many as unfair, as it fell upon everyone regardless of their ability to pay or the amount of gold they did or did not find.

The issue of taxation without the basic democratic right of representation led to a number of meetings of miners, where concerns were expressed about licence fees and the policing of the licence fees. The most significant of these meetings was the meeting of the Ballarat Reform League on 11 November and the `monster meeting' at Bakery Hill on 29 November 1854, where over a third of the Ballarat population gathered. The Ballarat Reform League had as part of their demands full and fair representation, manhood suffrage, no property qualifications for members of the legislative council, payment of members and short duration of parliament—things we take for granted as part of our democracy today.

The diggers then marched from Bakery Hill to the area chosen to establish the Eureka Stockade. Tensions came to a head in a pre-dawn raid on 3 December 1854, with police and soldiers joining forces. At least 16 nations were represented at Eureka, with 28 people dying and a number of others unaccounted for. A century ago, Mark Twain visited Australia and said of Eureka:

quote.para: It was a revolution—small in size; but great politically; it was a strike for liberty, a struggle for a principle, a stand against injustice and oppression. It was the Barons and John, over again; it was Hampden and Ship-Money; it was Concord and Lexington; small beginnings, all of them, but all of them great in political results, all of them epoch-making. It is another instance of a victory won by a lost battle.

speech.para: Eureka is not owned by any one political party or political cause. I am an avid student of history and its importance, and as the member for Ballarat I proudly highlight Eureka—and would do so regardless of which political party I was from. Eureka is a great national story that deserves greater national recognition. I was encouraged to see the leader of the Victorian opposition, Robert Doyle, in Ballarat alongside the Leader of the Victorian Nationals and the Premier of Victoria last Friday. The Leader of the Opposition and I were the only representatives of the federal parliament, as the Prime Minster had declined an invitation and sent no representative.

In today's Age, Gerard Henderson has written a terrific piece that argues there is a tradition in the Liberal Party supportive of the Eureka legend that deserves a hearing. He argues convincingly that the Liberal Party is missing the point of the Eureka commemorations and should be proud to claim this national story as part of the Liberal tradition, just as Labor does. I live in hope. Ballarat has put on a magnificent display this week, with events continuing until Sunday. I want to congratulate all involved. I could not have been prouder of the way in which the event is being commemorated by the local Ballarat community.

In the few remaining minutes I would like to take the opportunity to note the passing this morning of Alan `Beau' Williams at the age of 93. Beau was a great stalwart of the Ballarat labour movement. He was a boilermaker by trade, who as a teenager commenced his apprenticeship at the Ballarat railways and worked there for over 20 years. Beau earned his nickname from the hat he used to wear while splitting wood in the Enfield forest with his friends. I am told the hat resembled the hat worn in the then popular newly released film Beau Jess. He earned the nickname in his 40s and it stuck for life.

Beau served as Secretary of the Ballarat Trades and Labour Council from 1956 to 1975, a time of enormous tension within Victoria and certainly in Ballarat, at the heart of the split between the ALP and the DLP. He presided over many heated debates, splitting the chamber between the Left and the Right at the Ballarat Trades and Labour Council. The debates were particularly heated over the issue of conscription. Beau stood as a federal Labor candidate in the 1960s. I was proud to present Beau with a Centenary Medal in 2002. He was tireless in his efforts to represent working people in my district. Ballarat is a better place for you having been with us. Vale Beau Williams.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr ANDREWS
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I would like to commend to the House the memory of a great Australian, Dame Phyllis Frost, who died recently. Dame Phyllis was one of the few people in our community who became famous for the best of reasons: for taking the role of a professional beggar for thankless causes, most notably the plight of women prisoners in Victoria.

speech.para: Born into a Croydon family in 1917, Dame Phyllis lived in that community all her life. Her Presbyterian parents instilled in her and her sisters the ethos of charity to the less well off. During the Depression her parents helped to feed and clothe, in their front parlour, those unfortunately devastated from their local township. Phyllis Frost became involved in prison reform when an acquaintance was incarcerated for a minor crime in the 1940s. Shocked into action by the degrading conditions that prisoners have endured since the 19th century, she lobbied to change and improve policies towards women prisoners. She studied criminology and, in 1953, she established the Victorian Women's Prisons Council, for many years assisting women as they served sentences. She served as the chair of this organisation for some 46 years.

Phyllis Frost was also involved in around 47 mainly charitable committees and organisations, and helped raise millions of dollars for charity. In 2000 the Victorian government honoured her achievements with women prisoners by renaming the Deer Park Metropolitan Women's Correctional Centre to the Dame Phyllis Frost Centre. The centre, with its humanising design, was the apex of her policy drive and is a model for other states.

Survived by her three daughters, five grandchildren and three great-grandsons, Dame Phyllis Frost was tireless, obstinate, frank, mischievous and a real achiever with real legacies. She was, in short, a great Australian. Many here would remember her daughter, Pauline Osmond, who served previous Speakers of the House of Representatives with great professionalism. Our thoughts are especially with her daughter, Pauline, tonight.
Question agreed to.

debateinfo.title: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 17 November, on motion by Mr Hardgrave:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Howard government has well and truly failed the skills test. The Howard government's inaction has seen a severe skills shortage develop on its watch, which is hurting Australian business, families and our economy. Skills, as a driver of productivity, have dropped a staggering 75 per cent over the last 10 years, a shocking record from this government. We now have severe skills shortages in key trades and industries—engineers, electricians, mechanics, bricklayers, plumbers and metal fitters—and in the service industries, especially child care and aged care. The Productivity Commission has found that Australia needs more skilled workers and more skills growth to address skills shortages, improve living standards and remain internationally competitive, yet tens of thousands of Australians are turned away from TAFE each year because this government will not fund enough TAFE places.

speech.para: Most of the growth in the New Apprenticeships scheme over the last few years has happened in areas where there are no skills shortages. One study has found that between 20 and 30 per cent of new apprentices receive inadequate training, and about half the people who do not finish their new apprenticeships say it is because they feel they are being used as cheap labour instead of being trained. The Australian Industry Group has found that, across the manufacturing sector—right now, not in four years time—there are between 18,000 and 21,000 unfilled vacancies for tradespeople. What is more, according to the Australian Industry Group the number of traditional apprenticeships has remained largely unchanged since this government came into office in 1996.

Just last week there was more bad news. According to the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations skilled vacancy index, vacancies for skilled tradespersons have increased by a staggering 54 per cent over the last three years. The figures reveal sharply rising demand for skilled workers in the key areas of metal trades, automotive, electrical and construction industries. Other figures last week confirmed that the Howard government is doing little to address this demand. According to the latest figures from the National Centre for Vocational Education and Research, there has been a massive 22 per cent drop in the share of apprenticeships in traditional trades since 1999. Only one in three apprenticeships were in training in the traditional trades fields for the June quarter this year, compared to 42 per cent five years earlier. What a shocking record.

The NCVER figures also reveal that over the 12 months to June 2004 the number of Australians commencing a traineeship or apprenticeship has dropped 10 per cent, with nearly 30,000 fewer people having commenced training compared to the 12 months to June 2003. There are 9,800 fewer people in training, according to this report. The number of people cancelling or withdrawing from training is up by 5,400 compared to the June 2003 quarter, a jump of 19 per cent. These are the actual figures of what has been happening in vocational education and training under this government. You would think it would be a wake-up call. After eight years, what a mess they have created. They have let a severe skills shortage develop, and they are doing next to nothing to address it. It is, of course, Australian business and families that have to pay the price for the government's lack of action.

Yesterday, we saw a very confused Minister for Vocational and Technical Education reveal that he is well and truly out of his depth. He has no understanding of the seriousness of the severe skills crisis that has developed on this government's watch. In answer to a question from the federal member for Adelaide about whether the Howard government supported industry levies to deal with the acute national skills shortage, the minister replied that, no, he does not support industry levies. The minister clearly has no idea that earlier this month the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission authorised an industry levy on bricks to fund more apprenticeships in order to address a shortage of skilled bricklayers. The government's inaction has led to the industry having to put a levy on to pay for increased training.

The minister responded with what can only be described as confused waffle when I asked him—in light of his answer—what he was going to do to stop this new levy on Australian families and businesses. The minister's answer was that the issue was not within his remit. It just shows that the minister either does not know or does not care that Australia's skills shortage is seriously hurting. Amazingly, the minister also put his stamp of approval on increased costs for families and businesses arising from the wage pressures caused by Australia's skills shortage. He should of course tell that to local business and families, who are struggling to cope with spiralling costs because of the skills shortage that has happened on this government's watch. On the site of the new terminal at Adelaide airport, the shortage of wall and ceiling fixers is so severe that GMR Interiors, one of the construction companies on site, has to pay up to $600 a week above the industry rate. But the minister does not seem to care about this. Yesterday he said that inflated wages were a good thing, yet the severe skills shortage is clearly jeopardising local industry projects through inflated wages and costs.

Local businesses across the country are giving away work because they cannot find enough workers to fulfil demand. And things are set to get worse and worse. According to the Australian Industry Group, right now Australia has a shortage of around 20,000 skilled workers in sectors like carpentry, construction, manufacturing and mining. The AIG says that over the next five years 175,000 people are expected to leave the traditional trades but only 70,000 are likely to enter. That means there will be a shortfall of more than 100,000 skilled workers. But what is the government doing to address this? We are looking at a shortage of 100,000 workers and what do we get from this government? Next to nothing—a handful of technical colleges that are frankly going to make barely a dent. These technical colleges will not start for another year, they will not be in place fully for four years and they will in fact only affect a tiny proportion of school students when they are in place.

The skills crisis in this country is here and now and it is growing. Businesses cannot wait another year for action from the Howard government. They are crying out for more skilled workers right now. The colleges will provide training to fewer than two per cent of Australian year 11 and 12 students—that is the contribution they are going to make. The vast majority of senior secondary students will in fact miss out. Early school leavers and year 12 graduates will be excluded from the colleges, and yet every year under this government we turn away 40,000 Australians from TAFE and 40,000 early school leavers join the unemployment queue.

If this government invested the funds it is using for technical colleges into our TAFEs right now, we could create more than 45,000 desperately needed new places. Instead of wasting millions of dollars duplicating Australian TAFEs and limiting new training to just a few, the Howard government should fund our TAFEs properly and invest in more apprenticeships in areas of skills shortage. But instead of acting to address our skills shortages in this way the government is more interested in playing politics, especially with the states. The government has refused to fund any new TAFE places, and this has gone on for quite a considerable period of time. As can be seen, the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 that we are debating here today continues this neglect. It is further evidence of the government's inaction on skill shortages.

The bill reduces and limits the funding to the vocational education and training sector. The first section of the bill will reduce the level of funds for vocational education provided to the Australian National Training Authority for distribution to the states and territories in 2004. The funding will fall from $1.36 billion to $1.31 billion—once again, a reflection of this government's failure to strike an agreement on training funding with the states and territories in the last round of ANTA negotiations. The bill will also appropriate up to $1.154 billion in funds for vocational education and training to be distributed by the states and territories for 2005. This amount of money, I have to say, is a stark reminder that the government cannot be trusted when it comes to education and training. While on the surface it sounds like a large amount, closer scrutiny reveals a system which has been starved of funds and is struggling to fill a gaping hole that was in fact created by this government when it first came to power.

Just how little value this government places on training and apprenticeships was revealed when it slashed $240 million out of the VET sector in its first two budgets. This was swiftly followed by the 1998-2000 ANTA agreement, which abolished growth funding altogether and froze funding to the sector for the next three years. These funding cuts and the subsequent freeze have meant that more and more TAFE colleges have had to close some of their training facilities, putting teachers and students under pressure, and have threatened the quality in training and skills development in this country. At the same time that the government has been cutting and freezing funds we have had businesses crying out for more skilled staff, and of course there is a major shortage of TAFE places. This is the direct result of the Howard government's education and training policies.

This skills shortage has happened under this government's watch. No-one else is to blame. This bill is just the latest instalment in a long-running saga surrounding the last ANTA agreement. So, instead of a government that approaches negotiations over the funding of our national training system as an opportunity to work with the states and territories, what we have is a government that just wants to play politics, buck-pass responsibility for its policy failings and, as usual, blame somebody else. No wonder the government has announced that it will close down the Australian National Training Authority. This authority was the vehicle to enable people to work collaboratively—not only the states and the Commonwealth but also business and union representatives—to make sure that we had a group of people whose task was to address the training needs of this country. Well, this government has just decided to abolish it.

The government clearly are not serious about boosting the role of vocational education and training; otherwise we would see a much more substantial investment in this bill. They have not offered the states any extra growth funding, which is why they have not been able to secure an agreement with the states for the next round of ANTA funding. The government have just walked away—taken their bat and ball—and have decided to abolish ANTA, along with being unable to negotiate a new agreement.

For eight long years the Howard government has been wasting talent and missing economic opportunities because it refuses to act to address this growing skills crisis. This did not just happen yesterday and it did not just happen since the election; it has been happening over the last eight years. And the government has not only done nothing about it; if you go back to the early days of this government, its first few budgets had a disastrous impact on the funding for vocational education and training.

Our workplaces are facing skills shortages, there is a serious shortage of TAFE places, wage pressures are jeopardising local industry and, of course, families are suffering as well—suffering because they have to pay more to get their homes built. They will certainly have to pay more if they want a brick home because there is now a new levy on the price of bricks. I hope everybody who is thinking about either doing an extension or building a new home recognises that the increase in the cost of extending or building their brick home is a direct result of the Howard government not properly funding the number of bricklayers in training, and so the industry has been forced to put on this additional levy.

The government have had a long time to get this right. They have had eight years to invest in world-class training, but they have not done that; they have just ignored this area. I am sorry to say that this bill is yet another wasted opportunity—yet another wasted and missed opportunity—because it does not provide the additional funding and the additional places for training that our country needs. You do not have to take my word for it; just look at what the Australian Industry Group says about the shortage of workers. This bill today will do nothing to address the shortages that the Australian Industry Group has identified.

This bill just extends funding to the training sector for next year. The big disappointment is that it has no additional growth. Here we have a government putting forward a bill in the face of a very serious skills crisis, with no additional growth funding—none—to help cut down the queues of people waiting to get into TAFE and no long-term solution to the training crisis gripping Australian business. I for one know that none of us in this parliament can afford complacency in this vocational education and training area.

So, after eight years of neglect, the government are trying to reinvent themselves as a party interested in skills and apprenticeships. When they first came in, they slashed the budget. Then they froze the funding for a few years. They have realised they created this severe skills crisis and know they have to do something—but this bill is not part of it. This bill is certainly not doing anything to add to the training opportunities for Australians, because there is no growth funding associated with it. Instead of building on the successful elements of the existing system, next year the government is intending to create these new technical colleges. As some members of the coalition themselves have said, this will create unnecessary duplication.

The abolition of ANTA also clearly signals the end of tripartite collaborative negotiations in this area. No longer will we have a place where all the parties can come together and work out what is best for training in this country. This is particularly important if we are to protect the national training system and to make sure that, for business and for employees, we have qualifications and courses that are recognised right across Australia. The last thing we want is a return to a system where qualifications are recognised only in individual states or very narrowly accredited. That would be a disaster for both employers and workers.

The highest priority should be given to delivering adequate funding to make sure that our local TAFEs have the money that they need and make sure that there are work and training opportunities for those 45,000 young people who every year—I wonder when the government will wake up to this issue—leave school early. Every year for eight years we have had 45,000 young people leave school early. They join the unemployment queue. They are not going into training, they are not staying at school and they are the people who we should be targeting to make sure that we can get them into training and that they do not face a life of long-term unemployment.

It was Labor that actually introduced the first vocational education and training funding bill. We also set up the Australian National Training Authority so that apprentices could have a well-funded national education system. It was an unprecedented commitment to the training of young Australians in particular. We spent our time trying to build up a great training system. Unfortunately, over the last eight years we have seen a government running it down. As I said, this run-down of training has become a major concern of industry. The Australian Industry Group have released report after report, trying to get the Howard government to focus on the growing skills crisis. I quote from one of their reports:

quote.para: Over half of the businesses surveyed currently face skill shortages. Regional businesses in NSW (60% currently face skill shortages) are most acutely impacted followed by businesses in regional Victoria (48%) and Queensland (41%).

speech.para: According to the Australian Industry Group, skill shortages in Australia are endemic—`endemic' is the word the AIG uses. There is a shortage of around 20,000 workers. This government is not providing growth funding in this bill. The AIG's warning is that the skills crisis facing Australian industry is here and now. The AIG must be very frustrated that it has a government that is not listening. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry is also seriously concerned. This is what a survey of investor confidence, published this year, had to say:

quote.para: For only the second time in the history of the survey Business Taxes and Charges ... has been removed from its position as the foremost constraint on investment. Taking number one position for the first time is the Availability of Suitably Qualified Employees ... A much tighter labour market for skilled workers has seen this constraint rise from fifth highest just a year ago to second position in January and April, then finally to first in the current quarter.

speech.para: The first issue for business, the biggest concern for ACCI members, was the growing shortage of skills. The Senate Employment, Workplace Relations and Education References Committee has also found that Australia does not have enough skilled metal engineering and manufacturing workers to carry out the $20 billion worth of major infrastructure and resource projects expected in the next 10 years. Industry groups and a Senate committee have recognised a serious risk to economic performance and productivity resulting from this government's lack of action over the last eight years.

Unlike this government, we took a policy to the last election to boost Australian skill levels and address shortages in a much more substantial way. Our strategy to build the skill levels of the Australian work force included the following: an additional 36,600 real growth places—that is over and above the money being provided in this bill—including 20,000 new TAFE places, and a commitment, which I think was very important, to pay the TAFE fees of secondary school students. There was not a limit on the number of young people who could go to technical colleges. We were saying that all secondary school students who wanted to gain vocational qualifications while they were still at school would have their TAFE fees paid by a federal Labor government.

Our strategy also included 6,600 skill-up apprenticeships through group training in regions of high unemployment or skill shortage; a significant increase in funding for group training organisations to support small and medium enterprises and to create up to 8,000 additional apprenticeships; more opportunities for mature age Australians to update their skills; a training bonus for aged care and child-care trainees who complete their training; and national protocols to make sure that TAFE fees and charges are affordable. The government complain about these TAFE fees, but they do not do anything about it. I do not know what they think they are in government for. They are not there to have a whinge; they are actually there to fix problems.

Our policy also included a quality training agreement with state and territory governments to address current and emerging skill shortages and to make sure all apprentices and trainees receive quality training. These initiatives built on Labor's commitment to create 20,000 additional university places every year, including in nursing, teacher education and medicine. It also augmented a terrific program we wanted to put in place, called Bright Futures. This was a school based program to help schools raise the awareness of post secondary work and study options, including the benefits of a career in traditional trades.

These initiatives form a comprehensive strategy to tackle the skills crisis and boost Australia's skills level. Compare that to what we are debating here today: a bill that has no growth at all to address this serious skills shortage that we face right now—a shortage that has been described as endemic by the Australian Industry Group, a shortage that is not in any way, most unfortunately, addressed by the bill. Of course we want to see this money flow, but I say to the government: you need much more than this if we are going to address the very serious skills crisis that this government faces.

talk.start.para: —Today I wish to speak in strong support of the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 and bring to the attention of members the important role of vocational education and training in assisting young people to reach their full potential and to find their own place in the world of work. This government has actually made significant progress, despite the words we have just heard, in developing vocational education pathways for the 70 per cent of young people who do not go directly from school to university. Currently, 95 per cent of secondary schools across Australia offer vocational education and training programs. Certainly in my electorate of Bass in Northern Tasmania there is a level of involvement to varying degrees in every secondary school and college. I take this opportunity today to congratulate the teachers and principals in these schools who have had the foresight and the professionalism to introduce these programs into the curriculum. I especially commend them where they have used VET courses as a way of re-engaging difficult or at-risk students who stand to genuinely benefit from this extra option while at school.

speech.para: There has been significant growth in the numbers undertaking VET in schools from around 60,000 in 1996 when the Howard government came to office to almost 203,000 today. That is rather a different picture to the one just painted for us by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Nationally that represents 44 per cent of all senior secondary students. There has also been a large increase in the number of young people undertaking school based new apprenticeships. There are now 14,000 young people in school based apprenticeships compared to just 1,500 in 1998. This is nearly a tenfold increase. Will we as politicians ever be really able to understand the good this has done for our families and our young people? I am confident that for every student who takes up this option with the support of their family and their school there is a success story of a satisfied, fulfilled young person very happy to be doing something worth while and looking forward to a real career with a real job.

These pathways provide young people with industry recognised qualifications and provide viable pathways for those young people who do not wish to go to university for whatever reasons they may have for not wanting a tertiary education. However, too often the message is sent to young Australians that a career in a trade is not as valued and not as valuable as a university qualification. This message has contributed to the growing skill shortage we are facing today and to the high drop-out rate of students in their first year of university. Australia's university drop-out rate is among the highest in the developed world: 40 per cent of students who begin university study do not complete it. Government analysis shows that 100,000 of the 228,000 people who got a HECS place at university this year will not finish that course and 40,000 will have left before the end of the year and will never come back. How can this be happening? It is because so many of them are striving for university entry but have no particular long-term purpose in doing so except to gain a tertiary award. Perhaps they do not really know what they want to do with their lives; perhaps some have virtually had the decision made for them by their family, by their college or school or by their peers. But, for whatever reason it is happening, it stands to say that so many people are missing the opportunity to reach their potential and to attain personal fulfilment in their lives.

What I will not dwell on today but would like to mention is that for those students who do drop out of university there is an enormous price to be paid: the accumulation of a HECS debt without reaching the goal that it contributes towards paying for; the social cost and embarrassment; and, more importantly, the months or years that are in many cases simply lost to that individual. Another price that we as a community pay is having a large number of young people who have been taught to feel that there is no prestige if they only want to leave school and get a trade, as if it were an inferior option to tertiary study. As a former schoolteacher of maths, science and IT at Kings Meadows High School, I impressed upon as many of my students as I could our school motto, `We have our part to play.'

We have all heard how the abolition of technical colleges by the states has meant that over the past few decades many young people have lacked clear training and skills pathways, particularly the 70 per cent of those who choose to not go directly from school to university. Unlike the previous speaker, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I am excited about the Howard government's pledge to invest $289 million over four years to establish 24 Australian technical colleges. These will promote pride and excellence in the teaching and acquiring of skills at the secondary school level. These colleges, one of which is to be based in my own region of Northern Tasmania, will be open to talented year 11 and 12 students interested in gaining a trade, but while also being able to complete their secondary schooling. I am saddened, however, by Labor's negative, rhetorical approach to this important initiative. Repeatedly in the House of Representatives question time since the opening of the parliament, questions from members of the Labor Party on the subject of Australian technical colleges have uniformly described them as `overdue and insufficient'. We have just heard the Deputy Leader of the Opposition say also that the Australian technical colleges will make barely a dent in the skills shortages in Australia. What a sad comment.

The fact is that these select high-achievement colleges will provide tuition for up to 7,200 young people in years 11 and 12 every year. They will be implemented from 2006, within virtually one year from now—not the mystical four-year figure which is being used. Students at the colleges will be able to undertake academic, information technology and business courses. They will graduate from the colleges with trade, entrepreneurial and business skills, with the capacity to be self-employed in the future or to go on to further education and training. All students would have the opportunity to take up a school based new apprenticeship. Colleges will be endorsed and led by industry. They will be run autonomously by principals, who will be able to engage teaching staff on a performance pay basis.

Interestingly, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition referred fairly frequently to the Australian Industry Group. In a press release on 24 November, Ms Macklin stated that the government's Australian technical colleges were not a solution to skills shortages and that the government should address this issue immediately. However, this was not a view shared by industry. On the same day, a press release issued by the Australian Industry Group expressed strong support for the initiative and applauded the government's leadership in addressing the skills shortages issue. To me, these words from members of the Labor Party are a disgrace. If they secretly thought that the colleges were a good idea, good public policy and good for addressing the issues that we are all concerned about, then they could at least have kept quiet about it and let the bill go through. They could even have publicly supported it, reversing their predictable opposition from the time the policy was launched during the election campaign.

But these new Australian technical colleges need to be supported, they need to be championed, and Labor ought to spell out right now what they would do when the Australian technical colleges are progressively opened from 2005. Will they support them then? They need also to say what they would do to them if they won office after the next election. Would they mothball them? Would they still describe them as insufficient? Or was it a Freudian slip for them to describe them as `overdue' and they do actually believe that they may have some merit?

Also, during question time today I heard the answers to the questions asked by the Labor members that I have referred to. I listened to Minister Hardgrave's answers when on each occasion Labor members were interjecting with calls such as, `You have had eight years to fix this,' or, `You have done nothing for eight years,' and other claims that somehow the government had been asleep at the wheel. This is breathtaking hypocrisy. Are the Labor members claiming that the government has missed its opportunity to address a skills shortage that existed in 1996 after they had left office after 13 years in government? No, I do not think they are saying that.

The fact is that Australia is, in a way, a victim of its own success. Strong economic management, responsible decisions, not being beholden to unions, effective employment programs, industrial relations reforms and welfare reforms have rescued Australia. Today we have a strong and growing economy, consistent budget surpluses, lower income tax rates, evaporating government debt from the $96 billion debt left to us by Labor, more people in work, higher participation and an unemployment rate that is virtually half what it once was.

The growing economy has caused the higher demand for skills. The demand for skills has employed more people, which means that the pool of people left to take up new skills and provide them has been reduced. In short, under Labor we had people looking for jobs; under the Howard government we have jobs looking for people. This is, with due respect to the seriousness of the challenge, a good problem to have.

Also during the previous speech we heard of unmet demand in Australia. In fact, as the previous speaker correctly identified, today we have unmet demand in TAFE colleges in Australia at around the 40,000 level. I think it is important for me to remind members that, on the government's coming to office, that figure was 89,000, so there has been quite a dramatic turnaround since that time. It also has to be said that the government, with the leadership shown in the past and even today from the Minister for Education, Science and Training, have turned a spotlight on the issues and we are actively doing something about them. In contrast, Labor have sat on their hands. The Minister for Education, Science and Training reported on Labor's sudden interest as recently as August this year, prior to the recent election. He said in the chamber on 11 August:

quote.para: In the almost three years I have had the privilege to be this country's Minister for Education, Science and Training, I have had 59 questions in question time. Fifty-four of those questions have been about universities, and five have been about training—and in those five questions the word `apprenticeship' appeared once, as an afterthought.

speech.para: In relation to funding for TAFE colleges through the ANTA agreement, I say this: if Labor were serious about TAFE, then during the failed ANTA agreement negotiations earlier this year and even prior to that, when the federal government offered ongoing increases of 2½ per cent on the condition that states would increase their own funding to their own colleges by just 1½ per cent, they should have picked up the phone and told their Labor colleagues in the various states and territories to sign on the dotted line.

This government has also taken steps to strengthen careers advice. Earlier this year the Minister for Education, Science and Training announced two initiatives to address this issue. One was a professional development package for careers advisers, including a best practice resource for all careers teachers in secondary schools, an accredited online course to enhance the skills of career and transition advisers, and an elective course in career education to be offered as part of Bachelor of Education degrees. Another initiative was the Career Education Lighthouse Schools Project, which aims to support the leaders in career education programs in schools and promote best practice models to other schools.

These measures will assist students to navigate their way through their career options, make the most of their vocational learning experiences and make a smooth transition from school to work. Raising the profile of the benefits of VET in Schools pathways is also of major importance. The challenge is to ensure that both students and their parents recognise the value of VET qualifications and the pathways they can offer. To acknowledge the achievements of those students who have chosen VET in Schools pathways, a national student prize for VET in Schools students and school based New Apprenticeships students, consisting of a cash prize of $2,000, will be awarded to 450 VET in Schools students and 50 school based New Apprenticeships students each year across Australia. This initiative will support students in exploring a variety of options when they are making crucial choices about their futures. The national student prize will also encourage parents to talk to their children about the importance of VET in Schools programs and the career opportunities that are available to them in a broad range of industries. This bill will provide further funding for the development of strategic initiatives to expand the range of VET in Schools programs and enhance transitions to employment and further education for students.

In reply to the previous speaker I only have one further comment, and that is in relation to the description of this bill as somehow being a reduction in money to the states and territories. This plainly ignores or disregards the fact that during the breakdown in negotiations toward the next ANTA agreement, where the states declined the offer of increased funding because presumably they did not wish to dip into their own coffers, the government's response was to take the additional money which was being pledged and to simply tender it out to the local community. That tender process created 7,500 places around the country.

In conclusion, the Howard government's commitment to vocational education and training is strong. It is illustrated by the significant funding provided through this bill and the new initiatives announced this year, particularly in addressing skills shortages. Since 1996 the coalition government has reinvigorated vocational education and training with record numbers in training, record numbers in new apprenticeships and significant progress toward developing a high-quality, truly national system.

Today, 12 per cent of Australia's working age population is in VET training. This year the Australian government will spend a record $2.1 billion on vocational education and training, which will underpin this nation's strong economic growth and low unemployment. We have also announced new measures in our election commitments to a total of $1.06 billion over four years. This is one of the most significant boosts to vocational education and training ever undertaken by any government. This bill will provide the Australian government funding required to support Australia's world-class vocational education and training system in 2005, and I commend it to the House.

talk.start.para: —Government contributors to this debate on the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 have been saying at the same time that the skills shortage confronting Australia is a great problem to have and that they have taken all of these measures to avert a skills shortage in Australia. The truth is that the government cannot have it both ways. The fact of the matter is that there is an acute skills shortage in this country and it is not a great problem to have. It is a serious problem for our economic prospects both in the short term and, just as importantly, in the longer term.

speech.para: I want to outline the dimensions of the skills shortage in Australia. The Australian Industry Group has found that in the manufacturing sector there are between 18,000 and 21,000 unfilled vacancies for tradespeople. I do not think that is a great problem to have. Further, the Australian Industry Group has identified that numbers of traditional apprenticeships have remained pretty much unchanged since 1996, when the Howard government took office. So when this government talks about apprenticeships it does not talk about traditional apprenticeships as the people of Australia know them but of some variation or cheap inversion of apprenticeships.

Traditional apprenticeships have not grown under the Howard government. Indeed, according to the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations skilled vacancy index, vacancies for skilled tradespeople have increased by an astonishing 54 per cent over the last three years. According to the Australian Industry Group, right now Australia has a shortage of around 20,000 skilled workers in sectors like carpentry, construction, manufacturing and mining. The Australian Industry Group says that over the next five years 175,000 people are expected to leave the traditional trades but only 70,000 will enter. That means a skills shortage in the traditional trades of more than 100,000 workers. That is not a great problem to have.

Instead of wasting millions of dollars duplicating the Australian TAFE system and limiting new training to just a few, the Howard government should fund our TAFEs properly and invest in more genuine apprenticeships in areas of skills shortage. The government refused to fund any new TAFE places between 1997 and 2001. The same government provided only one-third of the funding states and territories needed between 2001 and 2003.

This bill will reduce the level of funds for vocational education that are provided to the Australian National Training Authority for distribution to the states and territories in 2004. The funding will fall from $1.36 billion to $1.31 billion. What is the government's response to the skill shortage? It is to cut funding to the Australian National Training Authority in 2004. Indeed, looking at the history of this government, in its first two budgets it slashed $240 million out of vocational education and training. Then it followed up with the 1998-2000 ANTA agreement that abolished growth funding altogether and froze funding to the sector for at least three years. Here is a looming skills shortage, which started emerging in the mid-1990s. The first response of the Howard government to that skills shortage was to take $240 million out of vocational education and training and then follow it up by freezing funding, no growth funding, in the subsequent years.

Those funding cuts and a subsequent freeze meant more and more of the TAFE colleges closed their training facilities, putting teachers and students under a lot of pressure. To cap it all off, the government has announced that it will close down the Australian National Training Authority. That was a vehicle to work collaboratively with the states, and the Howard government has obviously made a judgment that it does not want to work collaboratively with the states in addressing the acute skill shortages that have built up while the government has taken action to cut funding for vocational education and training and then to freeze it.

I foreshadowed this sort of response in the great GST debate when we talked about the Prime Minister's great tax adventure and the Treasurer's streamlined new tax system for a new century. It was clear that the government was going to allow specific purpose payments to the states to erode over time. On the day that the GST was introduced, the government abolished $18 billion in untied grants. It was plain to see that the government would allow the tied grants—which were of a similar order of magnitude—used for such purposes as vocational education and training to erode, contravening the spirit of the memorandum of understanding that was signed by the Treasurer, Prime Minister and state premiers. I remember well the Treasurer saying, `We have this memorandum of understanding and it will guarantee no cuts to the specific purpose payments.'

The way to reduce the value of specific purpose payments is not to adjust them for cost increases and general inflation and allow them to erode with population growth instead of providing the same per capita amount. Those two mechanisms were available to the government. Like a big, black, hungry dog, the government got in there and made sure that those two mechanisms were used effectively to erode the specific purpose payments to the states. Here, today, we have evidence of that, and only a few years after the government said: `Trust us. We have signed a memorandum of understanding with the states. We won't do it.' Well, they did. We knew they would. We knew they would do it in health. We knew they would do it in education. And this bill today shows that is exactly what they have done.

Government members are saying that a skill shortage is a great problem to have. I need to relay the story of Australian productivity growth, because today's productivity growth is tomorrow's prosperity. Labor recognised that when it was last in government and set out a major, comprehensive economic reform program designed to lift productivity growth in this country. Labor knew that the yield from those reforms would take some time, and, indeed it did. But Labor was patient, Labor was determined and Labor had a coherent program of economic reforms designed to lift productivity growth.

When those reforms were implemented, by the early 1990s productivity growth in Australia did indeed begin to respond. From 1993 right through to the current day, Australian productivity growth has been faster than almost every country in the world—faster than most countries in the world, with the exception of Finland and Ireland. So those economic reforms did work. Labor created the open, competitive economy. Labor opened the door to competition, both from abroad and from here in Australia, and it lifted productivity growth. When you see the Treasurer crowing about strong economic growth in this country, he is in fact crowing about the returns, the dividends, the yield from that economic reform program instituted by the Hawke and Keating governments.

However, having opened the door once to create the open, competitive economy, you cannot open the same door twice. You can keep it open and you can push it a little bit further where possible. That is why the Productivity Commission recently released a report advocating further reforms in competition policy and an improvement in the efficiency of various industries and infrastructure provision in this country. But the Productivity Commission knows that the main game—the opening of the economy—has already occurred.

We now come to the point in 2002 when the Intergenerational Report was released. The Intergenerational Report contains very worrying forecasts. The Intergenerational Report forecasts that Australian productivity growth from next year, 2005, will slip back to our 30-year mediocre long-term average—that is, down from 2.05 per cent during the late 1990s to 1.75 per cent for the coming decades. That 1.75 per cent productivity growth is a serious problem for Australia because we are confronted with the ageing of the population and it will be productivity growth almost exclusively that Australia will need to use to combat the ageing of the population.

The ageing of the population is a fact. The die is cast. To invoke the phrase used by the Treasurer: `demography is destiny'. The ageing of the population is a result of decisions made by parents over the last 40 years that will affect the age profile of the Australian population over the next 40 years. So the die is cast. We cannot prevent the ageing of the population. Fertility continues to decline and it is forecast to decline further to 1.65 per cent over the 40-year projection period. That forecast is contained in the Intergenerational Report.

So, if the die is cast on the ageing of the population, we need to rely on strong productivity growth to combat the effects of the ageing population on Australian prosperity. We may ask: what are the forecasts for per capita GDP growth, which is the best available measure of the growth in living standards in Australia? The forecasts contained in the Intergenerational Report are for a slump in Australia's per capita GDP growth from 2010 onwards that would constitute the slowest rate of growth in that measure of living standards since the decade of the Great Depression.

Everyone in this room and this parliament should be alarmed at those forecasts and should be doing everything possible to prevent those forecasts from becoming a reality—and we can. If we were able to maintain the productivity growth of the late 1990s that has been going on through to the early 2000s then we could successfully deal with the ageing of the population. Yet it requires us to identify the new sources of productivity growth because, if we have opened the door to competition, if we have created an open, competitive economy and we cannot open that door a second time, we must identify the new sources of productivity growth.
