The international evidence on this matter is stark. It is clear: the strongest, most powerful, most potent source of productivity growth in the Western world is skills formation. That brings us back to this legislation, because at a time when we should be investing in skills the Howard government is disinvesting. It is running down our skills base. It is divesting in skills in this country at exactly the wrong time.

talk.start.para: —We haven't even got enough bricklayers.

—Not enough bricklayers, not enough tradespeople, at exactly the wrong time. These are not just statements from a Labor Party politician; they are statements from people who have analysed these matters. I will cite some of those. The OECD, in a major international study in 2003, identified skills generation, skills formation, as the most important source of productivity growth in the 20th century, followed by investment in innovation and, thirdly, by investment in infrastructure and, of course, keeping the economy open and trading with other countries.

speech.para: So what is the Australian experience with skills formation, of which this legislation is a reflection? It is a very sorry experience indeed. I will quote from the Productivity Commission. This is a damning indictment on the Howard government, because the Productivity Commission said:

quote.para: ... the weight of evidence suggests there was a slower rate of accumulation of human capital in the Australian workforce in the 1990s, which all else equal would have detracted from a productivity acceleration in the 1990s.

speech.para: In other words, that strong productivity growth that was achieved out of the economic reform programs of the Hawke and Keating years was weakened by a detraction caused by a slowdown in skills formation. Similarly, the Productivity Commission said:

quote.para: ... there appears to have been no significant acceleration in workforce skills in the 1990s. In fact, the evidence shows a faster increase in skills in the 1980s—

speech.para: when Labor was in power. These conclusions are confirmed by the OECD's empirical work, which indicates that skill upgrading made no contribution to Australian productivity growth between 1990 and 2000.
Drawing together the work of the OECD and the Productivity Commission, Saul Eslake asked this question:

quote.para: ... why has education apparently not made any discernible contribution to the improvement in Australia's economic performance over the past decade? The answer, unfortunately, seems to be that there has not been any discernible improvement in Australia's educational outcomes—at least insofar as they impact on productivity growth—during this period.

speech.para: Saul Eslake is the Chief Economist for the ANZ Bank. He is no lackey of the Australian Labor Party and that is the conclusion that he has drawn.

Steve Dowrick at the ANU has had a very extensive career in looking at skills formation as a source of productivity growth in Australia and overseas—a lot of empirical work—and his conclusion is this:

quote.para: These international comparisons suggest that Australia's educational report card should be marked: `Started well, but slackened off. Substantial room for improvement.'

speech.para: What an indictment on the Howard government. What an indictment that we have legislation here today that involves the abolition of the Australian National Training Authority and the continuation of completely inadequate funding for skills in this country.

Skills formation is a big problem now and investing in skills is the best investment that we can imagine in this country, and yet we have a piece of legislation that abolishes the Australian National Training Authority and pursues the Howard government's ideological agenda of bypassing the states. The government has announced that it will set up its own technical colleges that will not be completed for another four years. So this is the government's urgent response to the urgent problem of skills shortages in this country: to announce an initiative in the election that will produce no discernible improvement in skills in this country for another four years, and yet the government has the temerity to say that this is a great problem to have—it is boasting that this is the problem that it has. Well, it is not a problem for the Howard government; it is a problem for Australia. Unless we turn around this government's attitude towards skills formation in Australia the Productivity Commission's work, the Intergenerational Report forecasts, will all come true—that is, from the end of this decade, in this country, we will have the slowest rate of growth per person since the decade of the Great Depression. You would think it probably could not get much worse than that, but it does, because the forecasts for the subsequent decade, the 2020s, are for an even slower rate of growth.

If we are to combat the ageing of the population, we must invest in skills in this country now. This legislation fails to do that. It abolishes the Australian National Training Authority, it pursues the government's ideological agenda—the government is not interested in cooperating with the states—and it realises the government's intentions back in the year 2000, when it signed a sham memorandum of understanding with the states, saying that it would maintain specific purpose payments to the states in all areas. It has done nothing of the sort, and it has betrayed the future of this country and of all young people who live in this country, young people who yearn for a decent opportunity in life and for the skills to enable them to develop their talents and contribute to this great country.

This is one of the most shameful pieces of legislation that have ever been brought into this parliament. It is one of the first pieces of legislation brought into the parliament in the new term of the Howard government. It shows how miserable and mean it is when it comes to investing in the nation's future, when it comes to investing in the talents of our young people, and the government should be condemned for it.

talk.start.para: —The Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 is another progressive piece of legislation from the Howard government. It is interesting to listen to our opponents, who explain that the sun will not rise tomorrow because of the terrible way the government are running the country. The opposition cannot escape the fact that apprenticeship numbers in this country have nearly tripled in the time that we have been in control of the Treasury benches. I think it is really important to note the whole change in culture that our government have been working towards over many years. When you add a progressive policy approach and the desire to establish 24 Australian technical colleges, as well as the belief that skills other than those attained in the universities of this country are of equal value to them, then you get an idea of the direction of this government and its commitment to the working people of this country.

speech.para: It is a particular pleasure for me to rise to contribute to this debate today. As someone who has not had the opportunity to participate in an apprenticeship scheme, university or even years 11 and 12, and as someone who comes from rural and regional Australia, there is nothing more important to my mind than seeing this sort of legislation in the parliament and people having the opportunity to remind anyone who cares to listen, but particularly the young people of Australia, that what they do with their young lives in terms of developing skills is of equal value to what others do, whether they be doctors of medicine, doctors of philosophy, schoolteachers, nurses or whatever. It is so important that we get in this country an equal opportunity for every Australian, and this is what this legislation is about.

I will say a few words about the 24 Australian technical colleges, the Australian network of industry career advisers and of course the financial assistance for Commonwealth trade learning scholarships, toolkits and residential support for new apprenticeships. Coming from an electorate that is 1,000 kilometres by 1,000 kilometres—just under one million square kilometres—I can say that residential support for new apprenticeships is a very significant step forward, with the youth allowance being offered in a way that is only being offered to a particular sector of the community.

I also remind the Main Committee that not only have we seen almost a trebling in the number of apprentices in this country over the last eight or nine years but we have seen a very significant reduction in unemployment. And now this whole debate about the shortage of skills right across industry and right across the economy demonstrates clearly the strength of our economy. This is a government that not only supports every Australian and encourages every Australian but puts into place policies within an economy strong enough to deliver on those aspirations which are so vital to every Australian, particularly every young Australian.

While I am thinking about young Australians it is very timely, particularly with the issues on Palm Island, for me to talk about young Aboriginal Australians. As the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs in the 41st Parliament, can I say that there is no more important issue than offering young Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people the opportunity to be employed. This sort of legislation, in cooperation with the states and territories—they are vital—is absolutely essential to the future of Aboriginal people. Unless we can offer the hope, the self-esteem and the opportunity for young Aboriginal people to develop the skills to work in their communities and to have a productive life, we will only continue the tragedies that Palm Island has witnessed over these last few days.

I am always delighted to speak on this sort of legislation, this sort of acknowledgment of the value of every Australian, particularly those Australians who are not necessarily academically inclined. The opportunities for regional, rural and remote young people in particular, in the tertiary sector, in the university sector and even in the TAFE sector, are very limited when we look at the opportunities in our urban centres. This bill, supported by the policy announcements from the last election, has given us the hope of and supported the aspiration of young people to a very positive future. There is more to be done, because if you live 1,000 kilometres away from a centre of learning, whether it is a TAFE, a university or any other institution which enhances education, then you are behind the eight ball. And then, if you have financial circumstances that, compared to those of most other Australians, add a bill of $5,000 or $10,000 per annum in order to have that opportunity, it is something which I have to describe as still being work in progress.

With great pleasure I support the bill and wish it every success. The measure of this bill will be particularly in the years ahead, as we see the vision that this government has given and will continue to give this country through its leadership, offering young people great opportunities to develop their skills.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 because it provides another opportunity for me as the member for Throsby to put on the public record my congratulations regarding the wonderful efforts of the staff and the directors of the Illawarra Institute of TAFE for our region. While located in Wollongong, of course, the institute has campuses in many outlying areas.

speech.para: The vocational education and TAFE system is a remarkable system, publicly funded and publicly accessible, that provides a wide range of educational opportunities. I visit the TAFE colleges quite regularly and talk to the teachers about some of the issues that they face as workers in the system. I also appreciate the very important role that the TAFE system plays in advancing the economic issues and dealing with the imperatives that face our regional economy. It is a wonderful system because it provides opportunities for the young and not-so-young, giving a lot of adults in particular a second chance and a second go. Its courses range from traditional trade training through to basic literacy and numeracy. In our area, particularly important are the programs for newly arrived immigrants and refugees in basic English language. It is also a system that is critical for Australia's future economic success. In that regard I have to express my profound disappointment that the bill before us in fact reduces and limits the funding that is available this year to that very important system. It is amazing that, at a time when we all acknowledge the importance of productivity and economic growth—and investment in human capital is going to be a really important marker for the next spurt of productivity improvements that will sustain our competitiveness—we find this government actually reducing the level of funds available for this system.

As the brief indicates, the funding will fall from $1.36 billion to $1.31 billion, largely as a result of the incapacity of the federal government to reach agreement with the states in the last round of ANTA negotiations. When you look back at the record of the Howard government it is quite an appalling record for this important sector of our education and training system. The first two budgets, of course, saw cuts to the system, followed by a freeze in funds at a time when growth in demand was outstripping available places. For years the TAFE directors unanimously have been arguing the case that the government has a responsibility to provide extra funding to meet the unmet demand if we are going to meet the challenges that we all know are important for our nation. The government walked away from trying to finalise an agreement. I was not surprised when the states maintained a firm position of rejection of the offer that was made by the federal government through the minister.

The government has really failed the challenge of seeing the critical role of this sector and funding it in a way that provides continuing opportunities for all Australians, particularly young people, those who want to continue the route of trade training and those who see TAFE as a system for providing upskilling of workers already at work. All of this is going to impact severely—and is impacting severely—on Australian businesses; and not just on businesses but also on the students, many of whom are rejected year after year even though they have the capacity to successfully undertake courses. With that freeze in funding and the limit on growth funding, enormous pressure has been placed on the extremely dedicated staff who I know work at the local institutions and those who I daresay work in other areas. I think we all understand the imperatives that warrant a much better resourced system than is there at the moment. I guess that, when you just look at the statistics, you do not see things as clearly as you do when you are actually dealing with the outcomes of a system that is inadequately funded and resourced.

I want to talk a little bit about the impact that the government's complacent attitude is having on the regional economy of the Illawarra and the huge crisis we are facing, with youth unemployment levels hovering around 30 per cent at a time when we have a crisis in terms of skill shortages in the area. I would have thought that, if anything, the fact that business is screaming about the problems in attracting skilled labour would have been sounding alarm bells for this government, but it seems not to be the case. We have had at best a very pathetic response. The only tangible response has been the proposal to create 24 additional TAFE colleges, which will not be up and running for a few years at a time when industry is crying out for skilled labour now. What a waste of taxpayer funds, to put that money into creating an alternative system—alternative structures, alternative bureaucracies, alternative colleges—when that money could be so easily and readily absorbed by the existing TAFE institutions! There is no rationale or justification for expending taxpayer funds in establishing a duplicate TAFE college system.

Regrettably, the Howard government has not heeded the warnings that have been given for some time now by industry, by the union movement, by the TAFE system and by the TAFE directors. There was a recent Senate inquiry which obviously the government has taken no notice of. One wonders why enormous amounts of time, energy and resources are put into producing well-researched documents with comprehensive recommendations when they only sit on a shelf and are ignored. The report of that Senate inquiry, entitled Bridging the skills divide, outlined the seriousness of the situation facing Australia. I think we would be very foolish if we did not recognise that the current and projected skill shortages are going to threaten Australia's future economic capacity and development. You do not have to take my word for that. The Australian Industry Group made it very clear in its submission to the Senate inquiry that over half of the businesses it surveyed face skill shortages. And ACCI, one of the other peak organisations, said to the inquiry that `Australian firms are greatly concerned at their incapacity to recruit employees with appropriate levels of skills and retain skilled employees, with such pressures being particularly acute in regional and rural Australia'.

Recent research conducted by the ACTU estimates that the growing shortage of skilled workers, particularly in the traditional trades, will cost the Australian economy up to $9 billion in lost output over the next decade. That body of research also estimated that, on current intakes and projections, over the next five years up to 170,000 tradespeople will leave industry and only 40,000 will be entering. With an ageing population—and we hear a lot about the ageing of the population, but it applies equally to the traditional trades areas—we are not training enough young people to replace the looming shortages that are going to emerge in those traditional areas. Again, if you do not believe me, have a look at the government's own figures, which show that the job vacancies in the traditional trades are now at their highest level for 15 years. In fact, the recent departmental skilled vacancies index, which looks at the vacancies for skilled tradespeople, showed a 54 per cent jump in vacancies, rising from 97.1 per cent in November 2001 to 149.4 per cent in November 2004. This has all been happening while the Howard government has been in power—when it has been asleep on its watch. This skills shortage that everyone had been referring to for years continues unabated with no constructive solutions to redress the critical situation.

As I said earlier, the government's belated—and, at best, only half-hearted—publicly indefensible policy response was its proposal to establish 24 new colleges. From what I understand, they will not start operating until 2006 and will not be fully operational for some years after that. Even then, these new colleges will provide training to fewer than two per cent of year 11 and 12 students. An estimated 7½ thousand students in years 11 and 12 might get the option of undertaking a course at the colleges. You have to ask the question: is that the best means of expending taxpayers' funds to address a crisis that exists now? It is not a crisis that will be there in four years time; it is a crisis that is there now. While attracting young people into trade training and apprenticeships is important, it is really a drop in the ocean in terms of the magnitude of the problem. As I said, it does nothing to help the crisis now.

The Australian Industry Group, the AiG, in their document looking at regional indicators which was released recently, said that the crisis is `endemic', with an estimated 20,000 job vacancies in manufacturing alone. I would argue that the money set aside for the creation of these new colleges should be redirected immediately to create and open up new TAFE places, to do what we are attempting to do in the Illawarra in our apprenticeship pilot, which extends into the member for Gilmore's area too. We have been able, with small incentives, to create in the space of eight months 60 additional apprenticeship opportunities for young people who would have missed out otherwise.

The government should assist local organisations who are grappling with their own regional solutions to the particular nature of the skills crisis that confronts them. The government needs to move away from the top-down approach and have faith in communities to come up with solutions that best fit their particular needs. In my view, what would best meet the needs of employers, students and families in our area would be to redirect that money immediately into a well-functioning system that has provided lots of opportunities in the past and can do even better with additional resources and funding.

I think the government has also failed to develop a strategy for, and have a clear understanding of, the impact of skills shortages at a regional level. It is fair to say that you can access data on national and state trends, and the department does that adequately, but when you try and go beyond those global statistics to look at the impact at a regional level it is sadly wanting. The government needs to develop a clearer picture of the impact of the skills shortages at a regional level in order to assist businesses in trying to develop a coordinated solution to address the problem. There is no magic bullet and there is not one solution that in itself is going to solve the crisis.

What we have done in the Illawarra is to rely on limited data that has been collected by a range of organisations. I mention that AiG Illawarra did a survey based on 44 local companies. Of those 44 companies—a limited survey—91 per cent said they were experiencing skills shortages. Based on that, current and projected skills needs were 740 positions just in that very small and limited sample. So that gives you some indication of the real crisis and the constraint on economic development that is staring our region in the face.

Regional trends may be quite different for a variety of reasons—sometimes for historic, geographic and cultural reasons. For example, in the Illawarra our close proximity to a booming Sydney labour market in more recent times has had a significant impact on the ability of local firms to attract suitable applicants. In 2001, according to the census data, 17 per cent of employed people in the Illawarra region commuted outside our region for work. That had grown from only three per cent in 1981. What I am trying to say is that regional skills shortage problems have a variety of underlying causes and a multifaceted strategy is needed to address this situation. The problem that we have locally is not just that we do not have enough skilled workers as a result of a general shortage of skills but also that we have an inability to recruit skills that are required locally because the labour market is competitive and often more attractive wages and conditions take labour out of the region.

Through the creation of a local task force in the Illawarra, we are attempting to look at the areas of current and future skills shortages and trying to tackle those through a variety of responses. I urge the federal government to be sympathetic to any applications that come from our region for assistance in conducting a proper analysis and audit so that we can base our responses on the actual problems that we identify locally. Currently, our work is being assisted by the efforts of the Illawarra Regional Information Service and some of the work that it is undertaking for the regional development board. But what seems quite clear in our area is that the shortages are evident not just in the traditional blue-collar trades but also in a number of white-collar employment areas as well.

The overall picture in the Illawarra is that most skilled labour is now in short supply relative to demand. I will list the occupations with the most critical shortages to give you feel of the problems that are emerging: aged care nurses and carers, boilermakers, chefs, electricians, engineers, fitters and turners and truck drivers. So it is not just in the traditional trade areas, where it is so obvious at the national level, that the acute crisis is emerging but also across a range of very important occupations that service community needs.

In the time that I have left I want to say that, disappointingly, the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 does nothing to instil any confidence in me that the government is on top of this crisis which is going to impact on economic performance and productivity. Failure to invest in the development of human capital and skill development is going to be a major constraint on future economic growth. Twenty-four new TAFE colleges to duplicate existing TAFE courses will not address the problem in any meaningful long-term sense. The severe skills shortage that a number of people have addressed in their contributions in this debate has developed while the government has been asleep on its watch. It can blame no-one but itself. I think the bill before us this evening confirms that the government has no coherent strategy or coherent plan to tackle the crisis at the national level and to assist regions like mine that are now facing the constraint of skill shortages. Businesses are running up against that constraint, and the government has no solution to address that problem. My plea is for the government to support innovative solutions at a regional level and provide assistance and resources to local organisations, be they task forces, community groupings or the area consultative committees—whatever framework exists at the local level—to try and analyse and address what is and is going to be a critical problem. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to speak on the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 for a number of reasons, first and foremost because it does go to the heart of a lot of the issues that I have been concerned about throughout my working life both in this place and prior to coming to the national capital. Secondly, I am pleased because it also affords me the opportunity to talk about the general issue of skills shortages. There has been a lot said over the last couple of months on the ageing of the population and the resulting crisis that may occur in our society at various levels, whether it be in health expenditure, the ageing of the work force or work force participation.

speech.para: Along with the member for Gorton—I have to keep reminding myself of that change—I sit on a House of Representatives parliamentary committee which at this very moment is looking at the issues of work force participation. Many of the issues that have been raised by the Productivity Commission, the Minister for Workforce Participation and even the Victorian state government in one of its submissions, which I will refer to, are issues that we are very much aware of. There is a skills gap and a need to entice more people into the work force. Nowhere is that more evident than in the traditional trades. This does give me a good opportunity to speak about some of those issues without going into the outcomes of our parliamentary committee, as it is still early days. But I will reflect on at least one or two points that have crystallised in my mind from some of the evidence that I have read.

Vocational training was rightly a key election issue throughout Australia, arguably no more so than in my electorate of Deakin in Victoria. The blue-collar trades are of critical importance, I guess regardless of where one resides. There is always a substantial number of blue-collar trades, even though we may feel at times that it is in dramatic decline. As I travel throughout my electorate I am fortunate enough to witness enthusiastic tradespeople of all ages contributing to our economy and our society in an important and worthy way. The trade- and vocation-bashing days of the Hawke-Keating era are thankfully behind us. There is more and more talk about valuing a trade and the alternative career path that young people take to the one which was promoted vigorously during the eighties and nineties—namely, going on to university.

As I said, the Productivity Commission draft report came down recently with a series of comments about the ageing work force. It did identify issues to do with the ageing work force. One of the things that have come out from some of the evidence that I have seen is the notion that by 2020 there will be 500,000 jobs in Australia with no-one to fill them. I do not make any judgment about where those jobs are, but because of the sheer size of that figure, and it being only about 15 years away, it certainly concerns me that we could very well have 500,000 jobs with no-one to fill them. It alarms me particularly if they are in areas where we are currently relying on older workers to fill jobs, such as in the trades.
The Victorian government, in a report they brought out recently called Preparing for Victoria's future: challenges and opportunities in an ageing population, say:

quote.para: With fewer young people entering the labour force, it will be increasingly important that all young people gain the skills and training needed to participate in employment. In order to support future growth and the productivity of our labour force, education and training for young people will need to focus on the development of higher skill levels and the types of skills necessary to support new and emerging industries. That might very well be the case, but we also should not neglect the traditional industries out there that are crying out for people to go into them—that is, the trade areas.

speech.para: While I welcome that kind of statement from the Victorian government, I also note that one of the other comments they came up with in their report is about apprenticeships for the group of people aged 25 years or over. The report says:

quote.para: In the five years to 2003 commencements of New Apprentices for people aged 25 years and over grew from 9 700 to 52 000, an increase of 435 per cent. Over half ... of commencing Victorian New Apprentices in 2003 were aged 25 or over.

speech.para: There is an argument there to encourage people to go into apprenticeships at a more mature age rather than simply at school age levels. The Herald Sun also commented earlier this year that in Victoria there are hundreds of apprenticeships that are not being filled by school leavers. Training organisations blame this on a bias towards universities and low pay for apprentices. The school curriculum is targeted towards higher education. We have all known this for many years. I am pleased to see that there is a change of attitude taking place in the community and also at the legislative level.

The growth of vocationally based employment since 1996, contrary to what the member for Throsby said, is an achievement of which this government can rightly be proud. The sector has been reinvigorated, and the number of people in New Apprenticeships has grown to almost 416,000. This number is three times that of 1995. Complementing this is a growth in vocational education and training. Minister Nelson highlighted recently that the most recent figures showed there were close to 1.7 million students in VET in 2002. Significantly, this represents over 10 per cent of Australia's working age population. So we have seen some considerable movement, and we have really only seen it because of the concentration on vocational education by this government.

One of the most memorable experiences of the recent election campaign was visiting the Eastern Industry Education Partnership in Ringwood with Minister Nelson to discuss vocational education with local trainees. It was heartening to see young people—many dressed in their overalls—brimming with pride and enthusiasm that they actually got into the trade of their choice, that they actually had a job, that they were learning some skills. You could see the self-esteem that was emerging in these young people—a sense of self-worth and a belief that they were on a path to a fulfilling career. It is this growing willingness in young people that underpins this government's commitment to developing vocational training opportunities.

The key to future development in vocational education and training is to work directly with industry. The federal government provides $510 million in incentives each year to employers to provide opportunities to new apprentices. I am pleased that the most recent trend in funding through the National Skills Shortages Strategy is continuing. Central to this is the $2 million this year and the $4 million for each future year to tackle shortages in traditional trades such as those of carpenters, plumbers and electricians. At March 2004, 35 per cent of new apprentices—147,000 of them—were in training in the traditional trades.

I find it a little ironic that the federal Labor Party are now beginning to squib for some moral high ground on this issue. The fact remains clear that it was Labor policy that set Australia on the course towards a skills shortage. The member for Throsby stated outright that she believes it is a failure of this government. Skills shortages do not happen overnight. They build up over successive years, and in fact sometimes can take a generation to occur. What we see is very much the culmination of the fact that previous governments ignored the issue and placed the full emphasis on tertiary education for our young people.

The fact remains clear that it was Labor policy that set Australia on the course towards a skills shortage. High unemployment created an initial shortage of places for blue-collar workers. It is fraudulent of the ALP to feign interest in vocational education. I am sure the members opposite remember how the Minister for Education, Science and Training would often entice the member for Jagajaga, the shadow minister in this area, to ask a question on vocational education. He would stand at the dispatch box and urge the member for Jagajaga: `Please ask me a question on vocational education.' This happened throughout the last term. In fact, you could probably count on one hand the number of questions that the member for Jagajaga asked in this area in the three-year period. Now we have come into parliament this term and there is this new-found interest in vocational education and having a hit at the government.

Of course, complicit in this fraudulent concern for vocational education are the state ALP governments. In December 2003 the state and territory Labor governments rejected the federal government's $3.6 billion offer for a new ANTA agreement, a real increase of 2.5 per cent per annum. This represented the state governments walking away from 71,000 additional VET places over three years. They basically turned their backs on the agreement and in doing so turned their backs on 71,000 additional places. The decisions of the state and territory Labor governments highlight the deficiencies of the ANTA agreement. The federal government applied the additional funding offered through ANTA to purchase additional training places for priority groups such as older workers and disabled workers. However, the federal funding for vocational education and training should not need to be administered in such an ad hoc fashion and at the whim and the mercy of state governments who play politics with all Commonwealth funding, no matter what the policy area may be.

Melbourne's eastern suburbs area, irrespective of it being snubbed by the Latham election bandwagon and the Bracks Labor government, continues to be a desirable place for people to live. It remains a strong growth corridor where an increasing number of families require an appropriate mix of training opportunities. Prosperity, however, creates challenges and, rather than meeting these, the ANTA system has failed our local area. I would like to share with this House a real example of how the ANTA funding has failed the people in the electorate of Deakin in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne, particularly in terms of the deficiencies of ANTA's funding distribution process.

I would like to refer members to a very significant government school in my electorate, one which I am certainly proud of: the Ringwood Secondary College. It is a good government school with strong enrolments; it is a strong state government school with a proud history. In fact, it celebrated its 50th anniversary earlier this year, and I was pleased to take the Prime Minister to the school for its celebrations. The school and its principal, Mr Michael Phillips, saw a valuable opportunity to establish an automotive and manufacturing skills centre to assist students throughout the eastern suburbs to obtain an accessible vocational education.

Naturally the first step for the school was to apply for capital funding from ANTA. I was particularly confident—they had a great submission—that their proposal would be successful. Skills shortages were starting to bite in the region as more and more experienced tradesmen were leaving their fields. In fact, the local ACC, Jobs East, back in the early years when I first got elected, did a needs analysis on skills shortages in the area and showed that in the metals industry, the traditional trades, there was a huge gap in people taking up opportunities. The demand for the labour was greater than the supply.

You would think that a proposal by a local school which would help fix the skills gap would be welcomed by ANTA. You would also think that the submission would be supported by the Bracks government, who after all do believe that they should be supporting the eastern suburbs, even though their actions do not prove that. The fact is the Ringwood Secondary College was unsuccessful. Not only did the school miss out; not one application for ANTA funding in the eastern suburbs was successful—not one from any of the schools in the entire eastern region, which of course makes up 40 per cent of Melbourne's manufacturing base.

In appraising what were wrong, it became blatantly clear that the ANTA funding allocation process was flawed. On closer inspection it was evident that successful applicants were located in traditional Labor heartland areas, particularly in Melbourne's western suburbs.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek to intervene.
(Mr Causley)—Is the member for Deakin willing to give way?
—Yes.

—Is there anything in this bill, or is there any other measure that the government has put forward, that would provide funding for the Ringwood Secondary College to provide this excellent training that the member for Deakin asserts is necessary?

—I will be very pleased to elaborate to the member for Denison on that dorothy dixer, and I will get to the point. Yes, not only is the skills centre funded by the federal government, but it is funded in collaboration with the employers the Eastern Industry Education Partnership Group, which looks after young kids in the school. The workshop will be located at the Ringwood Secondary College. The interesting thing is that they have now introduced one other skill, and that is robotics in the manufacturing technology. So you have automotive skills, manufacturing technology and robotics. You have an organisation like ANCA, which is a precision technology organisation; you have AAA, which is the largest manufacturer of airconditioners for the motor vehicle industry; and you have a number of other organisations all in partnership with Ringwood Secondary College. But it is not only for the benefit of that college. Because they will be providing the training for other government schools and, Member for Denison, independent schools in the area, it will include everyone. It is embracing employers, government and non-government schools and those who are charged with finding jobs for young people. So I am very pleased that has taken place—and, of course, not with any help from the ANTA funding process or, can I say, from the Bracks government.

speech.para: The federal government does allocate its funding to the states and territories in accordance with a funding act. ANTA was established to set up planning, accountability and funding arrangements for VET programs. The experience of Ringwood Secondary College demonstrates that the organisation is flawed. In particular, ANTA is a hindrance to effective planning for future vocational programs.

The partisan agenda of the Victorian Bracks Labor government ignored future trade workers in and around my electorate. Significantly, the sad bevy of local state Labor members, many of whom of course were not expecting to be in parliament, has been quiet on the issue, and they have failed to effectively represent the eastern suburbs. I for one have no faith whatsoever in the Bracks government or any of the Labor governments meeting their obligations under ANTA. It has been a dishonest approach by that government, and unmet promises have left many Victorians high and dry.

So I am pleased that this particular project has got up and running. Skill shortages do not occur overnight, as I mentioned. The biggest crisis facing the trade sector is a lack of incoming skilled workers to replenish the work force as experienced workers retire. I certainly recall speaking with many secondary school students in Deakin who described how a failure stigma can follow young school leavers who pursue a blue-collar career.

For many parents of my generation, the old state technical school system was an effective system which produced school leavers of the necessary skills and enthusiasm to pursue a trade apprenticeship. I appreciate that we cannot wholeheartedly go back to that system, but I do look forward to the increased concentration by governments of all persuasions at the state and federal level—and even the community—on placing greater value and greater emphasis on trade qualifications.

This bill is a first step towards achieving that. The abolishment of ANTA in July 2005 is the second step. Certainly, I believe the creation of the trade colleges is a most welcomed addition to valuing the trade areas and also giving real hope and aspiration to young people who are looking at alternative career paths. I welcome the upcoming negotiation of the 2005 ANTA agreement, and I welcome the changes that the minister will be introducing in the next six months.

talk.start.para: —I am happy to rise after the member for Deakin's contribution. I am happy to also acknowledge his interest. He is one of the very few government members who show an interest. Of course, he was Chairman of the House of Representives Standing Committee on Employment and Workplace Relations and I was a member of that committee, and I think it is fair to say that, as chair, he certainly conducted himself well. He certainly showed—
—Was?

—I am hoping he is back for this term, but certainly last term he was chair. He showed an interest. So I suppose it therefore makes it all the more difficult for him to have to get up and defend the government. Because for him to actually get up and boast that one of the great things about this government is that it has abolished ANTA, that it has not supplied the TAFE places required, is an unfortunate thing. It is an unfortunate thing for someone who I believed had a passionate and sincere interest in vocational training. Therefore the government has really placed the member for Deakin in an unenviable position: to have to get up and justify these very crude decisions by this government.

speech.para: However, I rise to lament, as I know other Labor members have lamented, the decline in skills in this country—the skills that have certainly declined since 1996. I accept the contention by the member for Deakin that there were shortages during the Hawke-Keating period. There were shortages, and I will refer to some of those shortages. But I think, when they win four elections in a row, it is about time the government accept that not only are they the government for this term but they take some responsibility for the preceding three terms. It seems to me that they want to carry on and continue to blame—

talk.start.para: —Indeed. As the member for Denison suggests, they clearly consider all things good to be of their own design, whereas of course we know that they are the beneficiaries of many of the policies of the Hawke-Keating period. When the government are in their fourth term, I think it is important for them to start to accept some responsibility for their failures. On occasions in this place I have criticised, with qualification, I accept, some of the deficiencies of the Hawke-Keating period because there were some. I think, in general, there were more better things done than worse things. There were mistakes, we made them and we have acknowledged them. But this government fail to ever accept any responsibility or acknowledge their own failings.

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 6.20 p.m. to 6.38 p.m.

talk.start.para: —Before the suspension, I was making mention of the fact that governments and government members have a responsibility to accept mistakes and failings and to try to rectify them. Unfortunately, it seems that this government wants to continue to blame any fault or any problem with the system, including vocational training, on Labor governments that ended their time in 1996. I think it is important that the government owns up to its own failings. There is no doubt there is a major skills shortage in this country, and it is something that we have to rectify. As we know, before the election, Labor was promoting the idea of increasing TAFE places in order to meet some of those shortages. Unfortunately, the fact that Labor failed to be elected meant that that was never going to occur. But I think it is now important for the government to announce what it wants to do to sort out some of these major problems.

speech.para: As I said earlier, there were skills shortages in the Hawke-Keating period, but the shortage trend has continued over the last eight-year period. The Department of Employment and Workplace Relations estimates trade shortages in construction, engineering and automotive trades, but also indicates that there are many shortages in the area of specialised skills. Some trade occupations have remained consistently in shortage for long periods of time. The department says that trade occupations which have been in short supply for a number of years include pastry cooks, chefs and motor vehicle mechanics continuously from 1994; tool makers and upholsterers continuously from 1995; boilermakers, fitters and turners, metal machinists, pressure welders and sheet metal workers in all but one or two years since 1995; refrigeration and airconditioning mechanics continuously from 1998; panel beaters, vehicle painters and automotive electricians continuously from the end of 1998. We have many skills shortages in our labour market. I will add another. I think the Deputy Leader of the Opposition raised this and it has been raised in question time. We have a critical shortage of bricklayers. I suppose one could say it is nice to see a bricklayer make $100,000 a year. We are probably in the wrong game, Mr Deputy Speaker! But I think that points to a real problem in the workplace; it points to a real shortage.

Two of the occupations which have not been mentioned perhaps as often and for which I think demand is going to grow exponentially over time are those of child carers and aged carers. Whatever the occupational description, those caring and learning industries represent large areas and involve particular skills. We do have a shortage of child carers. One of the reasons for that is that it is market driven. The wage or salary of a child carer is so low that many qualified child carers choose to just get out, because a career in that field is just not worth pursuing if you want to pay for a mortgage—increasingly a more expensive mortgage relative to income—or to do other things. There are real problems in child care. As we know, there is an increasing demand for aged care workers. Again, I think that is a very low-paid occupation commensurate with the skills and responsibilities required of those workers. We really have to turn our minds to that.

In the Australian Industry Group's recently released skills policy statement, entitled World-class skills for world-class industries, which was presented in August this year, it was highlighted that Australia faces a skills crisis in the next five years as the existing work force retires and the number of new tradespersons is insufficient to fill the gap. Labour supply problems are being experienced in many industry sectors but those that have heavily relied upon the traditional apprenticeship system as the major means of recruiting and skilling new entrants have experienced greater difficulties in sourcing skilled labour.

In a survey of more than 760 manufacturers, entitled `Australia's skills gap—costly, wasteful and widespread', the AiG found that one in two firms were experiencing difficulties in obtaining skilled labour. The greatest difficulties were in metal based sectors, particularly for transport equipment manufacturers. High levels of difficulty in finding skilled labour were also evident in the machinery and equipment, fabricated metals and basic metal manufacturing sectors. Across manufacturing overall, there were 21.8 vacancies per 1,000 workers. The highest vacancy rates for skilled labour were in the wood, wood products and furniture sector, which had about 45 vacancies per 1,000 employees, and in the machinery and equipment sector, which had nearly 38 vacancies per 1,000 employees. All other metal based sectors had very high vacancy rates. What that report points to, in quantifiable terms, is that there is a major skills shortage in many occupational groups in this nation.

The AiG estimated that the national skills shortage was 21,000 positions and that filling these positions would deliver a fivefold increase in the number of new people employed in manufacturing over the last 12 months. The largest numbers of skills shortages were in the areas of chemicals, petroleum and coal products; transport equipment; and machinery and equipment—each with estimated shortages of at least 3,000 positions. One report after another confirms the assertion I am making—indeed the contention that the opposition is making—that we have a fundamental problem. It is not being acknowledged by the government. I do not know how they work this out, but they believe there is a nexus between the Hawke-Keating period and the skills shortage in 2004, and they do not want to turn their minds to fixing the problem.

There is a further report. A discussion paper was commissioned by the Dusseldorp Skills Forum amidst concerns over the growing shortage in trade skills. It was presented at a round table convened in July 2003 by Group Training Australia. It presents new data on long-run apprentice training rates by broad occupation groups. The data show a significant and sustained decline in the training rate over the last 10 years. The author of this report discusses the implications of this decline and provides an overview and assessment of the key explanations. I would advise members who have not come across that report to do so because it does provide some of the reasons why there have been these shortages and suggests policy recommendations to address the decline. In short, these recommendations include training levies, an increase in public sector training, changes to employer incentives, improving the quality of operations of group training companies, re-establishing pre-apprenticeship programs, improving VET in Schools, improving multiemployer coordination, increasing innovation intensity of industry and improving marketing of apprenticeships. Those are some of the things the author of that report points to as what we could be doing to fix the problem of the critical skills shortages we have in the labour market.

Instead of looking at some of these things, this government has been blaming others. It has been blaming the states—and, as we know, a favourite hobby of the Commonwealth government is to blame either previous federal Labor governments or, indeed, current state Labor governments for the Commonwealth's failing. It is either doing that or not making much headway in this area. If announcing the abolition of ANTA is supposed to be some sort of beneficial reform, I do not see it. What it does say to me is that it is perhaps a symbolic exercise in what this government really thinks about vocational training.

We in the Labor Party were the creators of ANTA in 1992. We were the ones who supported ANTA and promoted the idea of vocational training. This government have paid lip-service to the notion of vocational training. There are shortages of training places. As a result, there are shortages of skills in the labour market. The government need to focus on those deficiencies. If they do not listen to the ACTU then they should listen to the employers, if that is what they wish to do. If they are not willing to look at a survey that might be commissioned by the ACTU, because of their ideological blindness to the reality of what is going on, they should listen to the employers. The major peak employer bodies are saying there are major skills shortages. Most employers are not sitting around talking about the need to make laws unfair for employees in the areas of termination; they are talking about skills shortages and asking what the government will be doing to fix them.

There is not a great amount of detail on the duplication of technical colleges, which was announced during the election campaign. I do not want to be negative, but it seems to me that it was an announcement for election campaign purposes. On the face of it, it does not seem to be particularly practical. We are going to have a TAFE system and, standing beside that, these Commonwealth technical colleges. Instead of funding the TAFE system that exists, the Commonwealth is now going to divert energy into a separate system so that they will run concurrently but separately. That does not seem, on the face of it, to be a very wise thing to do. As I understand it, it is going to be some time before those colleges are up and running.

As I understand it from the proposal of the Prime Minister during the election campaign, one of those colleges is proposed to be in or around my electorate, in Sunshine. I share the suburb of Sunshine, a great working-class suburb of Melbourne, with the member for Maribyrnong—I am not sure which one of us is supposed to be the beneficiary of this college. It will be a learning institution and, if it is at all effective, constituents of mine and, indeed, of the member for Maribyrnong and of other members will obviously be able to use it. I have to say that my electorate and surrounding electorates do need more places. There needs to be more support for many of our constituents.

If you look at the average levels of unemployment or of skills, I think the electorate of Gorton probably is not as well favoured as other places. It is a great place, it has a great pride and it is a great community to represent, but perhaps it has not been afforded the same opportunities as other places. People do not complain—they get on with it—but it would be great to see money funnelled in there to provide the wherewithal to ensure that my constituents and their children will be able to be properly trained up for full-time employment. Having said that, I am not convinced that the way to go about it is to set up this separate system which will not rectify the fundamental problems we have. Indeed, it will detract from the focus that I think the Commonwealth needs to have upon the TAFE system.

It seems to me that it is going to be robbing TAFE to fund these `you-beaut' tech colleges. I will accept whatever works. As the member for Gorton, representing people who I am sure would delight in more resources going into the area, I am not ideologically predisposed to one particular design or the other. But I do think that the system has to be coordinated, and I do think the Commonwealth have to start being a little bit more mature in the area. Instead of blaming the states, they should be working with them. Instead of failing to reach agreement on ANTA with the state governments, they should be showing some leadership, moving forward and reaching agreement. If they were to do that, they would have my respect—if not my entire agreement on the way in which they proceed.

So there are some significant problems, as I have outlined over the last 20 minutes or so. In so many areas and occupational groups there are deficiencies, and those deficiencies have been cited by employer groups. I would have thought the government would listen to those employer groups when they shout from the rooftops that they have major problems employing people in particular areas because of those skill shortages.

talk.start.para: —I rise today in support of the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004. The purpose of this bill is to amend the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992 to appropriate a total of $1.15 billion as the Australian government's contribution to the delivery of vocational education and training in 2005 and to adjust the currently legislated funding limit for 2004 to reflect the outcome of the ANTA agreement negotiations for that year.

speech.para: This bill supports the Australian government's plans for a smooth transition to new arrangements for VET funding to be put in place from July 2005. The Australian government is committed to maximising vocational education and training opportunities for our youth and continues to deliver real results for the 70 per cent of school leavers who do not go directly to university from school. A hallmark feature of Australia's highly successful VET system is the growth of new apprenticeships and their diffusion through the work force.

Since 1995, when Labor was last in government, the number of new apprenticeships has increased by 195 per cent to over 416,800 in training as at the end of March 2004. Last year, there were 2,300 new apprentices in Dobell, compared with 650 new apprentices in 1995 when Labor was last in government. That stands in stark contrast to the comments of the previous speaker. This growth in new apprentices is in direct response to the needs of industry for skilled workers. The evidence of the program's success is staggering. Employers are embracing higher skill levels, with 85 per cent of all new apprentices in training participating at certificate III level or higher.

Since 1996, the number of women in VET has grown by 30 per cent to 812,900. The number of Indigenous students has grown by 85 per cent over the same period. Forty-three per cent of VET clients are now in rural and regional Australia. The growth in new apprenticeships has been the strongest for people aged 40 years and over, where the numbers have increased almost sevenfold in the last six years. This is a great achievement. The reskilling of mature age workers helps to position industry to address the labour force challenges of the future.

The VET in Schools program is also working well. In 2002, over 185,500 students were participating in VET in Schools. In fact, the number of school students undertaking training has grown by 97 per cent since 1997, reflecting the huge success of the VET in Schools program, which is now available to more than 95 per cent of Australian technical schools. In fact, at the Wadalba high school in my electorate, 84 students in year 11 are involved in VET programs. That is quite an achievement. Next year that school will be doing year 12 for the first time.

The coalition has introduced school based new apprentices and there are more than 14,000 in training today. However, while there has been great interest in service industries, such as hospitality, tourism and business, there has been less growth in school based new apprenticeships in the trades. The coalition is providing $17.9 million over four years to help a further 4,000 school students get into school based new apprenticeships in the trades through group training. Our local work force reaps the benefit from having school leavers ready for work duties, and the only way this can happen is through good policy and strong partnerships between government, educational institutions, training organisations—like Central Coast Group Training, which does a fantastic job locally—and local businesses. The Central Coast campus of the University of Newcastle has been working hard to expand the VET opportunities for its students.

The Australian government has an integrated and comprehensive plan to ensure that the value of trades is enhanced as a career path. This includes providing expanded opportunities for students wanting a career in the trades, better advice on career opportunities, greater financial assistance for new apprentices and industry initiatives to build our skills base of the future. In fact, in my electorate of Dobell—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek to intervene.
(Mr Quick)—Is the member for Dobell willing to give way?

—No. I wish to continue with my speech. In my local area, the group training scheme has been quite successful. They have over 400 apprentices on the local Central Coast involved with many of the businesses. Also, the local Central Coast manufacturers group hosted a meeting of school advisers from all the secondary schools to give them an opportunity to understand where the skill shortages are in the trades. This is a practical way in which people can be involved. One of the most significant boosts to vocational education and training ever undertaken by the government was announced by the Prime Minister in his election commitments. He announced various measures to address industry skill shortages, including the establishment of 24 technical colleges throughout Australia, and one to service the Central Coast. These technical schools are actually years 11 and 12. They are not competing with TAFE in any way, as members opposite would have us believe.

speech.para: This is great news for the electorate of Dobell and for Australia. It is wonderful that we can have an Australian government that is achieving record results when it comes to vocational education and training yet is committed to providing even more funding to VET to further maximise opportunities for our kids. The 24 Australian technical colleges will be created in regions suffering serious skill shortages and high rates of youth unemployment and which are supported by a significant or rapidly growing industry base. The abolition of technical colleges by the states has meant that over the past few decades our young people have lacked training and skills. These pathways would have been provided particularly to the 70 per cent who do not go directly from school to university. The price we have paid is the current severe skill trade shortages we are experiencing in many of our key industries. The colleges will provide tuition for up to 300 students in years 11 and 12 and offer both academic and vocational education to students while completing their school studies.

Earlier this year the Howard government also announced the provision of a Commonwealth Trade Learning Scholarship to enable new apprenticeships in skill shortage trades. The scholarships will provide $500 to new apprentices starting their apprenticeship on or after 1 July 2005 at the end of the first and second years of the new apprenticeship. The initiative will assist around 60,000 first- and second- year new apprentices from year 1, July 2005. Many new apprentices eligible for a Commonwealth Trade Learning Scholarship will also be eligible for an $800 tool kit which the coalition government will provide to new apprentices in areas of trade skill shortage.

The Howard government has taken a leadership role in determining the overall direction and strategies to develop a skilled Australian work force. Skill shortages are always of concern to industry, but, as you can see, the government is committed to providing record funding levels toward VET initiatives to address this. Industry is increasingly recognising that an investment in skills is critical to its bottom line. As a result of the coalition government's investment in training and direct assistance to employers of new apprentices, Australian employers are spending more on training their employees than ever before. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, employers are spending 52 per cent more on training than they were in 1996. The Australian government's vocational education and training program continues to go from strength to strength and is in stark contrast to the poor VET results of the Australian Labor Party.

As I mentioned earlier, new apprenticeships have increased by over 195 per cent since Labor was in government. However, this is not the only evidence of Labor's lack of commitment to the provision of vocational training opportunities. When the Howard government offered a new ANTA agreement to the states and territories in May last year, every state and territory rejected our offer of an additional $220 million of funding for the creation of thousands of new training places. To keep good faith, the government applied the funding which was not taken up by the states and territories to purchase a total of 75,000 training places for priority groups. These are older workers, parents returning to work and people with disabilities. In this way the Australian government has fully maintained its level of commitment to vocational education and training in 2004 despite a lack of cooperation from federal and state Labor.

We have announced new measures in our election commitments to a total value of $1.06 billion over four years. This is one of the largest boosts to vocational education and training undertaken by any government. These new measures include extending youth allowance to new apprentices who are currently not eligible to receive youth allowance, even though they undertake studies while they are employed. This contrasts with the situation for university students. They are enabled to combine study and work while retaining their entitlement to youth allowance and Austudy within current eligibility requirements.

The coalition government will provide a further $5 million over three years in residential assistance to new apprentices who have to move away from their family home in order to start or continue a new apprenticeship. The coalition will provide funding for prevocational training, which is a prerequisite for many businesses. This will provide apprentices with basic skills in the workplace, including familiarity with tools and simple work practices, before they work as new apprentices. It is disappointing that over recent years the states and territories have been slashing places in prevocational training in the trades, limiting opportunities for young people to get a step up into a trade. The coalition government will provide $35.5 million over four years to more than double the new apprenticeship access program, which gives participants assistance with basic literacy and numeracy, employability skills and other relevant work and trade skills.

The Australian government has played and will continue to play a leadership role in the overall direction and strategies needed to develop a skilled Australian work force. Funding under the VET Funding Act in 1995 was $77.9 million. For 2005 under this bill the government will be spending $1.148 billion, underpinning the nation's strong economic growth and low unemployment. Since coming to power this government has revived Australia's vocational education and training system. The numbers in training have grown from 1.27 million in 1995 to over 1.72 million—an increase of 35 per cent. The number of new apprenticeships has grown by 195 per cent to span over 500 different occupations. New apprenticeships are vital to ensure the future economic prosperity of my local region and of our nation. The continuing financial support for the training of new apprenticeships is provided for in the bill presently before the House. I urge members opposite to support this important piece of legislation.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to speak to the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 and want to acknowledge at the outset the great privilege that I had in the previous term thanks to the decision of the then Leader of the Opposition, the member for Hotham, in appointing me shadow minister for employment services and training. The opportunity to be involved in vocational education and training took me to every state and territory, where I was able to discuss the challenges facing Australia in providing a skilled work force and also to talk first-hand to a great many Australians who were providing that vocational training in schools, in TAFEs, in private training organisations and in group training organisations.

speech.para: This issue is also one that I raised continually in the last parliament. Only when the federal election was upon us were skills shortages—which had been created as a direct result of government policy—acknowledged by the government. Before then it was clear that everyone, from peak business organisations to financial journalists and the Governor of the Reserve Bank, had been talking about Australia's emerging skills crisis and its potential to threaten future economic growth. According to Group Training Australia, there are currently national skills shortages in all key trades, including the engineering trades, all the vehicle trades, all the construction trades, all the food trades, as well as the electrical trades, electronics, printing, the wood trades, hairdressing and furniture upholstery. Service industries such as nursing, child care and teaching are also desperate for new entrants, to keep up with demand. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry in its July 2004 survey of investor confidence found that for the first time in 14 years the availability of suitably qualified employees was the No. 1 constraint on future investment decisions. Specifically, 79 per cent of firms surveyed said recruiting employees with appropriate skills was a major or moderate concern.

In September the Australian Industry Group released its survey, which found that more than one in two manufacturing firms were experiencing difficulties finding the skilled workers they needed. According to the Australian Industry Group, the skills crisis was here and now. The government's own department, in the DEWR skilled vacancy index for August, found that vacancies for tradespersons had reached the highest level since such data was collected. Unfortunately it is likely to get worse. Over the next five years 175,000 workers are expected to leave the traditional trades, with only 70,000 expected to enter.

Due to this, the Labor Party established a Senate Employment, Workplace Relations and Education Committee inquiry into skills shortages—something that was opposed by the government because they said it was not an issue. Yet the committee found that a failure to have enough skilled metal, engineering and manufacturing workers to carry out the $20 billion worth of major infrastructure and resource projects expected in the next 10 years would threaten the very viability of those projects. Indeed, it has been estimated that current skills shortages could cost Australia $9 billion in lost output over the coming decade.

The absurdity of this is that, at the same time that you have this shortage of skilled workers, you also have a significant reservoir of untapped labour. In particular, Labor identified and came up with a strategy to address the fact that 45,000 young people leave school early to go nowhere—not to go into further education, training or into a job. The Leader of the Opposition, Mark Latham, deserves a great deal of credit for being ahead of the game. As the centrepiece of his first budget reply, he announced the youth guarantee, a comprehensive approach to tackling skills shortages, addressing the needs of young people and providing them with those opportunities.

That policy is not surprising, because that is part of a proud tradition of the Labor Party. It was the Whitlam Labor government in 1973 that first provided Commonwealth financial support for apprenticeships through the establishment of the National Apprenticeship Assistance Scheme. This scheme was a landmark for apprenticeships in Australia. It marked the beginning of what has been continuous Commonwealth funding for apprenticeships and ensured that they became a national priority. It was the Hawke Labor government in the 1980s that took on the states and territories and put in place new industrial arrangements that enabled the traineeship system to be created in the first place.

It was the Keating Labor government that in 1992 got the agreement of all the states and territories to the establishment of the Australian National Training Authority. This was a statutory body which sought to overcome the inconsistencies of our federal structure and bring a national focus to the delivery of VET. But what we have seen over the last 8½ years of the Howard government is an undermining of this system, culminating in the announcement in a press release—not during the election campaign—that ANTA would be abolished from July next year. It is absolutely outrageous that nothing about this issue was mentioned or put to the Australian people prior to the election on 9 October.

But it is not surprising, because the whole structure of vocational training has been under attack. Indeed, since 1997, real funding per teaching hour has dropped by 19 per cent and the proportion of VET funding coming from the Commonwealth has fallen from 25 per cent to 22.2 per cent. So none of these arguments about the responsibility of the states stand; the Commonwealth has not been keeping up its share of the bargain. Inevitably, these cuts have undermined the quality of training that 1.72 million Australians are currently receiving from the VET sector. At a time when we most needed our federal structure to be working cooperatively, Minister Nelson went along to the ANTA negotiations last year. The states would not sign up because the offer had no growth funding in it and it had the government's ideological industrial relations agenda attached to it, so the minister simply said, `I'll get back to you next October after the election.' He broke off negotiations. That is not surprising, given the decision after the election.

The agreement was supposed to commence on 1 January this year, and the government could not even get its act together to get that in place. It also could not get its act together to have an ANTA CEO, because she resigned some months ago and was replaced by a temporary appointee. We all know now why that occurred, as well. With respect to the government's much-vaunted New Apprenticeships scheme, we know that it has become a numbers driven operation. When the government says there has been a massive growth in new apprenticeships, we know that most of that growth has been in the higher volume, higher turnover industries, as a means to subsidise wage bills, not to provide adequate training in what most Australians would see an apprenticeship as being—that is, a combination of on-the-job and off-the-job training in a profession, be it white collar or blue collar, over a number of years.

The government did announce at one stage during the election campaign—there was a leak in the Sydney Morning Herald—that skills shortages were going to spur a $725 million spree. What did we actually get? We got a tool box to fix the skills shortages. How out of touch! Obviously the government was not aware that construction, electrical, metal fabrication and other awards contain tool allowances of up to $22. If you add that up, you get an amount that is greater than $800. When I raised that with Steve Balzary, from the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, he assured me that no employer out there would seek to have the tool allowance removed, even though they were having their tools provided for them. It was a very bold commitment indeed.

The government also announced an $18 million plan for an institute for trade skill excellence. This was to provide `industry endorsement of qualifications provided by private and public training providers, including TAFE, identifying excellence and the preferred providers of high-quality and industry relevant training'. That was ANTA's job. So they announced a replacement for a national body that has been doing the job and that involves employers, unions, TAFE and the federal-state relationship. They announced its replacement in a five-page document that did not mention the name `ANTA' once. The institute will have four shareholders: ACCI, AiG, the Business Council of Australia and the NFF. The government said: `No TAFE, no unions, no state government. We will just have a focus on one section.' The truth is that employers and employees have an interest in a cooperative relationship when it comes to training, beyond any other policy area that you can think of.

The tragedy is that, certainly in the time that I was the shadow minister for training, I had excellent relationships not just with the trade union movement but with ACCI and the Australian Industry Group. The member for Cunningham is here. I went down to the Illawarra with her and the member for Throsby and sat down with the Illawarra business community, unions, TAFE, training providers and local schools, who all had a common interest. That is the only way that this system works. Yet it is being undermined. As part of this policy announcement the government announced an industry reference group for each key trades industry. What are skills councils for? They are only just in the process of establishing them and they announce a duplication.

As regards the proportion of the $18.3 million that is going to filter down—that is not going to ACCI and business organisations to create a bureaucracy—there are 20 awards for excellence valued at $10,000 each year, for three years. So $600,000 out of the $18.3 million is filtered down—to anybody. Awards are not a bad idea, but it is a pity that the government were not conscious of the way that the system was operating already. The government could not be bothered sending a representative to the world skills conference—a conference where 50,000 young people over three days in May this year went through the Brisbane Convention Centre. But, then again, during the campaign I spoke at the TAFE directors annual conference, a big national event. No government minister showed up; they sent along a parliamentary secretary.
