They could not be bothered during the election campaign to go along and talk to TAFE, the major provider of vocational education and training in this country. That is the heart of the system, and that is the reason why we were very committed to filling the gap, to providing extra TAFE places.

Then we come to the government's plan for `technical colleges', as they call them. They cannot say where they will be, when they will be up and running, and whether or not they will charge fees. Last year, according to the ACCER, there were 415,000 senior secondary high school students in this country; 202,000 of them were doing VET in Schools. It is happening. The member for Dobell, who refused to answer a question, outlined quite well in some of his comments what is going on, on the ground, on the Central Coast of New South Wales. What is going on with schools, be they in Gladstone, Marrickville, the Central Coast of New South Wales, Salisbury in Adelaide or Alice Springs, is that they are linking up with TAFE and local industry and providing an integrated vocational education and training system. It is occurring. Why you would come up with a gimmick, when we have a serious policy issue to confront, is beyond me.
The government senators' report—the Liberal senators' response, not the ALP's response—from the Senate skills inquiry stated, on page 216:

... VET in Schools ... is already active in promoting partnerships between the three education sectors, industry and the local community. There is, in any event, limitations on the Commonwealth in facilitating and promoting these partnerships which are best handled at state level.

No wonder the member for Page—who in a personal explanation today did not question the issue raised by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition—has called for the funding to go to Wollongbar TAFE, instead of having a college. I went to a TAFE college in his electorate during the election campaign, and they are providing a world-class system but they are starved of funds.

What does it say to the 202,000 young Australians who are currently engaged in VET in Schools? Indeed, as a result of a reference from the current minister, the member for Bradfield, to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Education and Training, we had an inquiry into VET in Schools on this very issue. Did the government report say that we should do something about that? No. What it said was that we should do something about the costs, which is why Labor committed in its Youth Guarantee to paying all TAFE fees for VET in Schools students. This commitment looked after the 202,000 people rather than creating another bureaucracy that, sometime into the future at some unknown cost, might be able to have 7,000 students. It is an absurd duplication of resources. This government stands condemned for its lack of action in addressing skills shortages. Indeed, its policies have contributed to these skills shortages which seriously undermine Australia's potential economic growth and rob Australians of the opportunity to participate in the work force.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak this evening not only on the nature of the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 but also, and perhaps more importantly, to highlight what I regard as one of the most urgent economic challenges confronting Australia. It is a major issue that we have to confront in terms of working out how we attract investment for skilling, which will in turn attract investment from the private sector and create further jobs into the future. In that context I indicate at the outset that Labor supports this bill for one reason: to ensure grants to the vocational education sector for the coming year. That is pretty important. The last thing we should do is create any more barriers or difficulties for the vocational education sector at a time of major skills shortages in Australia.

speech.para: Having said that, it is worth noting that, whilst this bill is about funding, it in no way addresses the pressing issues in vocational education and training that need to be seriously debated in this place and in the broader community. I challenge the business sector to actually start to stand up and confront this government about its shortcomings and failings in relation to the economic challenges that confront Australia. I recall that, when Labor was in government, the business sector had a view on issues that were barriers to the future economic and social development of Australia. All I can say is that since March 1996 there has been no leadership from the business sector in confronting Australia about its weaknesses and failings in the economic debate. All we hear about from key business representatives today is the need to make it easier to sack workers and keep their wages down. When do we really see them crying out about the fact that the Howard government has failed since March 1996, almost nine years, to do something about one of the major challenges confronting Australia, not only in the traditional trades but also in the professional area of employment—that is, how we train and skill people so that Australia continues to be competitive in a global world?

I regard this as a most serious challenge to Australia. It is at a crisis point. The Howard government stands condemned for walking away from its responsibilities with respect to these fundamental issues. If we as a nation in the 21st century do not invest in education and training then we are basically failing ourselves and future generations, because we are creating barriers to investment and job creation in the future in a variety of sectors. I raise some important facts. Today there are nearly 22,000 unfilled vacancies for tradespersons in Australia. Those 22,000 unfilled vacancies represent a barrier to attracting investment in Australia, both local and international. That effectively means that we are reducing employment in Australia because we do not have the skills to attract investment and give certainty to the private sector about a return on their investment.

It is also estimated that skills shortages could cost the Australian economy $9 billion in lost output over the coming decade. And all we hear about from the Howard government is the agenda of creating jobs in Australia, which is not about investing in education and training but about trying to make it easier for disreputable employers to actually sack workers. That is their real agenda in confronting the economic challenges at this point in time.

Having been the shadow minister for transport, infrastructure and regional development, I also note that $20 billion worth of major infrastructure and resource projects could be in jeopardy as a result of skills shortages primarily in trades and engineering areas. That speaks for itself. We also appreciate that cuts to public and private sector investment in skills formation in pursuit of productivity and efficiency gains have seriously eroded the skills base in crucial industries and occupations. That effectively means that the private sector has got to have a hard look at its own performance. Reducing investment in training and skilling is actually hindering its own future capacity to make profits. No employer in Australia should think that, by cutting expenditure on the skilling of their work force, they are doing the right thing by their shareholders in terms of maximising their economic opportunities in the future. I think that is something that the government has to have a look at. But some of our superannuation funds also have to have a look at it, because they are major investors in key projects in Australia. They have got to start speaking up about the fact that their potential investment return for workers through superannuation is being reduced by the failure of business generally to invest in the skilling which can potentially create bigger returns for their investments for the future.

I also suggest to the House that, unfortunately, this skills shortage has gone unrecognised by the government, which has turned tens of thousands of young Australians away from TAFE each year. I also believe that we as a community have a problem. For far too long the community, not just the government, has had a view that the only way forward for young people is via university education. That is understandable because of the lack of opportunities for past generations, particularly for the children of the Depression—our own parents—who saw the opportunity of a university education as a step upwards. But the time has come for us to go out and, in a very positive way, promote the fact that doing an apprenticeship is no less an opportunity for young people than becoming a doctor, a lawyer, an optician or whatever. It is just as good to be an apprentice bricklayer, carpenter or chef. They are equally as important in terms of decent employment opportunities in Australia. That requires leadership at a national level. It requires us to work out a strategy in the Australian community to not only create additional TAFE places but sell the community the message that going to a TAFE and doing an apprenticeship is actually good for you as an individual, good for your family, good for your community and good for your nation. We have to confront it—we have failed ourselves—and it is equally as important as forcing the government's hand in terms of putting real money into additional TAFE opportunities in the future.

It is for that very reason that, to address the skills shortage, Labor at the last election promised to create some 36,000 new vocational education and training places each year and to pay TAFE fees—and this is exceptionally important—for secondary students who want to get a vocational qualification. I want to underline the importance of not only putting additional TAFE places in place but also trying to encourage our young people to stay and complete years 11 and 12 and, in doing so, to have under their belts part completion of their apprenticeship so that they are more readily employable by employers willing to take on the responsibility of training young people in Australia. The more apprenticeships we can actually start at school to get our young people job ready and more attractive to employers so that they accept the responsibility of a full apprenticeship is very important not only to some of our suburbs, local communities and families but also to us in taking a big step forward as a community and overcoming the lack of skills in Australia. It is something we should be proud of. It is something that all state and local governments, in association with the private sector, ought to work in a cooperative and consultative way to achieve sooner rather than later.

From manufacturing to science and engineering and in the health and education work forces, the availability of skilled people into the future to replace the baby boomers as they retire will fall far short of the levels required. We also have the problem with the ageing of the population. I am talking not just about the traditional trades such as bricklaying, the metal trades or whatever but also about other areas such as the service sector and aged care. The challenge will be to provide and fund training needs to actually meet growing demand and higher standards. We have heard the Treasurer bash on about the ageing of the Australian population in recent times. It is not just about how we pay for retirement but also about making sure we have the trained personnel in those aged care centres to look after the elderly citizens, who should be treated with respect and dignity in retirement.

I go to the issue of technology and business processes. Changes are also driving additional training needs and new skill requirements in all areas of the work force. The Australian economy will be left behind if we fail to keep up and invest in our future. I have noted the fact that there are far fewer young people entering the work force to build a new skill base. It is well known that Australia's productivity gains over the past two decades were stimulated by economic and labour market restructuring. They were initially put in place by the Hawke Labor government, which was elected in March 1983. When Labor came to government at that time, unemployment and inflation were both over 10 per cent, there was no economic growth and, in essence, there was an industrial war. Over the last two decades Australia has actually come off a very low base. It was what the Labor Party inherited when it was first elected in March 1983. The Australian community should not forget that.

What is also accepted and perhaps less well recognised is the fact that the price we have paid as a result of reduced funding is a reduction in skills formation. According to the Productivity Commission, skills growth as a driver of productivity in Australia has dropped by 75 per cent over the last 10 years. And we talk about a nation that regards itself as being pretty productive. Our failure to invest in skills has actually reduced our productivity.

In that context, I refer to the 2003 Senate report entitled Bridging the skills divide, which noted that the next wave of productivity gains will have to be founded on a new skills formation strategy. Where is that skills formation strategy? It is not in the tool box. It actually requires leadership at a senior government level. I wish it was only as easy as buying a tool box for a young person starting an apprenticeship, but it is far more complex. It actually requires the government to lead and work with state and territory governments and also to work in partnership with the private sector, not the confrontationist approach that the Howard government is currently pursuing with its lack of a working relationship with the state TAFE sector and state and territory governments. To achieve that new skills strategy, I suggest to the House that we require increased public and private sector investment—that is, the government and private sector accepting responsibilities—as well as policy settings and a training delivery network that support new and more effective approaches to skills formation. Seems complex? It is not if you are actually prepared to work your way through those issues.

That goes to the urgency of this issue. What is the Howard government's answer? It was touched on by the member for Grayndler this evening. It is an approach intent on tinkering with a bureaucratic framework, not on delivering outcomes in the vocational education and training sector. I actually thought the establishment of ANTA was a historic moment for Australia. It meant actually getting the private sector, the representatives of workers, the union movement, and state and federal governments in the one room and working together with one common objective—to actually get more investment in the training of apprentices in Australia. I think the government's proposal to abolish ANTA is short-sighted. I also believe that the proposal to establish 24 Australian technical colleges, mainly in—guess what: it sounds like the Regional Solutions Program—marginal coalition seats around the country is wrong. Let us take politics out of the issue of skilling in Australia and pursue in a very dogged way a commitment to actually do the right thing through cooperation, consultation and working together, rather than the Howard government's desire to destroy the existing TAFE system. In that dogged pursuit of an industrial relations policy that is confrontationist, the Howard government is excluding the states and unions from any decision making about skilling in Australia, and that is also narrow-minded and short-sighted.

We should not be ashamed of the VET sector. They have historically been good performers for Australia. We as a nation have prided ourselves in the past on our capacity to train people. Historically, a young tradesperson was able to go overseas and pick up a job anywhere because of the quality of the training through TAFE in Australia. Why would we destroy that? Because of the narrow ideological approach being pursued by the Howard government. You do not have to reinvent the wheel—you actually work to improve outcomes rather than destroy a proven system.

I simply say that the proposal to establish a ministerial council of vocational education ignores the fact that the Commonwealth has—guess what—been unable to bring the states to the table to reach a new ANTA agreement. Why then—and this is a relevant question—if it cannot get the states to the table to work in a cooperative way and get a new ANTA agreement, would we accept that this government would be able to reach agreement through a ministerial council? It is not going to, because the government's approach is basically: `Take it or leave it. We are dictating the terms. You do what you are told or you don't get funding.' I simply say that the proposals by the government are backward. They are not going to take us forward in our requirement to invest in training and skilling to create productivity and make Australia attractive for investment.

Portability of qualifications across the nation is also important. There is no way we should destroy that. We fought too long at a national level in partnership with the private sector, unions and state governments in making some progress on the issue of portability. As we all know, it is also wrong that ANTA be re-established in the Department of Education, Science and Training, where the short-term focus will be on establishing new administrative funding arrangements. This is bureaucracy and red tape gone mad. This government talks about its desire to assist small business. Frankly, all I can say is that it is going to make it far more complicated for small business.

We have got good group training companies, good TAFE colleges and a desire by the Australian community to promote the apprenticeship system in Australia. The system is still attractive, but we need national leadership to reinforce more than ever to our young people as they go through years 10, 11 and 12 that there is a cooperative Commonwealth and state program aimed at attracting young people to do apprenticeships, because doing an apprenticeship is as good as training to be a doctor or a dentist. That is the message that has got to go out, in association with the addition of a national commitment to working with the state and territory system with respect to the development of TAFE. I also note that, so far as I am concerned, the Howard government's ideological approach is going to undermine progress made at a workplace level with respect to skill related career recognition, multiskilling, a desire to reduce the number of classifications through new training arrangements and new work methods to create a more productive work force.

I suggest that the Commonwealth should take a step back. The funding will go through as a result of the opposition's support for the bill before the House, but we ought to think through some of the announcements made on the run during the election campaign and by media release with respect to the abolition of ANTA after the election—something that we did not find out about during the election campaign.

There is a capacity to bring the nation together on the skilling front. State and territory governments, in association with the private sector, want to do the right thing by their local communities. I simply say that the government's proposal to abolish ANTA and create 24 national technical colleges is not going to guarantee that young people will desire to invest years of their future in apprenticeships, because it is not a system that is based on good policy and it is not a system that has general community support.

Alternatively, what the government should be doing is encouraging employers to do more in the private sector to fund and provide training for its existing work force and also attract young people who actually want to work in the skilling of apprentices. As the member for Werriwa said in this place yesterday, there is no more pressing area of government neglect than the underinvestment in TAFE and vocational education and training. We have to get this sector working effectively and efficiently. We have to properly fund our existing TAFE system and we have to get the private sector to play its part in funding and accepting its responsibility to train people.

I reject the view of the government expressed yesterday that the answer to our skilling problems is migration. The answer to our skilling problems, which result from our own community failings in recent decades, is to invest in the skilling of our own work force and also to work to make apprenticeships more attractive. I therefore commend the bill to the House in terms of the additional funding and willingness to actually meet the needs of vocational education and industry in the foreseeable future, but I simply say to the government: have a rethink about your ill-thought-out agenda announced on the run—that is, the tool box solution to apprenticeship training in Australia—and think about investing within private and government sectors in the future.

talk.start.para: —I will be brief, which is not my usual style, because I am also required to speak in the House very shortly. The basic context of the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 is entirely disgraceful. If you look at the history of vocational education and training from 1996 until now it is a disgraceful effort by this government, which has no fundamental commitment to the technical and further education system in Australia. The part it should be playing, to ensure that TAFE is remodelled and extended and to ensure that what the states put in will be matched by the Commonwealth in a way that is sufficient for the purposes of the state system, has been disgracefully underdone. In fact, looking at what is before us today, the explanatory memorandum to this bill is like a short note saying, `Dear Teacher, I am going to be late.' It is just a complete joke. It says: `We have been having a talk with the states, but we have not made an agreement with them. We have our bargaining position, so we are going to legislate our bargaining position and say cop it or else.'

speech.para: We know what the basis of this position is and the people up in the Parliamentary Library know what it is. Their brief talks about what has happened. When this government came to power in 1996 they reduced the funding agreement established by Labor by five per cent. They discontinued a five per cent real growth on base recurrent funding in 1996. What did they do in 1997-98? They compounded it. They said that annual funding to the states and territories needed to be cut to provide `an incentive to the states to achieve efficiency gains in their VET operations'. This reduction was estimated to be $20 million in 1998. It was to be carried into subsequent years, and so it has been.

This government cares nothing about the TAFE sector. It cares nothing about technical and further education. It has proved it in 1996, 1997, 1998, 1999, 2000 and then through to 2003. In 2004 they had an election, so they came up with a bright idea. They said, `If you have a look at what we have done, there is a bit of a problem occurring.' There was a bit of a realisation that the traineeship program they put in place to degrade apprenticeships down to traineeships to boost the numbers and in fact to decrease the quality of the training available to young Australians was causing a bit of a problem. People were waking up to the fact that there was a significant difficulty. What did they do? They proposed to establish 24 technical high schools run by the Commonwealth under Australian Workplace Agreements. That would substitute for what they had not done in the technical and further education area. This is a national disgrace.

In the last year, 250,000 people have come in from overseas to take the jobs that should be there for skilled Australians. Young people who should have access to technical and further education training that will allow them not just traineeships but to come out as fully qualified apprentices have been told effectively: `You need not apply. We're not interested. What we'd rather do is get the Poms, the Irish or people from elsewhere in the world to come in, work on a four-year contract in Australia, and—guess what?—at the end of the four years, with a quarter of a million people a year added to the immigration intake, if they apply to stay in Australia we will not operate the normal immigration guidelines. What we'll do is give them a discounted entry to Australia. They can stay here as a fully qualified plumber, carpenter or tradesman. In that way, we'll try to fix the skills shortage.'

This government will not commit to young Australians and to their education. It has cut the recurrent funding. It has cut out any commitment to their future. It has effectively said to them, `You can have a deskilled future in which you can be on the margins of society.' It is a complete and utter disgrace. How good is it to supply 24 technical high schools to provide what the whole technical and further education system has been attempting to provide? I personally think the people who wrote the Carmichael report were right when they went to Austria and other European countries and said the education systems operative there did a better job of providing skills education, training and apprenticeships. People who went to school in Austria, Germany or Holland would come out with a comprehensive education, but also in those schools—which were full technical high schools across the entire system—with an extra year of training they would come out as fully qualified tradesmen, not just in one trade but usually in two trades. A person would come out as a fully qualified electrician, able to practise, with a certificate that indicated that they had the requisite skills from day one. They would also usually have a second qualification so that if the demand was greater in one area than another they could switch; they were completely multiskilled.

The government do not understand the needs of this country when it comes to the skilling of our young people—or, worse, they do not care at all. They are willing to import people and then provide through the immigration system—effectively secretly—what they will not supply through proper funding to the states. They are not willing to grasp the nettle and say that we need a renovation of the technical and further education system. They are not willing to do the hard work and say to the state governments, `We need to look at a complete review of education from year 7 to year 12.' It used to be that 38 per cent of students stayed on until year 12, but a Labor government took it to in excess of 80 per cent and we are on the way to 90 per cent. We need to look at the actual needs of all those students and determine whether or not we should have a complete recast of the system so that those Australian students who want to enter trades, who want a real apprenticeship, who want real qualifications, could be supported both by the state governments and by the Commonwealth so that they get real training, real qualifications and real jobs at the end of it.

What do we have instead? We have a government that says: `This is what we're putting on the table. Take it or leave it. You've got reduced qualifications, but what we'll wave in front of you is 24 technical high schools.' It is a complete and utter disgrace. It betrays the aspirations and the future lives and livelihoods of every young Australian who wants to do the right thing, to work—and work hard—and gain a qualification to take themselves through. There will be other occasions when I can return to this debate. I am required in the other place to speak on health—I am told by the deputy whip that I have got a couple of minutes, so I will run on her instructions. This is a total, complete and utter betrayal of every one of those kids who goes into school in year 7 and who in the past, before we increased the amount of time they would spend at school, would normally want to come out with some reasonable expectation of being able to devote themselves to trades.

In this and the last parliament, Brendan Nelson, the Minister for Education, Science and Training, has put on a show of deeply felt concern about people who want to have a go and want to get some kind of qualification. This government is rewriting history, saying that the Labor Party is not concerned with young people and their educational concerns, that the Labor Party is not concerned with what the outcomes will be and that the coalition is the friend of the worker and the friend of the person who wants to get a trade. That is complete and utter rubbish.

This mob do not give a damn about the future of those people, as evidenced by what is proposed in this legislation and by their version of reduced funding to the states, reduced Commonwealth input, efficiency and productivity gains and all the rest of it. They know that traineeships are worth far less than the old apprenticeships. They know that Telstra, the state rail authorities and the other main education providers in the past have left the field. They know, or should know, that Australia is effectively deskilled and the great chance that we had to provide an education system that would allow young people to train here in Australia, have an apprenticeship and be fully qualified to work within Australia or earn income for Australia overseas in Asia is gone.

This government are reprehensible in their failure to properly deal with technical and further education. They have put forward a total con job not only with regard to apprenticeships and traineeships but also with regard to technical high schools. I call on them to retract the approach they have, to have a look at secondary education Australia wide and to do the right thing by young Australians by providing them with a real future, real access to apprenticeships and real access to an education system that will provide them with a guaranteed future instead of the farce that they are presented with now.

talk.start.para: —The Howard government's record when it comes to vocational education and training is absolutely abysmal. Despite its much touted New Apprenticeships scheme, this government has overseen a massive increase in skills shortage. This skills shortage is having an enormous impact on industry and Australia's ability to compete internationally.

speech.para: The Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 will provide Commonwealth grants to states and territories to support them in their role as providers and administrators of VET. These grants are for capital and recurrent purposes and are passed to ANTA for allocation amongst states and territories. They ensure the grants to the vocational education sector for the following year. It is interesting to note that this legislation does not deal with administrative changes arising from the proposed abolition of ANTA.

Before I came down here, I was looking at the percentage of GDP that this government have given to vocational education and training. That figure as a percentage of GDP is down. It is very interesting that, day after day, we listen to the government trying to convince the Australian people that they are doing a good job, that they are there to address the skills shortage and to make sure that all Australians have the appropriate skills that they need to find work and to meet the needs of industry. But, when you take a good look at the situation, you find that that is anything but the case.

Over the years I have worked in the area of employment. I have appreciated the benefits of vocational training and how it has contributed to retraining and opportunities for Australians who want to either enter the work force, re-enter the work force or maintain their employment and move along the corporate ladder or move through various occupations within whatever industry they are involved. But under this government we have seen people's options shrink and industry has become quite concerned about skills shortages. When I start evaluating and looking at why this happens and try to work out just what level of commitment the Howard government actually has to vocational education and training, I look to its first budget. One of the first actions that it undertook was to make massive cuts to TAFE—and, I must say, TAFE has never recovered from that. It is really interesting to see that, following the election, the government is now thinking of setting up in opposition to TAFE. I will be watching that very carefully. I will be monitoring these new technical colleges that the government has promised the Australian people. I will be watching very carefully to see that there is no duplication of services and that they are actually delivering—delivering to the people who are undertaking training and delivering to industry.

This government's inaction over a long period of time has resulted in this enormous skills shortage. It has created an absolute crisis within industry and it has created a crisis for those people who are looking for work. I think one of the organisations that properly is fairly supportive of the Howard government generally is the Australian Industry Group. They have done a number of studies. They have undertaken some really authoritative studies in this area, looking at the skills shortage throughout the whole of Australia and in the Hunter, which is part of my electorate. I will spend a little bit of time examining those issues. The first statement they make in the report before me, World-class skills for world-class industries: accelerating reforms to vocational education and training, is: `World-class industries demand a world-class training system.' Going through this document you will see that the Australian Industry Group believe that here in Australia we have anything but a world-class training system. What we have is a training system that has been run down; we have a training system that has been degraded by this government. On the other hand, we have had growth in industries, but the training system is totally fragmented, and it has become much more fragmented under this government. There is a shortage of skilled labour across Australia and industry has identified this as an emerging problem.

I noticed earlier that the Chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment and Workplace Relations referred to an inquiry that that committee has been undertaking into workplace participation. As a member of that committee I have been privileged to take evidence throughout the whole of Australia. A common theme throughout that committee's deliberations, submissions and hearings has been the skills shortage and the fact that on the one hand you have a skills shortage and on the other hand you have people who want to train but cannot link into the appropriate training. When you link that to the ageing of our population and some of the assumptions that have been made in that area, I think that we have a real problem unless the government truly embraces the need to address this skills shortage and the crisis that exists in Australia today.

I looked through the DEWR skilled vacancy index for 2003-04 to see some of the areas where there is a skills shortage, some of the occupations where vacancies cannot be filled. It shows that there has been a 21 per cent increase in vacancies in the metal trades, a 38 per cent increase in the electrical and electronic trades, a 45 per cent increase in the printing trades and a 17.9 per cent increase in the construction trade. The sad fact is that many of these vacancies are not being filled because of a lack of people within our work force who have the appropriate skills. This is purely and simply a result of the government's inaction in this area. It is also appropriate to put on the record that there has been an 8.9 per cent increase in vacancies in the past 12 months. In the Hunter region, 61 companies reported a total of 805 vacancies in 2004, 85 per cent of the companies surveyed were experiencing skills shortages—that is quite a considerable skills shortage—and 633 vacancies recorded were at trade level and above. What is needed is more than rhetoric. What is needed is a government that is prepared to address this issue.

There are also many anomalies in the training system. Constituents have visited me with their children—young people who have been unable to gain entry to appropriate training courses because the number of training courses has shrunk. In two cases that I can think of off the top of my head, parents have brought to me their sons and daughters who have undertaken training at, say, a certificate level III course. There has been a problem with an employer and, because these young people have undertaken training for a certain period of time, they have been ineligible to undertake any other apprenticeship training. This created real hardship for these young people, it created real heartache for their families, and it really limited their vocational options and their work options. It is a flaw in the system, which this government has failed to address and which I have detailed much more thoroughly in previous speeches in this House. When we are looking to address skills shortages, we have to look at them from the perspectives of the industries and of the people who would like to work in those industries. I do not think that is happening at the moment.

I will focus on the Hunter for a short time. Regional industries face many challenges and opportunities in the years ahead. Traditionally, the Hunter has been a region where industries have been established because it has been seen as an area with a highly skilled work force. But, unfortunately, in recent times this has changed and the skills base of the work force has dissipated. That is very sad, because I know that there are a lot of young people in the Hunter who would be more than happy to undertake training in the trades. When I was working in that area, of all the young male students who had left at the end of year 10 or year 12 with a strong desire to undertake an apprenticeship, very few were able to obtain that much sought after apprenticeship. Similarly, for young women keen to obtain apprenticeships in areas such as hairdressing there were not the opportunities for them to undertake the training. The government needs to address this issue.

As I was saying, it has been three years since there has been an emergence of a shortage of skilled labour with Hunter employers. This has impacted on their ability to tender for contracts. They would have been able to tender if there was a skilled labour force in the area. As I mentioned earlier, there are a total of 805 skilled vacancies. That is for 61 employers who currently employ 6,400 people within the Hunter region. That represents a vacancy for every eight employees in the work force. That is really significant. There are positions for electricians, boilermakers, fabricators, labourers and engineers. All these positions remain unfilled. They cannot find applicants who have the right skills, the right qualifications or the right experience to meet the needs of industry. From my perspective, that is a missed opportunity. It is a missed opportunity for the employers; a missed opportunity for the people who could be filling those vacancies; a missed opportunity for the Hunter, which concerns me very much; and a missed opportunity for Australia, which concerns me even more.

It is also interesting to break up those vacancies and take it a little bit further. The skilled vacancies are higher in the smaller firms—that is, firms with 30 or fewer employees. They have a vacancy for every four members of their work force. That is really significant: four employees, one vacancy. It is very worrying. Medium sized firms have one vacancy for every six employees. Larger firms, with 100 employees or more, have one vacancy for every 10 employees. Employers are not receiving the applications. Those who do apply do not have the appropriate skill levels or the appropriate qualifications. The one thing that is constant throughout this is that there is a skills gap within the existing work force. This is a real problem for industry in the Hunter region. It is also a real problem for Australia.

Australia is part of a global economy. As such, if we want to succeed, if Australia really wants to embrace this global economy, we must have a highly skilled work force. We need people who can work in industry and who can perform at the highest level. Almost every firm in the Hunter is identifying gaps where they would like to employ people, gaps in training programs and gaps in their existing work force. That is of great concern to me, and I know from the deliberations of the committee that I have been a part of that the Hunter is no different from other areas within Australia.

What really worries me is that all we receive from the government are platitudes. We do not receive action. We do not have the kinds of responses that will really develop benefits for all those fine industries and employers in the Hunter and throughout Australia. We also do not have the kinds of responses that will deliver jobs and outcomes to all those workers who would desperately like to work in industry. We need long-term solutions to address these skills problems. We need to encourage industry to take on more apprentices and we need to have the capacity for those apprentices to be trained. That capacity has been significantly dissipated by the government's cuts to TAFE and to vocational education.

As I have already stated, the percentage of GDP that is going to vocational training has decreased dramatically under this government. We need more apprenticeship training. We need more pre-apprenticeship training too. Employers really love pre-apprenticeship training schemes because they actually get apprentices who have got the skills to work in the workplace when they start working. We need increased financial incentives for employers, we need targeted recruitment and we need programs put in place that will allow more workplace training.

What we really need, more than anything, is a government with a bit of imagination. We need a government that is committed to Australia, committed to industry and committed to providing quality training to young Australians, to Australians in the work force and to older workers. We need a government that embraces lifetime learning and puts Australia first. We need a government that puts Australian industry first and is not mean spirited but is broad minded and forward thinking.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr HARDGRAVE
talker.role: Minister for Vocational and Technical Education and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —in reply—I am delighted to follow the member for Shortland and remind her that contributions to the states and territories have risen from $777.9 million under the Australian Labor Party—her party—to $1.13 billion under this government in this calendar year. That is an increase of 45 per cent, and in real terms is an increase of 23 per cent. The Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 in fact indexes the base further to make it $1.154 billion that we are putting out to the states and territories under our vocational education funding agreement.

speech.para: This is about making certain that the money continues to flow. We see the contribution which is offered through this bill to the states and territories as important. We would have liked to do more. We wish we had been able to get agreement between the states and territories and the Commonwealth in 2003, because there would be many more tens of thousands of people in trade training circumstances if we had been able to get that agreement up. But without agreement the funds continue to flow—it is an undertaking that Minister Nelson and I gave to the state training and education ministers as recently as just a week and a half ago. Perhaps that news has failed to filter through, in what is an uneasy time between the federal Labor Party caucus and the rest of the Australian Labor Party around the country.

Mr Deputy Speaker Wilkie, as you realise, a strong economy is driving an enormous amount of jobs growth. We have gone from a position under the previous government, where kids were looking for jobs and were going through the debilitating process of not being able to find employment, to this amazing circumstance where there are jobs looking for kids. In my own electorate of Moreton I am amazed at how many businesses are now saying: `Juniors required. Please apply within.' The signs stay up, not for a day but often for weeks, waiting for someone who is actually available to take that job. That is where strong economic growth has delivered for the average Australian and the average family. As a government, we want to make sure that the workers in those circumstances are well trained and have the opportunity to get access to what is regarded as world's best practice in the area of vocational and technical education.

This underpins Australia's ability to compete in an increasingly global market environment. It is absolutely vital to ensure our continued economic growth and the continued prosperity of this country. As a government, we are committed to vocational education and training. It is shown by the significant funding that is being provided through this bill, and I thank the opposition for its support. As well, of course, through the election campaign well over $1 billion of initiatives were announced, and they will be delivered through the budget next year. These initiatives address skills shortages and some of the particular needs of young apprentices and their employers in order not only to get them in a trade and help them with the equipment they need—the tools for that trade—but also to ensure that they stay and do not drop out of their apprenticeships as, tragically, some young people do. The drop-out rate is not as high as the one in three who leave university, but it is nevertheless a significant factor. So we want to target some of those, and we are.

In 2004-05 this government will spend a total of $2.1 billion on vocational education and training, of which more than $725 million will go to supporting new apprenticeships through direct incentives to employers and through the network of 500 new apprenticeship centres, the NACs. We have also announced new measures in our election commitments with a total value of $1.06 billion over four years. This is without doubt one of the most significant boosts to vocational and technical education ever undertaken by any government.

The Prime Minister's appointment of a minister to target this particular area of vital economic importance further demonstrates the high priority that he and indeed the government place on meeting the skills needs of industry. I am greatly honoured to have the opportunity to do that and to talk to people in regions around Australia, such as the Hunter. I will be there talking to industry, because industry is contacting us. TAFE training providers, private training providers and schools are contacting us and expressing an interest in being part of the network of Australian technical colleges.

I hope the member for Shortland and her colleagues on that side of the chamber encourage people to participate fully in the development of what will be centres of excellence that will say to students studying in years 11 and 12 that having a trade skill outcome from their years of education is as good as—and I would argue in fact better than—any university degree. University degrees are terrific things to achieve but we need people with trade skills in situ today. Those people are in the strongest position in our economy. We need to keep investing in them.

The vocational education and training sector is now in this transitional stage of national arrangements. On 22 October the Prime Minister announced the abolition of the Australian National Training Authority, ANTA, and the transfer of its functions to my department from July 2005. I want to pay tribute to ANTA. It was established in 1992 to coordinate the levels of government in setting up a truly national vocational education and training system. Of course, a dozen years later, with industry leadership, this national system is in place. It is a significant achievement of ANTA and indeed all the stakeholders in the national training system that we are now delivering industry endorsed, internationally renowned and nationally recognised qualifications that certainly are the envy of many other countries around the world.

The transfer of the ANTA functions to the department acknowledges the maturity of the system that has been created. It acknowledges the achievements of the national training system to date. It does not mean that there is going to be any reduction in effort—in fact, quite the opposite. The Prime Minister has announced that a new ministerial council will be established and this will ensure the continuing harmonisation of a national system of standards, of assessment and of accreditation. This will allow a clearer focus on the critical issues which are facing our country, such as the skills shortages that all speakers in this debate have talked about.

I want to stress that the government have a very clear intention. We want this national system to continue and we want industry's central role to be maintained and indeed enhanced in what lies ahead. In recognition of industry's role in the vocational education and training sector, the Howard government will establish the Australian Institute for Trade Skill Excellence. This institute will provide industry endorsement of qualifications provided by both private and public training providers. This institute will identify high-quality and industry relevant training.

The strength of Australia's economy has seen a strong increase in demand for skilled workers. As I said, for too long success in Australian society seems to have been measured for years 11 and 12 by getting a university degree. We want to make sure that young people making decisions about what to do next are as committed as we are to challenging the view that the new apprenticeships and vocational education are somehow second-best to university. We want to continue to provide even higher quality alternatives to the 70 per cent of Australia's young people who do not go on to university.

With the establishment of the 24 Australian technical colleges in regions all around Australia, regions which need an enhancement of the skills base, we will provide pride and excellence in the teaching and acquiring of trade and craft skills at the secondary school level. These colleges will provide tuition for up to 7,200 students in years 11 and 12 and will offer both an academic and a vocational education outcome. We want to make sure that, at the end of that year 12 experience, having attended an Australian technical college a student can still make the choices they make today. But we hope that, having been immersed in a vocational and technical education sector along the way, most, if not all, will take the path of a trade skill outcome.

I want to again emphasise, as I had to in the House of Representatives chamber today—and I am happy to keep doing this until those opposite abandon the negativity in opposition for opposition's sake and adopt a more positive approach—that these Australian technical colleges are not going to bypass or duplicate existing institutions. Rather, it is all about the Australian technical colleges working with existing education and training providers, developing new opportunities for young people interested in a career in the trades. The government will also provide greater financial assistance to new apprentices in skill shortage trades by offering a Commonwealth Trade Learning Scholarship and providing tool kits. The Youth Allowance will be extended to new apprentices, and third-year apprentices living away from home will be eligible for residential assistance.

I think this parliament has reason to be very proud of the excellent achievements of the Australian vocational education and training systems. Since coming to power, this government has set upon a course of reinvigorating the national training system. Those opposite should be interested to know this: the latest figures show that in 2003 there were more than 1.7 million students in vocational education and training. This represents more than 12 per cent of Australia's working-age population. That is an increase of 35 per cent over 1995's figures. I know those opposite want to talk it down, but the facts are getting in the way of their continuous story.

The numbers for new apprenticeships have grown to around 400,000 in training—nearly three times the numbers that were in training in 1995, when the figure was about 140,000. Today new apprenticeships are available in more than 500 occupations, including emerging industries such as aeroskills, electrotechnology, information technology and telecommunications. In fact, the report by the National Centre for Vocational Education Research which was released just last Friday highlights that new apprenticeship commencements in trade and related occupations have in fact increased by 18 per cent, with an estimated 66,900 commencements in the 12 months to 30 June this year. New apprenticeships in electrotechnology are up 21 per cent; in construction they are up 15 per cent; in hairdressing they are up 23 per cent; and in the automotive retail, service and repair industry they are up 12 per cent. These are all areas of skill shortages, all areas which the government is focusing on. The Australian Industry Group described these figures as `some of the best news heard in this area for some time'. The Ai Group is correct in stating that this government has made addressing skill shortages `a major priority'. That is what is really going on, but if you listened to those opposite you would never know about it.

Since 1996 the number of women in vocational education and training has grown by 33 per cent, to reach some 834,400 people. That is about 42 per cent of total new apprentices in recent years. Australians of all ages are benefiting from this government's constant and successful vocational education and training policies. Last year more than 200,000 senior secondary students enrolled in vocational education courses, reflecting the outstanding success of the VET in Schools programs, which are now available to more than 95 per cent of Australia's secondary schools. At the same time, older people are also very well represented in vocational education and training. In 2003, 30 per cent of all VET students were aged 40 years and over. So I am astonished by any negativity from those opposite in the face of the statistical underpinning of the government's argument in favour of this legislation.

I am pleased to inform members that my colleague Minister Nelson has written to state ministers on behalf of the government offering them certainty of funding for the whole of 2005, which will be maintained at the real value of funding in 2004. This bill will provide that certainty. Funding for the first six months of 2005 has been offered under a rollover of the current ANTA agreement and funding for the second six months of the calendar year to come will be conditional on the acceptance by the states and territories of the new Commonwealth-state funding agreement that will be developed early next year. This bill appropriates funding for the full 12 months, enabling the states and territories to plan their ongoing vocational education training and delivery.

Members opposite have raised matters to do with the purchase of VET priority places. These places were initiated in 2004 when the states and territories did not sign up to the agreement for 2004-06. Through my department this funding will continue in 2005 and, of course, it can be incorporated in the new Commonwealth-state funding agreement if this decision is taken with the state and territory governments.

I thank all who have contributed to this debate and I note the interest of a lot of members in this area. From the government's point of view, we are very pleased to see the Australian Labor Party, the workers party, becoming interested again in training issues. I commend the Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 2004 to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.
